text:
**Garbage in, garbage out**
Charging families for each bag of rubbish they throw away seems like a good idea for the environment and for money. But it might not be. In many developed countries, people have a regular service to collect their rubbish. Rubbish bags or bins are taken away by a special truck to a dump. This service is usually free. Families pay for it through local taxes, but a family that throws away a lot of rubbish pays the same as a couple that throws away very little. However, collecting rubbish is not free. The more rubbish people throw away, the more trucks and workers are needed, and the more money local governments spend on dumping it.
If rubbish disposal is free, people will throw away too much rubbish. A simple solution is to make families pay for the rubbish they throw away. This would encourage them to throw away less and recycle more, if local governments help with recycling. 
Two American economists, Don Fullerton and Thomas Kinnaman, studied some towns in the U.S. that started charging families for rubbish. The most common way was to sell stickers that families put on their rubbish bags. Only bags with these stickers were picked up. In one town, Charlottesville, Virginia, families paid 80 cents for each sticker. 
At first, this seemed like a good idea. The number of bags thrown away dropped by 37%. But many people just packed more rubbish into each bag instead of buying more stickers. This is not good because machines at dumps can compact rubbish better than people can. The total weight of rubbish collected only fell by 14%. In other towns without a pricing system, the weight of rubbish also fell, but by only 3.5%. 
Some people even started to dump their rubbish illegally instead of paying for collection. This illegal dumping might be responsible for 30-40% of the drop in collected rubbish. However, there was a positive side: recycling increased by 15%. This means people chose to recycle instead of paying to throw away their rubbish. But many people were already recycling before the new fees.
In a later study, Fullerton and Kinnaman looked at rubbish disposal in more detail. They found that charging for rubbish does reduce the amount thrown away, but not by much. For example, if sticker prices go up by 10%, the amount of rubbish only goes down by 0.3%. This is less than in other studies. To throw away much less rubbish, people would need to buy less of everything. A small tax on rubbish is unlikely to change much.
It is also important to think about other factors, like income and education. In richer towns, people throw away more rubbish and have less time to recycle. So, should we say that charging families for rubbish is a bad idea? Not really. Free disposal is too cheap. But the effects of these simple ideas can be complicated. We often need detailed studies to understand them, and sometimes the results are not what we expect.

**Work and Life by Theodore Zeldin**
Theodore Zeldin talks about how our work life could change. Do you feel respected and appreciated at your job? Success in a career is not enough anymore. Many people feel their work is not valued or understood. Even famous people can feel unhappy despite their success. 
Loving your job used to be enough to feel special, but now you need to think about how your job affects you as a person. This is an important question. If your skills make you boring and unable to talk to others, then no amount of money or status will make you happy. 
Zeldin wants to find ways for work to help us feel fulfilled. Work should not just be about making money; it should help us live better lives and discover new talents. However, just creating more jobs is not enough. As people learn more, they want jobs that are interesting and meaningful.
Even jobs that used to be respected, like doctors and architects, can be stressful and unfulfilling. Many workers feel lost in their roles, and companies are not helping them feel connected to their work. In Britain, only 8% of workers feel their values match those of their companies.
Zeldin is studying different jobs to see how they affect people. He is looking at important topics like happiness, love, and respect. He believes we need to think about who we want to work with and how we can feel more alive at work. 
For example, many people work in hotels, but they often feel unappreciated and overworked. Hotels could be more than just places to sleep; they could be cultural centers where people from different countries meet and share experiences. Hotel workers could use their skills and knowledge to create better connections with guests.
Zeldin believes that work is about relationships. Many people want to feel independent and should be able to design their own jobs and choose their colleagues. Good communication is important, but it should be more than just talking. Real conversations create respect and understanding between people. 
Every time we have a meaningful conversation, we can change the world, even if just a little.

**BROADCASTING: The Social Shaping of a Technology**
The word 'broadcasting' originally meant to spread seeds widely by hand. It is not just about farming; it also represents hope for growth and success. This idea suggests that there are resources available to help spread information and ideas.
We need to understand why a new technology that sends words and pictures electronically was set up in a way that fits this farming idea. Television, like the telegraph and telephone, can allow two-way communication. However, from the beginning, it was seen as a way to send information to many people at once from a central place. This way of broadcasting matched the social and economic structures of modern societies.
There were some attempts to create different ways of using television. In the early 1930s, radio enthusiasts in Britain tried to make two-way television to replace regular telephones. Many science magazines wrote about how to build television equipment, and many people experimented with it. But in 1938, big companies agreed on rules for television that pushed these amateur efforts aside. This was a missed chance for television to develop as a more equal way of communication.
Broadcasting was connected to strong economic interests and the structure of modern societies. Even though there were amateur TV activities, television was mostly used for public shows in the USA in the early 1930s. Many people watched television in public places, especially in Britain and Germany.
The idea of amateur two-way television was not successful. Instead, companies wanted to sell television sets for homes. As working-class people began to earn more money in the 1920s, having a home filled with entertainment became possible for many people in Western countries. Now, this is happening all over the world.
There is a clear link between social changes and how broadcasting works. As societies modernized, power and money became more concentrated, and traditional communities broke apart. People became more mobile, which made them feel more isolated compared to earlier, stable communities. Centralized broadcasting helped governments share important information with all citizens and created a sense of community in the nation.
Broadcasting became the main way to share information through radio and television. However, there is also a positive view of broadcasting as a way to support democracy. During the time between the World Wars, many countries saw broadcasting as a way to ensure everyone had access to important information for participating in society.
Television is changing now, and the term broadcasting may not fit as well as before. In the future, it may only refer to a specific way of using audio-visual technology during a certain time of social change.

**Clutter**
Sometimes, it feels like no matter how many things you own, you still do not feel safe. It is normal to want a home that meets your needs, but sometimes we want too many things. Modern advertising makes us feel insecure. It tells us that if we do not have certain things, we are not good enough. 
To see how much advertising affects you, try not to look at any ads when you walk down the street. We see many ads on TV, radio, newspapers, magazines, posters, t-shirts, and the internet. All of these tell us to buy more things.
**Caves**
Many researchers and universities study caves. They look at where caves come from, how water moves in them, and the plants and animals that live there. Caves are small but interesting parts of nature. They make us curious and want to learn more. Because caves are natural, people have studied them for a long time, especially in places where caves affect our lives. 
However, visiting many caves can be hard, so cave research is often done by people who enjoy exploring caves, not just by scientists.
**Weather Watch**
Many people have watched the weather for a long time without any special tools. This helped create the science of meteorology, which has become very advanced since the 17th century. Now, satellites and electronic tools give us a lot of weather information quickly. Computers can solve complex math problems much faster than people can.
Meteorology uses many difficult words that are hard to understand. But human experience is still very important for making weather forecasts. What people observe can help scientists understand the weather better.

**MUSIC AND THEATRE**
Not long ago, I thought that opera was mainly theatre. Now, I think differently. After working at a national opera house, I learned that music is the most important part of opera. This is how it should be. But I come from the world of theatre, where words and actors are very important. In theatre, there is no one directing the action once it starts, and the audience usually understands the language of the actors.
At any music performance, like in a concert hall or an opera house, there are many people who do not know much about music. Some might feel embarrassed about this. Most people are amazed by the talent of the musicians. A great singer or a good orchestra is easy to admire. Even a good musician shows us the results of many years of hard work. Watching top-class music is like watching a sports match. We know athletes do something similar to what we do when we run, but we see how much better they are.
Theatre audiences have different expectations. They often do not understand how skilled an actor is and may not be very impressed by what they see. They might ask, "How do you learn all those lines?" but they do not usually feel amazed when an actor finishes a long speech. This does not mean that theatre audiences are less demanding than music audiences; many people enjoy both. In theatre, audiences and performers meet on more equal ground, no matter how difficult the play is.
The question is, can music learn anything from theatre? I think yes. I have seen how a different approach can make the experience of concert-goers better. Live music is very theatrical, full of feelings, and can connect with the audience. However, the way music is often presented, with strict dress codes and a lot of respect for conductors and soloists, can make it feel like there is a big difference between the musicians and the audience.
Sometimes, music audiences clap between songs or after a great performance. This is a way to show appreciation, but it can also interrupt the flow of the music. Is there a solution? Yes, many people are working to bring new audiences to concerts and opera houses and to make them feel that "serious" music is for everyone.
I remember a special event called "In Search of Angels," where the performance moved around a cathedral and into the town. It was a wonderful musical experience, and many audience members were not just watching but also taking part. I wish music could have more of the excitement and boldness that the best theatre can show. Sometimes, this can happen in unusual places, where expectations are changed. This can create surprising effects for both performers and the audience. 
I know that most plays are performed in a traditional way, similar to concerts. However, I believe that music can and should change how it is presented. I am just a fan of both theatre and music. I love them and want more people to enjoy the pleasure of being part of the audience.

**Sand**  
I think sand is amazing because it can be changed into useful things like glass and concrete. But I do not like it when it is just sand on the beach. To me, sand is a problem. It gets in my face, my food, and can even hide important things like car keys and coins. When I am wet, sand sticks to me and is hard to wash off, even with a lot of water. But when I step on a towel, get in a car, or walk on a clean carpet, the sand falls off easily. For days, I find sand everywhere when I take off my shoes and socks. Sand stays with you longer than some illnesses. So, I do not want sand around me.
**Lock and Key**  
People have always wanted a safe home. A long time ago, they used simple locks, but now we have electronic locks that use cards. However, many people still prefer to use a real key. They feel safer when they can turn a key in a lock. One company made a new electronic lock but included a real metal key because people want that feeling of safety.
**Modern Art**  
I was nervous to visit the new Tate Modern gallery because I do not understand modern art very well. I like some of it, especially soft things, bright light sculptures, and big photos. I think if I knew more about art, I would have more opinions. But art is not just about understanding; it is about feeling something. This gallery tries to help visitors understand the art better. The first thing I saw was the labels next to the art. These labels explained what the art was about. Instead of just looking at the pictures, I could learn more and understand them better.

**Every Picture Tells a Story**
Making a movie from a book often means cutting down the story. This can be hard for the writer, but it can also help them see things in a new way. When I worked on a movie script, I noticed that I could remove a lot of the dialogue and descriptions from the book and still tell the same story. This does not mean that the original words were not important. It is about how each type of story (books and movies) asks the audience to pay attention in different ways.
In a book, we often repeat important details about characters and use phrases like "he said" to help readers understand. We only need to describe a character once, but reminding readers helps them remember. In movies, we can often tell who is speaking just by looking at the scene, but using speech tags can make it easier to follow.
When we watch movies, we can feel like we are part of the story. It takes us away from our everyday lives for a while. But when the movie ends and the lights come on, we are back in the real world. Some people, like our parents and teachers, thought movies were just for fun and not real art. They enjoyed watching movies but did not see them as something important.
**The Film Studios**
The Leiper Film Company studios were made up of many different buildings. It was hard to find your way around because there were no clear signs. There were three main entrances, but they all looked the same. It was confusing for anyone who did not work there. However, the people who worked there knew how to get around. Because of their hard work, people could enjoy stories of romance and adventure in movies. Couples like Jane and George, or Sally and Dick, could escape their everyday problems for a few hours thanks to the studio.
**Film-Makers**
Many people want to make movies. Bookstores have many books about how to write scripts and make films. Universities offer classes on this too. There are contests where you can win a camera to make your own movie. Robert Rodriguez made a famous film called El Mariachi for only $7,000, and it helped him become a well-known director. He wrote about how he wanted to make his big movie before he turned 26, just like famous directors did when they were young.
In the past, it took longer for directors to start making movies. They often worked in other jobs first, like editing or writing. For example, John Huston was 35 when he made his first film, and Fred Zinnemann started directing in his forties. But now, many new filmmakers have to find their own way without the help of big studios or TV.

In the past, there were many council houses on the western side of the city. These houses were small and not very nice, made of orange brick or white plaster. In the summer, a bad smell from a factory nearby filled the air. In the mornings, you could often see a paperboy making a face because of the smell as he walked to deliver papers. I don’t remember much from my early life, but I do remember sitting by a window and looking at the houses far away. 
I also remember my mother. She was a small woman who often seemed angry, and I never really understood why. When I went with her to the shops, I noticed that she was very alone, even in a crowd. She cared a lot about behaving properly, which was not common in our neighborhood. This meant we had to keep off our neighbors' gardens and sit quietly at the dining table, listening to the radio. There were many rules I didn’t understand.
My mother had a few friends. There was Mrs. Buddery, who loved the Royal Family, Mrs. Winall, who hardly spoke, and Mrs. Laband, who was more lively. Looking back, I see that they often talked about sad things, like their health and their children. I felt like I was part of their conversations, even when I didn’t want to be.
Growing up in West Earlham was not easy. Until I was five, I stayed at home and played while my mother sat in her chair. After I turned five, I went to school half a mile away. Some kids had mothers who rode bikes, but mine let me walk with other children. 
I remember summer holidays when I saw a little of the world outside West Earlham. There was an old man next door who told stories about his life at sea. Once, there was a charity event where a kind woman offered lemonade, but my mother didn’t want to join because she thought they just wanted money. My mother often talked about how people were greedy, especially politicians.
My mother did care about my education. Sometimes, she took me to the Norwich Castle Museum on the bus. We looked at paintings together. She even made a joke once about a painting of a Roman soldier, saying she wouldn’t want to meet him at night. This was a rare moment of fun with her.

**Philadelphia Avenue**
I walked down Philadelphia Avenue on the side with odd numbers. It was getting dark, and the air was humid with a light drizzle that made my walk feel secretive. I knew this side of the street very well. Our neighbors were the Matzes and the Pritchards, and there was Han Kieffer's grocery store. The Krings and the Pottses lived nearby, and they were my first friends, all girls. 
The houses on this street were special to me, even if I didn’t know everyone’s name. I remembered the little channels in the cement that carried rain from the roofs to the street. I used to skate and ride my scooter over them. As the street went down, the houses changed too. The porches got lower, and the front yards got smaller. 
Over the years, things changed. Wooden porch railings were replaced with iron ones. In Shillington, some houses I remembered became stores, and some stores, like Pep Conrad's and Han Kieffer's, became homes again. I wondered how people lived in those spaces that used to be filled with products. 
**Bachelor Fads Furniture Designer Rick Gilbert**
Rick Gilbert lives in a flat that used to be a curtain warehouse. It has big doors and exposed brick walls. But Rick did not want his flat to be completely open. He said it was hard to work when everything was in view. So, he used a big piece of plastic to create a hallway and hide his office. 
He wanted his kitchen to be a place where he could cook for friends or make coffee for clients. To make the flat feel warmer, he put light wood on the floors. He has modern chairs and sofas, but he also has furniture from his parents and things he bought at markets.
**Bruce Chatwin**
Bruce Chatwin was a writer who loved to travel. His life was full of secrets and stories. He wrote a famous book called *In Patagonia* in 1977. This book changed travel writing. It was exciting and imaginative, like a thriller or a romantic story. 
Chatwin sometimes changed facts to make his stories better. He believed that traveling could help people discover amazing histories and adventures.
**Swimming**
One summer day, it was raining heavily. I ran across the lawn behind my house and jumped into the pool. I swam back and forth, watching the raindrops create bubbles in the water. The best moments were when the rain got stronger, and the sound of birds disappeared. 
During this summer in 1996, I thought about swimming across Britain. I wanted to follow the rain as it traveled to the sea. I felt frustrated with my life, always going back and forth like a tiger in a cage. 
Many places today have signs and labels, making everything feel the same. But walking, cycling, and swimming let us explore the wild and old parts of the world. A swimming journey would help me discover the mysteries of nature, like dark woods and high mountains.

**Crying**
Charles Darwin thought that crying did not have a clear purpose for humans. But he was probably wrong. Scientists today say that crying is important for social reasons. For example, psychiatrist John Bowlby showed that crying helps create a strong bond between a mother and her child. Many people believe that children cry because they feel helpless.
It is harder to understand why adults cry. The sound of crying is not as important as what we see when someone cries. In early human groups, crying may have helped people trust each other and feel close. 
People cry for different reasons. We might cry to show sympathy for someone who is suffering. Sometimes, we cry without meaning to when we hear beautiful music or moving speeches. We may also cry when we watch a sad movie, and this happens more often when we are with other people than when we are alone. 
Crying has a social purpose, but scientists are still studying it.

**The Heat is On**
We all know about global warming, but how much warmer will the Earth get? How will it change our lives? Most people have some idea about global warming, but they are not sure what will happen because of it. A warmer climate will change the weather everywhere. Since the atmosphere affects everything on Earth, these changes will also impact plants, animals, water, and soil.
Humans use natural resources to help us live. We grow food, build cities, and support billions of people. If these resources change, it is a serious problem. We need to understand how the world will change and what is causing these changes. 
In the last 100 years, human actions have increased the amount of certain gases in the atmosphere. These gases are connected to global temperature. It seems that these gases are already affecting the climate, but we do not fully understand how everything works together. 
Scientists have found that the Earth has warmed by about 6°C in the last century. Most scientists believe this warming is not just natural and is partly caused by human pollution. Many scientists are trying to predict what will happen because of higher global temperatures. They use special computer programs called general circulation models (GCMs) to help them. These programs look at temperature, pressure, sunlight, and other factors to make predictions about the climate. However, these models are not perfect and can be slow and expensive to use.
Despite these challenges, most people agree that climate change will happen faster than before. The predictions suggest that by the year 2100, the average global temperature will rise by 1°C to 3.5°C. Sea levels will also rise by 15 to 95 cm, and there will be changes in rainfall patterns. Scientists expect more extreme weather, like heatwaves, floods, and droughts.
These changes will affect the environment and humans. Climate change can change where forests and grasslands are located, what plants and animals live there, and how these areas provide resources we need. This includes food, water, and places to live. Some effects may be very bad, but not all changes will be negative. In some places, like Australia, warmer temperatures have helped increase wheat production.
However, small changes in climate can also lead to water shortages, especially in dry areas. For example, in the Mediterranean region, there has been less rainfall in recent years. This can cause problems for people and nature. 
Another issue is that glaciers are melting, which affects ice and water levels. The Arctic ice is melting, which makes it easier for ships to travel but also increases the risk of icebergs. 
The most visible effect of global warming will be rising sea levels. Warmer water takes up more space, and melting ice adds to this. Many people live in coastal areas, so rising sea levels can cause serious problems. Cities like London, New York, and Tokyo could face flooding, and many people could lose their homes. 
Small island countries are at the greatest risk. If sea levels rise too much, these islands could disappear. This would be devastating for the people living there and for other countries that would have to help those who are displaced.

'Mission to Mars
Wanted: a married couple for a 501-day trip to Mars. The couple should be healthy and strong. This will be the first group of astronauts to go to Mars if Dennis Tito's plans work. He wants to send a spacecraft on 5 January 2018. The spacecraft will take the crew to about 160 km above Mars. It will use Mars' gravity to come back to Earth without using more fuel. Saving fuel is very important. The trip must happen in 2018 because the next time Mars and Earth are close is in 2031. 
There is a lot of work to create new technology for this mission. If everything is ready in time, the spacecraft might go. Even if it does not leave Earth, the work will help future missions to Mars.'

**AESTHETICS**
Art is important, but sometimes it is hard to understand. This is because we often think of art as just a building, a book, a painting, or a statue. We forget that art is also about how people feel and experience it. When we only look at the art itself, we miss its true meaning.
Some artworks are very famous and admired. Because of this, people create rules about them that can stop new ideas. When art becomes a classic, it can feel separate from the people and the life experiences that created it. This makes it hard to see why art is important in our lives.
To understand art better, we need to connect it to our everyday experiences. Just like mountains are part of the earth, art is part of our daily lives. People who study art should help us see this connection.
To really understand art, we might need to forget about it for a moment. We should look at the simple things in life that we enjoy. For example, we can enjoy flowers without knowing much about how they grow. But if we want to understand how they grow, we need to learn about soil, air, water, and sunlight.
Many people enjoy things like movies, music, and comics, but they do not always think of these as art. When art is only seen in museums, people often look for enjoyment in other places. Some people do not like the idea of art being only in museums, but they still think of art as separate from everyday life.
When art is connected to our daily activities, we appreciate it more. The best times to enjoy art are when it is part of our normal experiences.

**Observing Lions**
Lions are often seen as amazing hunters. In stories, they work together to catch their food, moving quietly and quickly. They seem like friendly animals that help each other. However, after many years of watching lions in the wild, we learned that they are not always like this. 
When we started our research in 1978, we wanted to know why lions hunt together, take care of their young, and scare away other animals with their loud roars. We thought that working together would help them have more baby lions. But sometimes, if one lion helps too much, it can lose out. So, we wondered why lions still work together. We thought we would find answers in two or three years, but lions are very good at resting. 
Because lions can live up to 18 years, it has taken a long time to understand their behavior.
**Pop Music Review**
Bedrock's third album was very important for the band. The album, called *New Life*, changed rock music in the country for many years. It moved away from the serious and dark music of the past and brought in lighter and more fun sounds. 
The music mixed social ideas with humor and had a mix of different styles. Bedrock showed they were good at collecting ideas and writing songs. They wrote about everyday things like sunbathing and relaxing on Sundays. But the best songs were deeper, like "So Low," which was about the weather, and "To the Brink," which was a serious ballad. 
*New Life* is special because it has 16 great songs with no bad ones, which is rare for long albums.
**Extract from an Autobiography**
As a child, I loved stories about 'The Sibyl,' wise women from ancient times. I first heard about one from my mother. An old woman from Cumae tried to sell King Tarquin of Rome nine books for 300 gold pieces. He said no, so she burned three books and offered him six for the same price. He still said no, so she burned three more. Finally, he bought the last three for 300 gold pieces. I learned a lesson about sales and life from this story.
I was often lonely as a child. I wanted to play with other kids, but they would say no. My mother told me to do something interesting so they would want to join me. It worked, and I never forgot that lesson.
When I got the chance to write a travel book, I looked for something I liked. I don’t like to travel much, so I gave my editor a long list of places I didn’t want to go. I prefer to think about old ruins because I enjoy traveling in my mind through time.
**What Happens to Your Manuscript?**
When you send your manuscript (your written work), it will probably go into a big pile of other manuscripts waiting to be read. This pile is called the slush pile. Usually, a young person or an experienced worker will look at it. They want to find something new and interesting.
If they like your work, they will show it to a senior editor. This editor will decide if your manuscript is good and if it can sell well. They will also think about whether you, as an author, can be successful in the future. Publishers often want to meet authors before they make an offer.

**Advertising on Trial**
If you work in advertising, the early 1990s were very hard years. The economy was in a recession, which means many businesses were struggling. This recession was worse than expected and lasted a long time. In Britain, in 1991, the economy shrank, interest rates were very high, and many people lost their jobs. More than half a million people were unemployed, and many homes were taken back by banks because people could not pay their mortgages. Every business was affected, especially the car and building industries, which saw a big drop in sales.
People in advertising were not the only ones losing their jobs, but those who kept their jobs felt a lot of pressure. They were expected to help their companies make money, but they had to do this with smaller budgets. They were told to do more with less money. At the same time, companies started to realize that marketing was very important. They needed to make products that customers wanted, not just what was easy for them to make. In the last ten to fifteen years, many companies began to focus more on marketing.
Because of this, marketing people started to get more respect, but they also had more work to do. Many people thought that marketing could solve all problems, but this was not true. About half of marketing budgets were spent on advertising, so advertising people felt the pressure. The 1980s were good for advertising, but the early 1990s were very difficult. The bad economy made companies cut their advertising budgets and think more about how effective their advertising was.
Companies wanted to know what they were getting for their money. They needed proof that advertising worked. Many companies said they wanted better strategies, better targeting, better creativity, and better results from advertising agencies. They wanted the best people working for them and to be very motivated.
Even though advertising is a tough business, many advertising workers faced the same problems as their clients: how to do more with less money. The recession made it hard to spend money on advertising, and companies were afraid to take risks, which are often needed for good advertising. Other changes were happening too, like changes in the population, the power of retailers, and new laws about advertising. Some companies also had to learn how to advertise in other countries.
Because of the economy and these changes, advertising people had to think about the saying: "Only half of my advertising works. The trouble is I don’t know which half." Now, more than ever, they needed to make sure their advertising was effective. However, help for them was not easy to find. Companies and advertising agencies were too busy dealing with problems to share their experiences. Those who were successful often kept their methods secret. This meant that while some events could help, many books and resources about advertising did not provide useful information. They often made it seem like all advertising work was perfect, which was not true and did not help the people who needed to make advertising work better.

**The Kitchen's Appeal**
When I was in university, I wanted to be a chef. This was not a common choice among my friends. Most people wanted different jobs. Being a chef seemed hard and not very nice. Chefs work long hours, have a lot of pressure, do simple tasks, and do not earn much money. But I still wanted to be a chef. I was not happy at university. The work was difficult, and the social life felt closed and too serious. Being a chef seemed like a good escape from this. It promised a real purpose that I did not find in college.
My wish to cook was not just because I was a student. I also loved the beauty of cooking. I first felt this when I ate at a famous restaurant in London. The meal was amazing. I remember my first dish very well. After that meal, I wanted to learn all the secrets of cooking. I changed my student life to prepare for becoming a chef. My history degree felt unimportant, and I learned about cooking by reading cookbooks, visiting markets, and making special meals.
**The Swimming Instructor**
The swimming teacher at my school was a tough man with strong muscles and tattoos. When I asked him to teach me how to dive, he told me to sit on the edge of the pool, put my hands above my head, and roll forward, pushing off with my feet. I practiced this until the lesson was over. The next time, he had me stand up and dive off the edge. He was strict, and every time I came up from the water, he would say things like, "Don't look down, look up!" and "Keep your legs straight!"
The following week, I went to the high diving board. It was very high, and I felt scared. I tried to remember what I learned, waved my arms, looked up, and jumped. For a moment, I felt like I was flying. But when I hit the water, I fell awkwardly, and my legs were everywhere. The instructor looked at me with disappointment. But I still felt very happy. I thought, "This is what they mean by 'free as a bird.'"
**The Traveller**
For people who like comfort, like a nice bed and running water, the traveller seems strange and interesting. These are people who choose to take risks. They climb dangerous mountains, sail alone on small boats, and eat insects if they have to. They can live for months in unknown places. Some people think these travellers are odd, and they are different from us. We can ignore them and be happy in our own lives with microwaves and phones, where the risks are small and predictable.
**Sailing**
Jonathan Raban is afraid of the sea, which is why he spends a lot of time on it. He does not say he is a great sailor, but he is good enough. He sails because he is a writer and wants to write about his experiences. Sailing gives him stories to tell.
Raban's small boat has a device that tells him exactly where he is on the earth. He likes this tool, but he also believes that using a compass was a mistake. He thinks it changed how people connect with the sea. Now, sailors look at the compass instead of watching the waves and feeling the ocean. The sea, which used to be full of life, is now just a space to cross. Because of this, a sailor can let a machine steer the boat for a long time. This is why Raban has time to watch the waves carefully.

**Holiday Reading**
Summer gives us two great joys: leaving home and reading books. These joys are connected. Books can help us feel at home in the world. We can relate our own experiences to those in great books from the past or from faraway places. In these books, we find our own thoughts and feelings. Authors can express what we feel but in a clearer way. They can say what we are shy or confused about, and this can be surprising, especially if the author is from a different time or place. We feel thankful to these authors for helping us understand ourselves.
When we read or travel, we can escape our daily routines. Our eyes are wide open when we first arrive in a new place. This is also true when we read a great book, which helps us notice things we usually ignore. Our minds become more aware of the world around us. We start to see the colors of the sky, the changes in a person's face, or feelings we didn’t know we had.
**Author's Note**
These travel thoughts were published in the Observer newspaper over seven years. I have made some small changes to the original articles, but not much else. I corrected a few mistakes, but I did not want to change too much. For example, in my article about China, I thought the Hong Kong dollar would stay strong, but it fell a year later. If I changed the article to show this, it would not be the same as what I felt at that time. Like many travelers, I was there, not knowing what would happen next, just trying to understand what I saw.
**Ecotourism**
If there were awards for tourism phrases that have been misused, "ecotourism" would win first prize. This term started in the early 1980s when people became more aware of the environment. Tour operators realized that many travelers wanted to make sure their trips did not harm the places they visited. Soon, "ecotourism" became a popular term for holidays. Now, it can mean anything from living with remote tribes for two weeks to a short boat trip in Australia. Any tour that includes cultural experiences, beautiful nature, wildlife, or a bit of adventure is often called ecotourism. While the original idea was good, the lack of rules made it hard for travelers to know what ecotourism really means.
**Transylvanian Journey**
I lost my notebook about my trip to Transylvania for 50 years, but I found it again a few years ago. It helped me remember that time, but it was not perfect. In Transylvania, I had a much easier time than I expected. I moved from one friendly house to another, often staying for weeks. When I stayed in one place for a long time, I stopped writing because I thought there was nothing to record. I was slow to start writing again when I moved on, and sometimes I only wrote short notes instead of full stories. I worried that some details might be out of order when I started writing this book, but then I realized it didn’t matter much. So, I let the story tell itself without too many worries.

**Fashion**
Fashion is often thought to be a new idea that started with capitalism in the 19th and 20th centuries. However, many historians say that fashion, in terms of style and design, has a long history. They often look at the growth of trade in the 16th and 17th centuries as the beginning of fashion. As societies grew and changed, more people needed different types of clothing, and new ways to make clothes were invented. Because of this, the meanings of clothing have also become more complex. Today, it is hard to say what a piece of clothing really means. For example, a man's suit can mean different things to different people and in different situations.
**Writer**
Stories in newspapers about famous authors can give a wrong idea about what life is like for most writers. For many of us who are not best-selling authors, there are two main ways to earn money. The smartest writers work at other jobs during the day and write in the evenings. This way, they have a steady income even if their book does not become popular. Others, like me, do different small jobs, such as teaching and writing articles. I have heard of a writing job at a chocolate factory, but I have never found something like that. Still, by balancing part-time jobs and using credit cards, and often thanks to the help of friends, I manage to write my novel.
**Sudden Fame**
The small places where we performed started to fill up with fans, and we needed extra security to keep the excited girls back. We had to use secret doors to enter the places we were playing to avoid being overwhelmed by fans. On the few nights we were not working, it was hard to go outside without being followed by fans. In just a few days, we became famous. Our fans watched our every move, and our management took care of everything we needed. Even though I was still shy, I felt a strange confidence that many shy people can understand when they suddenly become famous. In short, I felt very out of my comfort zone.

**Music - The Future Ahead**
Technology is changing our lives at work, home, and in our free time. Susan Hallam talks about how this affects music in Britain. In the late 20th century, there were many new ways to listen to music, like radio, TV, records, tapes, CDs, and videos. However, there are fewer live music performances and fewer full-time jobs for musicians.
More people can access music now, and this is likely to continue because music meets many human needs. In Britain, music is important for national events and personal activities. A society without music is hard to imagine. The question is not if there will be music in the 21st century, but what kind of music it will be and if people will still want to learn to play instruments.
I believe that people will still want to learn instruments. The music industry is a big part of the economy in Britain, and musical skills are important for many jobs, especially in media. Also, playing an instrument can help develop skills in children. Research in the USA shows that making music can improve thinking skills. Studies in Europe suggest that group music lessons can help children make friends and focus better in school.
Current research is looking at how playing an instrument can help people learn other skills. For example, practicing regularly can help with good study habits, and playing in concerts can teach punctuality and organization. Because of this, there will likely be a continued need for music lessons in the near future.
What about the future? I think two things will happen. First, people will listen to more types of music, mixing different styles. Second, technology will be used more to create and perform music. This will make it easier for people to compose music without needing a lot of technical skills, but it may also mean fewer live performances.
More people of all ages will want to make music together in their communities, reflecting their local musical traditions. To prepare for this future, music education needs to change. We need to help more people learn different instruments throughout their lives. This means music lessons will need to adapt to be relevant for more people.
Musicians will need training to inspire and teach learners of all ages. They will also need skills to work with different groups and manage community projects. This is a big change from how things are done now, and it will require accountability to the public. 
This is a chance for everyone in music education to show the high quality of music teaching available. Finally, we need to make music more important in our lives. Music is essential, but we often take it for granted. Everyone in the music profession should work together to change this.

**The Actor's Craft**
Sometimes, people do not respect actors. This is often because actors talk about their work in interviews. Instead of sharing their feelings, they use boring phrases or gossip. The actor Paul Scofield once wrote to a friend that acting is only interesting when it is happening. Talking about it makes it less real. Each time an actor performs, they start fresh and learn new things about their character and the story. After a play ends, the actor feels empty until the next performance. This emptiness shows when people talk about acting.
**A Review of Hamlet**
Adrian Lester plays Hamlet, a character between being a boy and a man. His performance is simple but strong. He shows great control and confidence. Lester plays a young man who feels angry but also has a sense of humor. His acting is very skilled. You can see how he moves his body, waiting to act. Another actor, Handy, plays Horatio and also shows a strong inner feeling.
So, what is acting? Is it copying real behavior or creating something new? This is an important question in theater.
**One Director's Approach to Rehearsal**
This director has a special way to start rehearsals called "dropping in." The stage manager shows the script on a screen. The actors listen quietly. When it is their turn to speak, they look at the screen, think about the words, and find a reason to speak. For example, if the line is about waiting in the rain, they should breathe and remember a similar experience. They should not plan too much and trust that something will happen.
**The Perfect Theatre**
The perfect theater should make you feel important. Going to see a live performance is special, and the staff should feel this too. It is not nice if the workers act like it is just a job. The theater should connect the actors and the audience. People in the audience should be able to see and hear everything clearly. The size of the theater is important. It should fit the human voice and body. If the theater is too big, it feels wrong because drama is about people. Many theaters built in the late 1800s were good because they made the stage feel close to the audience. 
When you go to the theater, you want to see something surprising and new. If not, you might as well stay home.

**Paul Simon**
Rock and roll music in the 1950s was very popular with young people. It was important because it changed the lives of many adults too. This music helped create new rock stars who were inspired by it. Paul Simon, like many young people in the US, listened to a famous radio show called Moondog Rock'n'Roll Party, hosted by Alan Freed. This show was very important for many future rock stars. 
Paul Simon was excited by the music he heard on Freed's show. He wanted to move from just listening to music to making his own music. 
**Snow**
I could not see a path, but I thought I would be okay if I was careful. The wind was very strong, and it pushed me over as I tried to walk on the slippery ice. Suddenly, the snow under me broke, and I fell into a hole that was about four feet deep. The snow had covered a gap between two rocks, and I did not see it. I climbed out of the hole, feeling scared and shaken. I wondered what would have happened if the hole was much deeper. I sat against a pine tree that was sticking out of the snow to think about what to do next. After an hour, I had only walked half a mile. I realized I had to change my plans.
**Qualitative Research**
There are many books that help researchers understand qualitative research. These books talk a lot about how to collect data, but they often do not explain how to analyze the data. This makes it hard to understand how researchers do their work. To help with this, we asked different social scientists who have done qualitative research to share their experiences. We wanted to help people understand how to analyze qualitative data, not just create a guidebook. This is not an easy task. We let our contributors share their work in different ways, including personal stories and more formal writing.

**Screen Learning**
A few days ago, I saw my six-year-old son eating noodles in a funny way. He was pulling them up with his teeth and pretending to be a dinosaur. "I'm a little dinosaur," he said. He was acting out a scene from a TV show. I asked him what he remembered about dinosaurs, but he didn’t remember much.
Many people think that learning on the internet and computers is good. But is it really a good way to learn? One writer talked about using an interactive program with his son. The father read the words while the son played with the pictures. The father thought that if his son had spent ten minutes reading a book, he might have learned something.
Research shows that learning happens best when children talk with teachers or parents. It is important to have conversations. Using new technology to teach our children is fine, but traditional education is still very important.
**Hollywood**
By 1918, most of the world’s movie-making was in Hollywood. People who lived there did not like this change. They thought Hollywood was becoming a place for rude people. But in the end, they accepted it because success is important. Success is measured by how much money a movie makes.
Hollywood has changed a lot in less than a hundred years. It went from a small village to a famous town, like New York or Paris. A long time ago, you would walk through orange trees to get to the store. But now, it is still a place where everyone talks about movies: how much money they made, who is dating whom, and who is working on what project. Many successful people want to work in Hollywood but live somewhere else. Still, it is the place where everyone in show business wants to be.
**Photography**
Photography was created by artists in the 1800s. They wanted to make a lasting record of what they saw. With new tools, they could create images that were more real and detailed than paintings. This surprised other artists. Some critics said photography could not be art because it depended on machines. But photographers believed they had found a new way to express themselves. They used photography like other artists use paint and pencils to show their view of the world.
**Book Illustration**
In the past, every children's book had pictures. This was also true for many novels for older readers. During this time, children's publishing was mostly low-budget, which meant some work was not very good. However, the best artists always did their best work. 
The collection of black-and-white illustrations is a mix of good and not-so-good work. It is a great place for research and finding interesting things. Some of the best illustrations will be shown to the public again, either through new books or exhibitions. There are signs that this is starting to happen, and soon, a publisher will likely create a series of classic children's book illustrations from this time.

**Blogging: Sharing with the World**
Some time ago, a website talked about the dangers of telling everyone where you are online. When you say, "Hey, I'm here," you are also showing your location to many people, not all of whom you might want to meet. This shows that sharing everything online can have bad sides.
The internet gives us many chances to share our lives with a lot of people. We might think this will bring us money or fame. But sometimes, we share too much and get lost in the online world. It can feel sad, but we should not give up. There are lessons from people who used the internet before us.
In the early days of the web, some brave people explored it. They faced many problems, lost jobs, and learned hard lessons about sharing online. These early bloggers have stories that can help us today. 
In January 1994, a 19-year-old student named Justin Hall started sharing his life online. The web was new and mostly used by students and scientists. Hall wanted to share his experiences. He created a blog where he wrote about everything in his life. People were interested in his stories. 
But one day, his blog disappeared. Instead, there was a sad video called Dark Night. Hall had fallen in love, but when he wrote about it, his partner said he had to choose between the blog and their relationship. Hall felt that sharing his life online made people not trust him. 
In 2002, Heather Armstrong had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job. One day, a coworker shared her blog with their bosses, and she lost her job because of it. This shows how what we say online can come back to affect us in real life. 
Armstrong was sad and stopped blogging for a while, but later she got married and started a new blog about her family. Now, she is very popular as a "mommy blogger," and her writing helps her family. 
Armstrong learned an important lesson: the internet lets us say anything, but that doesn’t mean we should.

**Enough Sleep?**
Many people today feel tired. In rich and busy countries, not getting enough sleep and feeling anxious are common problems. In the USA, research shows that 40 million people have trouble sleeping. Some popular books in Britain have characters who cannot sleep or are about sleep research. 
A sleep expert says, "People need more sleep." When people are busy, they sleep less. They wake up early to avoid traffic. One researcher did an experiment. He let people sleep for up to 14 hours a night for a month. After three weeks, they started to sleep about eight hours a night. This shows they needed more sleep.
In Europe, a university in England studies sleep. They look at how tiredness affects sailors, how noise at airports disturbs sleep, and how tired drivers can be dangerous. They ask students to help with their research. Students are paid £5 an hour and change their sleeping habits based on instructions.
Dr. Louise Reyner helps the students feel comfortable. Some worry because they wear electrodes on their heads, thinking the researchers can see their dreams. But the researchers are more interested in how the body works. 
In a dark room, there is a driving simulator. Students come in the afternoon after not sleeping well. They drive while answering questions. The road ahead looks endless, and the sun is bright. The young men say they will not fall asleep. But Dr. Reyner has a video of one student trying hard to stay awake. At first, he sits up straight, but then he starts to blink and nod off. Each time he wakes up, the car goes off the road. Drinking coffee can help. Dr. Reyner says two cups can keep you awake for half an hour. She suggests energy drinks and gum for alertness. 
Scientists know that humans sleep in a daily cycle, like other animals. When we sleep, we go through four stages, from light sleep to deep sleep. We usually dream during light sleep. Our brain keeps our body still to prevent injuries while we dream. 
Scientists are sure that women sleep about half an hour longer than men, and older people need less sleep, but they do not know why. Some researchers say sleep helps us travel through time safely. 
In the past, people had different sleep patterns. A history professor studied British life from 1500 to 1850. People went to bed early, woke up after midnight, stayed awake for a while, and then went back to sleep. This time was good for thinking and remembering dreams. Poor people enjoyed this quiet time away from their busy lives. 
By the 17th century, with more artificial light, rich people changed their sleep habits to sleep more efficiently. Later, during the industrial revolution, most people worked longer hours in lighted buildings. 
In some non-western cultures, people still do not have strict bedtimes. They sleep for a few hours, then wake up again. For some tribes, noises and the need to watch for danger make it hard to sleep all night. It seems that people everywhere need more sleep.

We are talking about big cowboy boots. I stood in my very expensive cowboy boots in the Arizona desert. I wore a full cowboy outfit, but I was not a cowboy. I looked at the mountains and realized I did not belong there. I flew in from Denver early in the morning. I thought I looked like a cowboy, but that changed when I saw a real cowboy at the airport. He was wearing a dirty shirt and carrying a bag. He looked at my new boots and then left without saying anything.
I used to be a racing driver, and I loved it. I was very good at it, but now I don’t race anymore. I wondered what I should do next. A racing driver should have other jobs ready for when they stop racing. I thought I had some ideas, but they didn’t work out. I tried to be a commentator for races, but there were many other drivers who wanted the job. I also tried to sell classic cars, but that didn’t work either because nobody was buying them.
Being an "ex" racing driver is hard. Nobody wants to hear about how I almost became a champion. Even if I had won, people would only listen for a short time. Last year’s champion is not important anymore. I don’t want sympathy, but I do miss racing. I miss the excitement of driving fast cars and the attention from fans. 
Now, I have a lot of free time. I looked up at the blue sky and saw some small birds. They seemed to be telling me to leave their nest alone. I never thought the desert had songbirds. I realized that I, a fake cowboy in fancy boots, still had a lot to learn.

**Vancouver**
In the last ten years, many people from all over the world have moved to Vancouver, in western Canada. In the evenings, residents walk around the city, and if you join them, you will hear many different languages. People come to Vancouver for its nice weather, beautiful views of the ocean and mountains, clean and safe places, and good schools and jobs. Some people complain about how fast new buildings are being built, but many agree that new people and tourism have helped the city grow. 
Vancouver used to be called 'Terminal City' because it was a place where many journeys began. Now, it is still a gateway to many other places.
**Writing Letters**
Journalists, like me, are not very good at writing letters. Some say this is because we do not like to write for free. But I think it is because we always want our writing to be perfect. A true artist, who writes without thinking too much about it, does not have this problem. The best artists know how to use their words well. For example, when Shakespeare wrote his famous lines, he did not think about how to make them great; he just wrote.
**New Supermarket Opening**
Opening a new supermarket used to be a big event in Britain. A famous person, like a soap star or a member of the royal family, would come to cut the ribbon. Now, new supermarkets open every day, and they do not need a celebrity. Last week, people waiting to enter the new Superbuy store did not care who opened it, as long as they were first in line. 
A customer said that the first five men to enter would get a bottle of aftershave, and the first five women would get flowers. This news spread quickly, making those at the front feel proud, while those who arrived late felt jealous.

**Citizen Kane**
The film *Citizen Kane* came out in 1941. Many people talked about it a lot before it was released. The release was delayed because the distributor was afraid of what William Randolph Hearst, the person the film is about, might do to them. Even though the reviews were very good, the film did not make a lot of money at first. It was television that helped people remember it later. This film has inspired many people to become filmmakers. This is surprising because it was Orson Welles's first film. Welles said that the film was successful because he did not know what he could or could not do. He just made the film the way he wanted. He also had a great team, including cameraman Gregg Toland, screenwriter Herman J. Mankiewicz, and special-effects expert Linwood Dunn. When Welles and Mankiewicz decided to show a newspaper owner who was like Hearst but not exactly him, Welles knew he had a great chance to be both the director and the actor. He took this chance with a lot of energy.
**Dermot and Carmel**
That morning, Dermot thought Carmel was acting a bit strange. He had told her twice that he might be late and that he might stop at the golf club on his way home. He wanted to talk to someone, and that was a good place to do it. Carmel nodded her head but seemed like she did not really hear him. Dermot asked her, "Will you be okay? What will you do today?" She smiled and said, "It's funny you ask. I was just thinking that I have nothing to do today, so I will walk downtown and look at the shops. I feel like it is almost wrong to waste the day." Dermot smiled back and said, "You should enjoy yourself. If I am late, I won’t need anything to eat, so don’t worry." She replied, "That’s fine."
**Title Race**
A recent study showed that job titles can cause problems at work. A survey by a big recruitment company found that 90% of employers and 70% of employees think job titles create divisions among workers. The survey also found that 70% of office workers would give up a pay rise for a better job title. This shows that people care a lot about how they are called at work. In the early 21st century, no one wants to be called "subordinate." The job titles people want focus on skills, like "specialist" or "coordinator," but they are really just fancy words.

**The Vienna Assignment**
I was in Vienna to take photographs. This was usually why I traveled. Taking pictures was not just my job; it was my passion. I loved how light fell on different surfaces. A single photo could show the beauty of a place, a city, or a person. I always hoped to take the perfect picture. As long as I had film in my camera, I could keep trying. I had a simple rule: finish one roll of film, load another, and keep looking for great shots.
Once, I took a photo of smoke from a burning oil well. It became very popular, and many newspapers wanted to use it. It was a lucky moment. They say you create your own luck, both good and bad. After that, I decided to work freelance. I thought it was a smart choice, but life had other plans. The mid-nineties were not as successful as I had hoped. That is why I was in Vienna instead of a more exciting place. But I was still taking photographs, and I was getting paid. That felt good to me.
My assignment in Vienna happened by chance. I had taken photos for a book called "Four Cities in Four Seasons," which included London, Paris, Rome, and Vienna. I had a good time taking pictures in London during all the seasons. But I knew that many of my best photos would not be used because it was just a picture book. 
After Christmas, I sent my winter photos from London. I learned that the Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, had left his job in Vienna. Instead of hiring someone new, they asked me to take his place. The publishers liked my work, and I was available. I was happy to go because things were not good at home. A week in snowy Vienna sounded great.
They put me in a hotel called the Europa, in the center of the old city. I had visited Vienna before with my wife, but it was a busy trip, and I didn’t take many photos. This time, I was alone in January, and I knew it would be different. When I arrived, I saw the beautiful light over the snowy roofs of the city. I was excited to take great pictures.
On my first day, I didn’t take any photos. I rode the trams around the Ringstrasse, getting on and off to enjoy the city. The weather was cold, like the old buildings around me. I didn’t want to see what Rudi had done in the other seasons. This was going to be my Vienna, and I wanted to discover it myself.
A photograph captures a moment, but you have to wait for the right moment. So, I took my time and looked carefully. The next morning, I woke up early. The snow from the night before made Stephansplatz look beautiful and quiet. I wanted to take a picture of the big cathedral, but it was hard to fit it all in one shot. The tall spire reached into the sky, but the building was very large at the bottom. I knew I would have to find a different way to capture it.
In that weather, the scene could still be magical. Photography has always felt magical to me. Even when I learned how it worked, I still felt its mystery. That morning at Stephansplatz, something surprising happened, but I was ready for it.

**Kinetic Art**
Great news! The Hayward Gallery in London has changed into a wonderful place. This change is not because of a big, expensive show, but because of a special exhibition about kinetic art. Kinetic art is art that moves or shows movement. This exhibition looks at the history of kinetic art over the last 60 years. It shows that making art that moves or talks about movement has been an important part of art in the twentieth century. 
The exhibition has many paintings, drawings, documents, and films about kinetic art. The curator, Guy Brett, has studied this topic for a long time. He has chosen to show the art without too much text. This way, visitors can enjoy the art and make their own discoveries.
**David Hockney**
David Hockney is an artist whose work many people like. Some people enjoy his art because it is easy to understand. His paintings often show fun and relaxing moments, which help people escape from their daily lives. Others might like Hockney because of his fun personality and clever words in interviews. 
Some critics think Hockney is not a great artist. They say he is too popular. But others believe that just because he is popular does not mean his art is not good. Hockney knows his own strengths and weaknesses. He does not say he is a great artist and believes that only time will tell how important his work is.
**Window-shopping - an Art Exhibition**
In recent years, I have seen many art exhibitions, some great and some not so good. I often feel frustrated when exhibitions seem to push a certain idea or message. Sometimes this works, and we learn about new trends in art. But often, it feels forced or not genuine. 
As a curator, I wanted to create a different kind of show. I worked with seven artists in an empty warehouse. The exhibition was called "Window-shopping." It was a collection of individual artworks that were connected only by being art. 
For example, Sam Cole made knitted cats that chased each other on a toy train track. In another piece, Matthew Crawley used a video camera and broke it while filming. These artworks did not fit into a specific theme, but they worked well together. They did not get in each other’s way and, I hope, they helped each other shine.
**Art History**
Many people who love paintings are sometimes afraid to think too much about them. They worry that thinking will ruin their enjoyment. Some art historians focus more on theory than on the beauty of art. This can take away from the pleasure of looking at art and the joy of creating it. 
Understanding art does not mean we cannot enjoy it. In fact, knowing more about what we see can make it even more enjoyable. Our feelings about art are also influenced by the society we live in. What we like is not just about our personal taste but also about the values of our culture. 
While it is important to enjoy art, it is also valuable to think about it. The idea that thinking about art takes away from enjoyment is an old belief. Today, we can appreciate both the feelings art gives us and the thoughts it inspires.

**Metals**  
A long time ago, people in the Stone Age became interested in metals. While sitting by a river and waiting for fish, one of our early ancestors might have found a shiny yellow stone. This stone was not like other stones; it was beautiful. This is how gold may have come into the lives of these early people. Gold is soft and easy to shape, so it quickly became very popular. Copper might have also been found by chance. When people saw how useful copper tools were, they started to look for copper and ways to get it from the ground. This is how metalworking began for our ancestors.
**St Ives**  
It was quiet as we carried our bags down the narrow, cobbled street to the town center. The strong wind made it hard to walk, and we tried to avoid the cold waves that crashed over the walkway. The streets were empty, and all the windows in the houses by the water were closed tight. We had seen the weather get worse as we arrived in St Ives on a small train. The dark clouds made visiting Cornwall in the off-season without a car seem like a bad idea. I had convinced my friend to come with me by promising beautiful walks along the coast and cozy evenings by the fire.
**Computer Modelling**  
Studying the past is difficult because it is already gone. The people who lived in times of peace and times of trouble are no longer here. We cannot know exactly why they moved or settled in certain places. Archaeology gives us some clues, but we cannot test our ideas with experiments on people from the past. We cannot go back in time and see what happened. However, we can use computer modelling to recreate old landscapes and environments. We can create virtual communities that act a little like real people. We can set rules and make social groups. Then, we can change things, like making it rain less or increasing the population, and see how these digital people react.

**Vervet Monkeys**
Cheney and Seyfarth studied vervet monkeys. One day, the main male monkey saw a strange male monkey nearby. The strange monkey wanted to join their group. If he did, the main male might lose his place as the leader. To keep the stranger away, the main male made an alarm call that sounds like a warning for a leopard. When the strange monkey heard this, he ran back to the trees. The main male did this every time the stranger came close. 
But then, the main male made a mistake. He called out the alarm while walking across the open ground himself. 
**What Cats Catch**
In a village in England called Felmersham, people counted what their cats caught. Over one year, seventy cats caught more than 1,000 animals. A professor in America thought that all the cats in Britain might kill 100 million birds and small animals each year! But this number is not realistic. Most cats live in towns and catch fewer animals than the cats in the village. 
The important question is whether the bird population can survive. The answer seems to be yes. In winter, many people feed birds, and there are many places for birds to nest. So, the cat population is not destroying the birds in Britain.
**Buffalo's Day**
Buffaloes are very important to the marshmen. Every morning, the buffaloes leave their sleeping places slowly. They make sad sounds as they walk to the water. They stand at the edge for a long time, tired, until the leader goes into the water. 
Once in the water, they relax and forget their purpose. They stay there for a while, making low sounds. When they finally swim away, they look tired, as if they are drowning. They spend the day in the reeds, eating the green plants they can reach.
**Picasso, Pablo**
In 1940, Picasso painted fish while he was in a fishing town called Royan. The painting shows a fish market with a crab and some soles. The fish look alive, even though they are on the market. 
The painting is hard to understand because Picasso used a flat style with overlapping shapes. The colors are calm, making it feel like an underwater scene. But there is also a feeling of danger, as the fish seem to be fighting the crab. The sharp shapes in the painting add to this feeling of tension.

**Photography**
For the last 150 years, photography has been used to capture many parts of human life. It helps us see moments in time and understand both big and small things. Photography gives us images from faraway places, different parts of space, and shows us the problems of modern life. It is an important way to express what it means to be human.
However, people have been making pictures for much longer. The first pictures were made about 35,000 years ago in caves. We are not sure why these early paintings were made. They might have shown hunting events, been used for magic to help with hunting, served as religious symbols, or just made homes more colorful. Pictures have always been a part of human culture.
Throughout history, people have asked how accurate pictures are and what they mean in society. Many believe that "seeing is believing," which gives pictures special importance. When photography was invented in the mid-1800s, it seemed to promise a true record of what we see. The camera works like our eyes and can create fixed images that look very real.
Photography was seen as a big achievement. It could capture images that artists had worked hard to create. Some thought that everyone could easily understand photographs, making it a "universal language." For example, in 1933, photographer August Sander said that even a very isolated person could understand a photo of the sky.
But as global communication grew in the late 20th century, we need to think about how well photographs can cross cultural differences. Is photography limited by culture like language? Do we take for granted how photographs show reality? People often believe photographs are very convincing, making it hard to see the difference between what we see and what is in the photo.
Since photography was invented in 1839, it has changed a lot. At first, it was a way to keep records, but now it is more than that. Photographs have become historical documents that tell us about the people and society that made them. 
I want to show that the camera is not just a tool that records events. Photography can also inspire social and political change. For example, the changes during the Italian Renaissance in the 15th century were connected to new ways of showing images. Similarly, photography has played a big role in creating the media culture we have today, while also showing the tough realities of the world.

**How to Write Poetry**
Writing poetry is not easy. It can be fun, but it can also be hard. If you want to write poetry, the best way to learn is to read a lot and write a lot. Let your imagination go free. Some people need to feel safe in their lives to write poems, while others write when they are sad. Some people write poems on a schedule, and others wait for a special moment to inspire them. All of these ways are okay as long as you find your own style. 
It is important to listen to your inner voice and let it grow. With time, your voice will become strong enough to stand on its own.
**The Short Story**
In a short story, you should not have too many characters or long descriptions. Flashbacks should be short and only used when they help the story. A memory can help explain what is happening in the story, but it should not slow down the action. 
Dialogue, or conversation between characters, is very helpful. It can show different sides of a story quickly. Too many words can make a short story boring, but being too short is not good either. A short story should have conflict and action, just like a novel, but every word must count.
**Screenplays**
Writing a screenplay for a film is like playing chess. When you play chess, you may not know what will happen next, but you make moves anyway. As you play more, you start to see the whole game and understand the patterns. 
In screenplay writing, the more you practice, the better you understand how to create a good story.
**Looking at Writing**
People naturally learn to speak, but writing is different. Charles Darwin said that language is a human instinct, but writing is not. All children learn to speak without lessons, but writing systems were created only in a few advanced societies. 
Many children today still struggle to read and write. A group of children is not likely to invent a writing system on their own. Children are good at listening and speaking, but learning to write takes time and effort. We need to understand how writing works and how to help children learn it.

I have never started a book with so much doubt. I call it a novel, but I am not sure if that is the right word. I do not have a big story to tell, and I do not end with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave my reader wondering. This book is about my memories of a man I met only a few times, and I do not know much about his life in between our meetings. I could make up stories to fill in the gaps and make it more complete, but I do not want to do that. I just want to write what I know.
To protect the people in this story, I have given them made-up names, and I have tried to make sure no one can recognize them. The man I am writing about is not famous. He may never be famous. When he dies, he might not leave any mark on the world, like a stone thrown into a river. If my book is read, it will be read for its own interest. But maybe the way he lives and his special character will influence others, and after he is gone, people will realize he was a remarkable person. Then it will be clear who I am writing about, and those who want to know about his early life may find something useful in my book.
I think my book will help those who write about my friend. I do not say that the conversations I wrote down are exact. I did not take notes, but I remember well what matters to me. I have put these conversations in my own words, but I believe they show what was said. I mentioned before that I have not made anything up, but I have taken the same freedom that historians take. I have imagined what my characters might have said to make the story more lively. I want people to read my book, and I think it is okay to do this to make it interesting. Smart readers will see where I have done this, and they can choose to ignore it.
Another reason I feel nervous about this work is that the people I write about are from a different culture. It is hard to really know people, and I think you can only truly know those from your own country. People are shaped by where they were born, the homes they grew up in, the games they played, the food they ate, the schools they went to, and the books they read. You cannot understand these things just by hearing about them; you must live them. Because you cannot know people from another country except by watching them, it is hard to make them believable in a book. I have only written about my own people before, and if I have written about others in short stories, it is easier because you can give broad ideas and let the reader fill in the details. In this book, I do not pretend that my characters see themselves the same way; they are seen through my eyes.

**POETRY RECITALS**
At different times in history, people may find the world of literature confusing. However, later on, it is easier to see which writers and styles are important. Right now, there are many different types of poetry and ways to write and share it. There are two main groups of poets: 
1. **Literary Poets**: These poets write poems to be read on the page. They want their work to be printed in books and magazines.
