2. **Popular Poets**: These poets like to perform their poems in front of an audience. They often read their work at events and festivals.
Over the last twenty years, public poetry readings have become more common. Small groups in towns hold readings in local halls or homes. Schools invite poets to read to students, and arts festivals often include poetry readings by famous poets.
For popular poets, performing is very important. Their poems are usually simple and easy to understand, so people can enjoy them right away. However, for literary poets, it can be harder. Their poems are often more complex and may not be appreciated by people who are hearing them for the first time. 
Sometimes, literary poets might choose to read their easiest poems instead of their best work. This can be a problem because it does not show their true talent. 
Listening to poetry readings is not the same as reading poems on the page, but it can be fun and helpful. Hearing poets read their work can help the audience understand the poems better. It is good for listeners to have the text in front of them or to know the poems before the reading.
One good reason for popular poetry readings, sometimes mixed with music, is that they help people enjoy poetry. This way, more people can see poetry as something fun and not just for a few special people.

**Oral History**  
Historians often use oral history, which means they listen to people's stories about the past. However, this can be difficult. When someone talks about their past, their memories can be influenced by the person asking questions. The historian chooses who to talk to and what to ask about. Even if the historian just listens, their presence can change how the person remembers things. The way the historian thinks about the past can also affect the stories they hear. This means historians help create new evidence. But even the person telling the story is not always completely connected to the past. Their memories can be mixed with things they learned from other places, like TV or books. Sometimes, they remember the past with feelings of sadness or happiness that come from later experiences. These feelings can make their stories seem more real, but they might not reflect what really happened.
**Animal Science**  
There are two main ways to study animal science: the physiological approach and the whole animal approach. Physiologists study how the body works, like how nerves and muscles help animals behave. The whole animal approach looks at how animals act in their natural environment. Within this approach, there are psychologists and ethologists. Psychologists usually study a few types of animals, like rats and pigeons, in labs. Ethologists study animals in the wild and how they behave naturally. Both groups are starting to work together more. Physiologists believe their methods are very important, but understanding behavior also needs to be studied at a different level. For example, if we only looked at how nerve cells work, we would miss the bigger picture of how animals behave, like how birds build nests. 
**The Social Sciences**  
Students studying social sciences for the first time have two tasks. They need to learn about the subject and also understand how to study it. This means they must know both the facts in textbooks and the methods used to gather this knowledge. These two parts are connected. We all have experiences in social life, so it may seem like social sciences are just common sense. However, each social science looks at different parts of society and uses special methods and ideas. These ideas help social scientists understand more than just everyday thinking and make each discipline unique.
**Classical Architecture**  
In Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building structures. The Roman architect Vitruvius said that architecture includes order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, and distribution. He also used Greek words for some of these ideas. He did not mention utility or function at first, but he later talked about how to design buildings for different purposes. At the start, the focus was on beauty and art in architecture. The history of classical architecture is complicated. Before the grand buildings, there were simple huts in Greece and Italy. These simple structures did not meet Vitruvius' artistic ideas, but they were important for later designs. Even though classical temples look complex, they are based on the simple idea of a single-room hut.

The two sisters kept Lily's driving a secret from Chen for a while. Lily would drive around the gardens and the train tracks, jumping over a small bridge with all four wheels in the air. This was the only mistake she made. After driving, they would smell the gasworks. Chen was actually happy about what his wife was doing. "So you can really drive, Lily? Well done!" he said. Mui thought men were strange. Chen should have been upset, but he was excited to make plans with Lily for a trip. They decided to go on a Monday at the start of next month. This day was usually quiet, so they would leave early in the morning and come back by noon. This way, they would not lose any customers. Lily would practice driving around the gardens before the trip. Mui, even though she was worried, bought a road map. She got a ten percent discount, which made Chen happy, but Lily felt a bit insulted because Mui did not trust her to find the way.
After leaving home, they quickly saw the English Channel. Lily drove very well. Even Mui, who was in the back seat ready to give directions, had to agree. On the road, Lily passed a few slow cars with great skill. Chen even clapped for her. After driving through the gasworks and past the lagoon with small boats, they drove smoothly along the empty seaside road. Lily parked in a small street near the sea that had many empty spaces. She was not sure about the parking signs, so she decided to pay for parking to avoid problems. 
Lily often looked at her sister's worried face in the mirror. She thought it was better not to add to Mui's worries. Lily locked all the van doors carefully. "Don't worry," Chen joked. "No one will want that old van." The sisters were not happy with this. Lily told Chen he was ungrateful, and Mui said he was too proud. Chen took Man Kee, their son, to look at the grey sea. He held Man Kee close. Man Kee was warm and soft, and he reached out to touch his father's sleeve. In that moment, Chen decided to raise his son in a certain way. He wanted Man Kee to learn about numbers and to own many restaurants when he grew up.
As Chen looked at the sea, he felt a bit sad but also happy as he thought about Man Kee's future. He saw smoke on the horizon and then a ship appeared in the sunlight on the water. Chen put a coin in a telescope and tried to find the ship. At first, he could not see it, but then he found it. It was a small, old ship. Chen lifted Man Kee to the telescope. "Do you see the ship, Son?" he asked gently. "It is a special ship for us. It is small and old, but it will take us back home when we are done here. It will take you to your homeland, which you have never seen." Chen kissed Man Kee's head. 
Lily and Mui were behind them. Lily put her arm around Chen's shoulders. "The little old ship," Chen said. "Let your mother see, Son." Man Kee did not want to let go of the telescope. When he finally did, the telescope stopped working, and all Lily could see was a blurry white light. By the time Chen found another coin, the ship was gone, and Lily could only see seagulls flying over the water.

**THE WELL**
I read somewhere that if you dig a deep enough hole, you can see the stars on a clear night. I asked you to help me with my idea. You watched with wide eyes as I pulled up the well bucket, steadied it on the wall, and then climbed in. I told you to let me down. I didn’t think about how heavy the bucket was or that you might not be strong enough to hold it. You held the handle while I pushed the bucket off the wall. As soon as it was free, I fell into the well. You screamed and tried to stop it, but then you let go. I hit my head and saw strange lights. At first, I was confused, then scared, and finally angry at you for letting me fall. I was also worried about what my mother would say.
You called down to me, asking if I was okay. I wanted to shout back, but then I heard panic in your voice, and I stopped. I lay still and peeked at you through my eyelashes. You ran away to get help. I waited a moment, then climbed back up and pulled myself over the edge. I landed on the courtyard stones. I heard loud voices from the castle. I ran away to hide in the shadows. My mother and father came with you and old Arthur. My mother was screaming, and my father told Arthur to pull on the winch handle. You looked pale and shocked.
I felt a rush of excitement, but then I saw the drops of water I had left from the well. I looked in horror at the dark spots on the dry stones. There was a little pool of water at my feet. I looked back at my father, who was shining a flashlight into the well. The drops sparkled in the sunlight. I couldn’t believe no one had seen them. My mother was screaming loudly now, and it scared me. What should I do? I had played a trick on you, but now it was serious. I felt like I was in big trouble.
I thought of a plan. I took a deep breath and came out of my hiding place. I called out softly, then louder when no one heard me. I stumbled a bit and then fell on the stones. I sat up, feeling comforted in my mother’s arms. I said I had found a secret tunnel from the bottom of the well to the moat and that I crawled through it to get out. I thought I was almost safe until my father came and asked me to repeat my story. I hesitated. He looked at me closely. I said the tunnel had fallen in after me and that the well was dangerous. I had barely escaped with my life.
When I looked into my father’s eyes, it felt like he was seeing me for the first time. I felt scared. He said, “Don’t be ridiculous, boy,” and walked away. Arthur looked at me with a sad face. He seemed to understand my lie and worried about me. His look made me feel even worse than my father’s words. I realized that my actions had consequences, and I felt very ashamed.

**REMOVAL DAY**
Susan is a widow with grown children. She is leaving her family home. A van with the words "Removers of Distinction" is taking her things away. Fred, the removal man, is carefully packing her belongings. He is big and strong, but he is gentle with the fragile items. Susan's house is beautiful. It has four floors and looks over a small harbor. Many memories are in this house, especially of her children growing up.
When they bought the house, her son Robert, who was five years old, asked, "Mum, how do you get a house home?" Now, Robert is an adult and is helping her move. He is making sure she does not forget about the piano. Francesca, her daughter, is also helping. She is very bossy and wants to take care of the piano because it is special.
Fred notices that Susan is not crying. He tells her that some people cry when they move. They are happy while packing, but when they see the empty rooms, they get sad. Susan understands this feeling. She thinks she should have told the movers about the piano before they started.
The piano is in the best room of the house. They will move it last. Sitting on the stairs, Susan remembers the day they brought the piano into the house. It was a big problem because it got stuck on the stairs. The movers worked hard for two hours to get it inside. Robert watched with excitement, and Francesca cried, "We can't live without a piano!" They had to find a way to get it in, and her late husband, Peter, helped solve the problem. They took out a window and used a crane to lift the piano inside. The children were so happy to see it.
Now, Susan thinks about how her children are busy and do not come home often. She is also having trouble moving around the house. She worries about the piano and the stairs. Fred asks if she is okay. She feels nervous as she watches the movers. Robert and Francesca are there too, watching quietly.
Suddenly, the piano comes down the stairs. Fred is careful with it. They bring it outside and put it down by the van. Robert laughs, and soon everyone is laughing together. They feel relieved that the move is almost over. As they walk down the path for the last time, Susan realizes that she is not crying; she is laughing with her children.

**Online Literary Criticism for Everyone**
**Do-it-yourself literary criticism: Is it just fun?**
When the Internet started, one important idea was that everyone could share their thoughts. In theory, anyone could write and publish anything online. At first, it was not easy for everyone because some technical skills were needed. But there was one area that became open to many people: book reviews.
Amazon.com was the first popular online bookstore. Here, anyone could write a review of a book. Amazon allowed anyone to say what they thought about a book and give it up to five stars. This was a great idea because it let readers see what others thought about a book, not just what the publisher said or what professional critics wrote.
Amazon had many customers and many reviews because it was the biggest online bookstore. But this also led to some problems. Many reviews were written every day, and Amazon could not check them all. They had a team that looked for bad reviews, like those with only one word or personal attacks on authors. But many reviewers were anonymous, so it was hard to catch all the bad ones.
For example, some authors wrote good reviews for their own books. One author, Lev Grossman, was upset by the bad reviews of his first book. He wrote some good reviews under a fake name to make his book look better. This worked until he wrote an article about it, and then Amazon removed his fake reviews.
Authors could also comment on their own books by clicking a link. Most authors wrote nice messages asking readers to buy and enjoy their books. Some even gave their email addresses for readers to contact them. However, Amazon did not always check if the comments were really from the authors, except for famous authors.
Sometimes, readers wrote angry reviews. For example, when James McElroy's book about a cheerleading team came out, some people mentioned in the book were upset and wrote many bad reviews. These reviews disappeared after a few days. But Amazon thought it was good that so many people were writing reviews.
Amazon wanted reviews to be about the books, not just chatting. They paid special attention to popular books to make sure the reviews followed the rules. This meant that silly reviews were more likely to be found on pages for less popular books.
One classic children's book, "The Story about Ping," inspired some funny reviews because "ping" is also a computer term. One long review compared the book's story to how the Internet works. But most reviews were serious, and they helped other readers know if a book was worth buying.
The writer George Orwell once said that writing too many reviews was hard because he had to pretend to feel something about books he did not care about. This shows that letting everyone write reviews is a good thing.

**Art in Modern Times**
In the last two hundred years, people often think that artists must go against the art of their time. We like to say that art is special, new, and sometimes shocking. We feel proud to admire artists whose work was not appreciated in the past. But when we look at art today, we often say that some artists go too far and that their work is not really art. The media often say this for us, and we agree because we expect art to be confusing. We forget that today’s art still has old ideas and methods.
In the past, people asked artists to create art for specific reasons, and art was part of everyday life. Now, we let artists work alone and sometimes get upset if they try to connect with us.
**A Situation to Think About**
I want to describe a situation and ask an important question. An artist picks a text from an art book. The text talks about different kinds of pictures and says there are many types. Then, the artist asks someone to prepare a canvas and write the text on it in simple black letters. My question is: is this finished piece a painting?
**Underground Encounters**
At the Mercury Gallery in London, there is a rule that artists should stick to one style if it is successful. Collectors want artists to keep making the same type of art. If an artist tries something new, people often feel disappointed. Some artists, like Picasso and Hockney, have successfully changed their style. Eric Rimmington is another artist who is trying something different. He is moving from still life paintings to paintings about the London Underground. He has created an exhibition called Underground Encounters, which shows 40 paintings and drawings of this unique underground world.
**A Story from an Island**
I have come to this island with a few books. I say "escape" because the villagers joke that only a sick person would choose such a lonely place. I am here to heal myself. Besides an old woman who comes to clean, I am alone. I feel neither happy nor sad; I am like a feather floating in memories. I talked about how art seems useless, but it also brings comfort. Through art, we can change reality and find meaning. For artists, art helps us deal with the pain of everyday life. It allows us to fulfill our true potential through imagination. Otherwise, why should we hurt each other?

**Family Business**
"Look here, it's no good!" said my Dad. We were in the car going back to London. My father, with my brother Maurice, had just picked me up from my fancy girls' school. He had also just been to Parent's Day, where I won a prize for Latin and another prize for my end-of-school exams. He talked a lot with my headteacher, and now we were going home for the holidays.
"What isn't?" I asked, but I already knew what he was thinking because he was quiet. My dad usually talks a lot. "You can't fool me. You'll do what you want now," he said. "With all those certificates, I heard you will get a scholarship to Oxford."
"So?" I replied, trying to act brave. "Mightn't that be useful?"
"I also heard," he continued, and I knew he was going to confront me, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister!" My father knew a lot about lawyers and the law. "I just said that," I said. "I couldn't think of anything else to say!"
"And apparently," he went on, "you have the right personality. You can understand a lot of information quickly, you are good at talking, and you like performing."
"I don't know about that," I said. "I only know what I see on TV."
"Anyway," he said, trying to stay calm, "I feel like you won't want to join the family business. You will go to Oxford University, and after that, I can't see you wanting to do this."
The problem was that, like many kids in family businesses, I felt trapped by what my family expected. I saw many jobs I could do, and I wanted to explore them. But I also didn't want to upset my dad. I wasn't as scared of him as Maurice was - I was his favorite - but I still found him intimidating.
"It's too soon to know," I said weakly.
"I tell you, you won't want to join us," my father said, who often turned out to be right about these things. "It's a pity because you have the skills - the brains, the courage, the vision."
"There's still Maurice," I said, feeling down. My father laughed. We both knew Maurice didn't like the business.
"Anyway," I continued, "you could always use me as a consultant." My mother had died when I was young, and my father raised me and Maurice. Maurice was two years younger than me, and I took care of him because he didn't have a mother. I loved Maurice, and it was not hard to take care of him.
Because the business was successful, we lived well - in a big house in London, went to nice schools, wore good clothes, and went to parties and shows. My father knew many important people - politicians, actors, and businesspeople - and our house was always full of interesting conversations.
"I tell you what," my father said. "You can help us during the holidays until you leave Oxford, and then if you want to leave, you can. It will give you some money and help me."
"OK," I said, happy to avoid making big decisions right now, especially since my father would be upset if I disagreed with him. This was how he controlled us.
So, I helped out during my last term at school and during university breaks, but only a few times a year and with easier tasks. I became a smart student, had a small house, a nice car, designer clothes, and a special black dress for my final exams.
In my last term, my father came to see me and took me to a village for a meal and a chat. I had only a few weeks left. My teacher said I would get a First Class degree in Law, and I knew if I focused, I could do it.
Then my father told me he needed me to do one last important job for the family business. He said it was the most important work they had ever done, and it would be worth my time.
"But Dad," I said, "I have my final exams soon, and I need to focus on that. It's really important, and I don't want to think about anything else right now."
I could see that my father didn't understand how much pressure I was under. He would think that if I said no, I was betraying him. As he explained the job, I saw how focused and determined he was. He was very good at his work, and I admired that in him. It made my own plans seem less important.
"All right," I said. "I'll do it."

Simon Costello realized that buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake within a year of moving in with Lois. They could only afford the house by being very careful with their money, and maybe it was better not to buy it at all. At first, it seemed like a good idea. Simon had been doing well at work, and Lois returned to her job after having the twins. She even got a raise, making thirty-five thousand a year. Lois wanted to move because their flat was too small for a family. They needed more space, a garden, and a place for an au pair. They could have found these things in a cheaper area of London, but Lois wanted to live in a nicer place. 
Lois thought one of them should save money by using public transport. Since her job was far away, Simon had to take the tube. The crowded ride made him feel unhappy and jealous. He remembered his grandfather's house, where he felt safe and cared for as a child. His grandmother always made sure his grandfather had peace after a long day at work. 
Lois had made it clear that her job was just as important as Simon's. They both needed their salaries to pay for the house and their lifestyle. Now, they were worried about a woman named Venetia. She had come to their office upset and angry. Simon wished he had left his room earlier to avoid her. He remembered her accusations about a case he worked on years ago. She said a man named Brian Cartwright claimed Simon knew he had bribed the jury but did nothing about it. Simon denied it, but he felt guilty. 
He could see that Venetia did not believe him. He wished he had said something different to defend himself. He felt ashamed and scared, remembering the punishments he faced as a child. He looked into Venetia's eyes and saw her disbelief. He wondered why she was so angry and if she had the right to judge him. He was worried that if people heard about this, it could ruin his career.

I chose this place to live because I thought I could be alone. I wanted to be around people who did not care about broken houses or messy gardens. But I was wrong. People in the shops soon start to recognize you, even if you don’t know them. The beautiful roses from next door remind me that gardens can be loved. I usually stay inside to forget about summer, but tonight I am watching the birds fly between the trees and roofs. I have cut back some plants to make space for a chair, and my arms are a bit scratched.
My upstairs neighbor, Jaz, leans out of her window. She is a writer and I sometimes help her with her work because I am an English teacher. I have her latest story with me. "How is your writing going, Jaz?" I ask. She complains about how people always ask her about her work. "I have something to drink in the fridge. I’ll bring it down," she says. I don’t want her in the garden because it looks messy. Jaz knocks on my door and comes in. 
"You're on holiday now," she says, sitting in my chair. "I should have become a teacher. Writers don’t have holidays." She asks me about my plans for the break. I feel worried about having empty days with nothing to do. "I’m going to Stonebridge tomorrow. Can you feed my cats?" I ask. "Of course," Jaz replies, knowing she will be around.
"I’ll stay with my friend Ruby at the Rising Sun. We have been friends since we were kids," I say, even though it is not true. Jaz asks about her story, "The Cruelty of Red Vans," which I have not read much of. I tell her I like the title. I think red vans can be cruel because they bring gifts to other houses but not to hers. I decide to give her some advice. "Try writing about nice people for a change," I say. She gets upset and tells me to get a life. 
I tell her I keep a journal where I write something good about each day. She laughs at me. "Get a life, Ann," she says. I do have a life. I work, go out sometimes, and read on the tube. When we go back inside, I feel calm in my kitchen. But then I remember my old geography teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who once winked at us and said, "I've had my moments." We all laughed.

**Heritage**
Heritage means the connection people have with their past. We often feel close to our personal heritage because we know about our grandparents and their stories. Learning about our past helps us understand our future. Heritage is important because it gives us a sense of belonging and identity. Just like we inherit our genes, we also inherit our culture from previous generations. Some parts of our national heritage may not be perfect, but they are still a part of us. Heritage teaches us many things and is important for our well-being. It influences our customs and culture. In the past, we learned about our heritage through stories from our ancestors. However, in modern society, many of these stories have been lost. Now, we can learn about our past through places and buildings. It is very important to protect these places to remember our ancestors.
**The Fens**
I once started writing a novel called *Waterland*. I chose to write about a place in England called the Fens. At first, I thought the Fens were flat and empty, but I learned they are actually very interesting and unique. Many people in England find the Fens strange, even though they are in the middle of the country. The Fens are both empty and full of life, and they are both farmed and wild. I have not visited some places in the Fens, but as a writer, I like to imagine what they are like. The Fens are not just a place; they are also a way of thinking.
**Museums**
Museums should make their collections easy for everyone to see and understand. In the past, museums just put items in display cases with long descriptions. Now, museums should create exciting displays that attract visitors and make them feel something. Museums should also reach out to the community. For example, they can provide boxes of objects for teachers or materials for elderly people with memory loss. Museums show real items from history, not copies. This is their strength and what makes them different from other places like theme parks or books. Museums that create engaging displays and programs will find that they can work with technology to help people appreciate real history.
**Architecture and Environment**
The desire to keep things from the past is not new, but changes in our towns happen very quickly now. This can make some people want to preserve everything, while others think more about how towns are changing. People who have lived through big events, like wars, often want to keep things stable. If we need to preserve our history, planners should consider this. Change is not bad if we learn to manage it. Changes in our towns reflect changes in society, like our population and needs.

**Einstein**
If you ask people on the street to name a scientist, many will say Albert Einstein. His picture is used to sell many things, like computers and books. Most people do not know much about what Einstein did, except that he created some complicated ideas called 'relativity'. These ideas are famous for being hard to understand and for making strange predictions that do not match our everyday experiences. 
Einstein was part of a big change in science that started in the 20th century. Scientists wanted to understand the universe better by studying how matter and natural forces work together. Einstein made important contributions by looking closely at basic ideas: time, space, matter, and energy. Before him, scientists like Isaac Newton thought that stars and planets moved in a fixed space and time. Einstein changed this idea, saying that time and space are not fixed but can change.
**Young Readers**
When we were children, Lydia and I did not trust books that won awards because we thought they would be boring. Our mother did not like this attitude, but our father would give us small coins for every chapter we read to encourage us. He also gave us some special books for Christmas and birthdays, marked with "This Book is NOT Literature." We thought many of these were for boys, but he did help us read some good stories and even a famous book of poems.
**Language**
Jacob Grimm wrote in 1851 that the beginning of human language is a secret and wonderful thing. This secret has led to many strange ideas. For example, Charles Caller said in 1928 that early humans made sounds like "meuh" when they were scared. This sound is sad. Early humans who faced dangerous animals made desperate noises, and some words today still remind us of this, like "malaria," which means "fever," and the Latin word "mors," which means "death." 
Many people avoided talking about how language started because they thought it was silly. But now, studying the origin and development of language is very important. Language likely began in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. At first, people used speech to connect with each other and to gain power. Sharing information was probably not the main reason for language, which is different from what philosopher John Locke thought. He believed language was mainly for sharing knowledge.

**Writing Reviews**
Frank Kermode talks about how to write reviews. Most reviews are written quickly and do not last long. They have deadlines and strict rules about how long they can be. When they are published, they are only in the newspaper for a short time, like a day or a week, and sometimes a month.
People often think that writing reviews is not very important. Many believe that writers only do it because they need money. Others think that writers cannot spend all their time on a serious book, so they write reviews instead. However, writing reviews is a skilled job. 
It is different to write a short review of 600 to 800 words for a newspaper than to write a longer review of 6,000 to 8,000 words for a journal. A review in a weekly magazine is usually about 1,500 words and has challenges from both short and long reviews. 
Reviewers must think about who will read their work. Some readers just want a quick summary, while others want a detailed review. Reviewers also need to know a lot about different topics and write in a way that is easy for smart people to understand.
Most reviewers also write other things besides reviews. For example, the American writer John Updike does not think much of criticism, but he still writes reviews while he writes his novels. He collects all his reviews, even the short ones, into books with humble titles.
Some people think that less famous writers should accept that their reviews will not last long. But if they can, they should be allowed to keep their work and feel proud of it, especially if they think some of their best writing is in reviews. I feel this way about my own work too. 
Most of my work is academic, and my serious books are for professors. In English-speaking countries, it is common for the same people to write reviews and study literature. The old days when professors were criticized for writing reviews are gone. Now, there are many reviews, and almost everyone can write one. 
I believe this is good for readers because they can trust that the reviewer knows what they are talking about. It is also good for professors because it helps them stay connected to the public. They need to remember to write in a way that everyone can understand, not just other professors. 
In conclusion, writing reviews is important, but it is usually a secondary job. You can only write good reviews if you are also doing something else well.

Ralph opened the door to his flat. When he walked in, he felt a quick sense of ownership. Even after three years, he sometimes felt this way when he came home alone at the end of the day. When he first bought the flat, he was always excited to come back, wondering what it had been doing while he was away. His flat felt like a welcome place for him, a space where he could be himself. 
He thought he should worry about things like break-ins or leaks, but his flat always seemed to be waiting for him, looking either clean or messy, depending on how he left it. Over time, he started to see it as part of himself, a place where his thoughts and feelings spilled out. He became frustrated that it didn’t change. 
There were always some letters by the door and the answering machine would sometimes blink when he got home. He was thankful that his windows were not broken and that nothing bad had happened to his things. He often looked forward to his quiet evenings at home after a long day at his office. 
On the bus ride home, he felt more like himself again. But once he was home, he didn’t want to be alone anymore, even though he thought he did. At his desk, he wanted to be alone with his things, but when he got home, he felt empty. He worried that his job was changing him and taking him away from who he really was. 
He would read or listen to music at night, but he started to wonder why he did these things. His thoughts became unclear, and he felt lost. He remembered a time when he felt stronger and thought he could change his life. But he had been so eager to find something that he just went along with what others were doing. 
After university, he tried to make a plan for his life, but he only wanted to get by. He applied for jobs that his friends talked about, following them as they moved forward. He went to one job interview and didn’t think much about the job itself. He was happy to have a nice chat with Neil, his future boss, and didn’t think about what working there would be like. Neil offered him the job right away, saying he was the only graduate who applied, which Ralph took as a compliment at the time.

**Goat Racing**
I was about to see goat racing on Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. There were many ice-cream vans, lots of people, food stalls, and loud music. Even though everyone was going to the racecourse, I pushed my way through the crowd to find a good spot. They had made a special area for the race. It was not like a big racecourse, but people were standing on both sides of the ground where the goats would run. They were trying to keep a few goats in order, which is not easy because goats can eat almost anything!
**Canoe Trip**
As the day ended, I started to worry about the night. The canoe was too wet to sleep in, and we could not find a place to stop. We had not seen any villages or huts since early morning. In the dim moonlight, we used our flashlight to see the cliffs, but the flashlight batteries were dying. We changed the batteries, but they did not work. We could not find a place to camp. A little later, Lesley saw a flickering light, and we felt hopeful. But the light was just the moon shining on the waves. Soon, we heard the loud sound of rushing water, but we could not see what was happening. We kept moving on.
**How to Be Presentation Perfect**
I am not good at making presentations, but as a managing director, I have to present to my colleagues and important shareholders. How can I get better at this and feel more confident? You are not alone. Making a presentation is different from running a company, but many leaders need to be good at it. If you want to convince your audience, you must believe in what you are saying. Show your passion and enthusiasm during the presentation. This means you need to prepare well. Test your ideas before the presentation. Ask your colleagues what tough questions the audience might ask. You should also start with something everyone can relate to and then lead to your main point.

Some activities cannot be done quickly. They need their own time. If you are late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you rush when making mayonnaise and add the oil too fast, it will not work. If you pull hard on a tangled fishing line, it will get tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some things happen very fast, while others take time—seconds, minutes, hours, days, or even years. 
Some things can be done faster, like solving puzzles or doing math. But other things cannot be rushed. If you try to hurry them, they can break, like the mayonnaise, or get tangled, like the fishing line. Saying "Think fast; we need results" can be silly or unhelpful, just like trying to sleep less to save time. We learn and think in many ways, and these ways work at different speeds for different tasks.
There are three main speeds of thinking. The first is very fast. Some situations need a quick reaction. For example, if my motorbike slips on a wet road, my body knows what to do right away. This fast reaction is called our "wits." 
The second speed is thinking. This is when we figure things out, weigh options, and solve problems. A mechanic fixing a car or a student working on homework uses this kind of thinking. We often call this "intellect." People who are good at this are called "bright" or "clever."
The third speed is slower and more relaxed. It is not always clear or direct. In this mode, we think slowly and dreamily. For example, when we sit by the sea and listen to the waves, we are in a different mental state than when we are planning a meal. This slow thinking is just as important as fast thinking. 
Taking time to think slowly is necessary, especially when life gets busy. Some problems are better solved with a slow mind. Recent studies show that slow thinking helps us understand complicated situations. Fast thinking works well for simple problems. But when things are unclear or complex, we need to take our time. 
For example, if we are unsure about how to manage a difficult team at work or if we should change jobs, it is better to sit and think than to rush for answers. This slow thinking is linked to creativity and wisdom. Poets and philosophers have always understood that slow thinking can be valuable. Scientists are now studying these slower ways of thinking and finding that they can help us solve many important problems if we give them time.

**Surviving in a Foreign Land**
I have been welcomed warmly. It is a friendly place with many supplies, but it is very isolated. There are about forty people here, including scientists, students, and weather experts. We all work together as a close community. My French is just enough to communicate, but I cannot have fun conversations. I miss the small details in the language, and my phrasebook does not help me at breakfast. This is not a big problem, but at first, I felt unsure of myself. I was a little scared of mealtimes. I would wait and worry about which table to sit at. I felt nervous when I spoke, and I felt like I was back in my first weeks of school. I still smile awkwardly or feel panicked when people talk to me. I think my occasional sadness is not about being alone or not talking, but because I have lost the confidence I used to have when I could talk easily.
**Elliot**
When I first met Elliot, I was just a young writer, and he did not pay attention to me. He remembered faces, though. When I saw him, he would shake my hand nicely but did not want to be friends. If I saw him at the opera with important people, he would not notice me. Then, I became successful as a playwright, and I noticed that Elliot started to like me more. One day, he invited me to lunch, and I thought he was testing me. After that, I had many new friends because of my success, and I began to see him more often.
**Alfred Hitchcock**
The film director Alfred Hitchcock said he did not care about the story or the acting in his films. He cared about the pictures and the sound. For Hitchcock, it was not the message or the acting that moved the audience. He believed that people react to the film itself, no matter where they come from. So, if a film is made well, people in Japan should scream at the same time as people in India. Hitchcock was very clear and logical about his work. He was a smart man and a great filmmaker who liked to hear the audience scream. He did not think about deep ideas or complicated meanings. He focused on the film itself and how it could affect the audience.

**Amateur Astronomy**
Many things have changed in astronomy in the last 50 years. About 30 years ago, there were not many charts and books about astronomy. Telescopes were not very good, and there were few practical guides. Now, there are many types of telescopes and equipment available. Computers and calculators have made it easier to create charts and analyze observations. This is a great time for amateur astronomy. 
However, some things have gotten worse. Now, you may have to travel 80 km to find a dark sky, unlike 50 years ago when it was easier to see stars in cities. During the day, the sky is often filled with trails from airplanes, which can last for hours and make it hard to see the sun or stars at night.
**Too Much Choice**
Today, there are too many choices in life. People have many options for products and services. This can be overwhelming. Technology makes things change quickly, and new products come out all the time. This can make people feel tired and disconnected from life. 
Having more choices can lead to more stress and less time. Because of this, many people are looking for "simplexity," which means finding simple things that make life meaningful. But it is not easy to simplify life when there are so many products and options available.
**McAndrews Hotel**
Every summer, my family stays for two weeks at McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. This is a tradition started by my grandmother, and it is very important to us. We do not want anything to change this tradition. 
The guests at McAndrews Hotel are often old-fashioned and a bit different. I do not like the rude behavior of some shop assistants today. I also do not enjoy when waiters act too friendly. I know many of the other guests because we have been coming here since we were children. When I see them in the hotel, we usually just say hello and do not talk much. This respect for privacy is hard to find in hotels today.

**Othello**  
A great show of Shakespeare's play Othello is now in London. I want to say sorry for a bad review I wrote when the show started last spring. I said that Ray Fearon was too young to play Othello, and I was wrong about his acting. I still believe that Othello and Desdemona should have an age difference, but I take back my words about Mr. Fearon's great performance. The whole cast is wonderful. Some memorable scenes are when Cassio plays games with other young officers, and when Iago starts to lose control. The scene where Emilia helps Desdemona get ready for bed is very emotional. The pace and tension in the play are amazing. Don’t miss this show!
**Lake Vostok**  
In Antarctica, there is very little life. On the edges, you can see penguins, seals, and birds. But in the middle, there is a huge lake called Lake Vostok, which is under almost 4 kilometers of ice. This lake has been cut off from air and sunlight for about 25 million years. Scientists are excited to explore this hidden lake and find out what strange life might be there. For two years, researchers from around the world have been trying to learn the secrets of Lake Vostok. If they succeed, we will see many discoveries in the next few years.
**Scientists**  
Last week, I heard something interesting on the radio. Some scientists are thinking about why they want to be scientists. They often say it is "because it's there." We know that they want to learn about everything, from tiny atoms to big black holes. But these scientists want to understand why we want to know these things. They wonder why science cannot explain this desire. I think it is more important to know if what scientists do is right, rather than argue about why we want to know. Science is a tool, and we should decide how and why to use it.

**Food**  
Food is very important in our lives. Many people who love cooking buy cookbooks like this one. Sometimes, we think cooking is only for special occasions or fancy dishes, but that is not true. You can make a tasty soup by just putting chopped carrots, a leek, celery, and some herbs in water. This is much better than buying soup in a packet or a can. Instead of buying a sweet chocolate dessert full of chemicals, you can make a delicious treat in just five minutes that everyone will enjoy. Cooking is also a way to show care and love. Sharing food is important for our happiness, which is why we celebrate special events like birthdays and anniversaries with food. No one would want to have fast food at a wedding or an important party!
**In the Elevator**  
This morning, Alistair tried to clean his office, but there were still papers everywhere. Tax forms were sticking out of drawers and boxes, waiting for a day when he could organize them. He also had a lot of papers because he owned an apartment building. As the elevator took him to his floor, he knew Mallory would be on time for their meeting. She always arrived exactly on time. He wondered how she would feel about the mess. She might think someone had made a mess in his office. Alistair could pretend to be surprised when he walked in after her. His cleaning lady, Mrs. Wilson, had come while he was trying to clean the floor. He smiled at her, hoping she would help, but she looked unhappy and went into her own area, leaving him to deal with the mess.
**Karen**  
Karen wanted to be different from her mother. She created her own story about strength and difference. One important moment in her life was when she was twelve years old. Her brother accidentally hit her in the eye with a golf club. At first, she thought she would go blind, but the doctor told her she was okay. The club had missed her eye, and she only needed a few stitches. When she opened her eyes in the doctor's office and saw her mother, she felt grateful and knew she was saved for a reason.
**Miss Fogerty**  
Miss Fogerty was happy and sad as she walked back to her work on the village green. She was excited to learn something new in her small community, but she was also sad about Dr. Bailey's health. He had been her doctor for many years and always cared for her when she was sick. She appreciated how he made her feel like he had time to listen to her problems. This made him very loved in the village. He always gave his time, knowledge, and humor to his patients, and in return, they were very loyal and cared for him deeply.

**Joanna's Lessons**
Joanna MacGregor is a busy concert pianist. She plays music for many people. But she also writes books for young children who want to learn the piano. Joanna plays the piano very well. She can play many styles of music, like classical, jazz, and blues. 
At one concert for kids, a small boy asked her, "Can you play Match of the Day?" This surprised her, but she thought it was funny. She played it, and the boy was happy. Joanna cares a lot about how children learn music. She has written a piano book for kids called *Joanna MacGregor's Piano World*. 
Even though she has a lot of work, she wants to help children learn music. She believes that the first lessons are very important. Many people think only about the best musicians, but Joanna thinks everyone should be able to enjoy music. 
When she was younger, Joanna taught many beginners how to play the piano. She also saw many children come to her home to learn music from her mother. She wants to make music fun for everyone, not just for those who are very talented. 
Some kids learn quickly, but others take more time and sometimes give up. Joanna worries that some parents push their children too hard to be like the stars they see on TV. She believes music should be fun, not just about winning or being the best.
Joanna's books are colorful and fun. They have stories and music to make learning easier. She wants children to enjoy playing the piano. She believes it is important for kids to practice, but she understands that it can be hard. 
Joanna thinks that practice is very important for learning music. She suggests that children should have clear goals when they practice. It is also good to mix easy songs with harder ones. Most importantly, she wants children to have fun while they learn.

**Writing by Hand and on Screen**
Dr. Johnson said that "what is written without effort is usually read without pleasure." This means that good writing is hard to do. When I look back at my school essays that I wrote by hand, I see that I made very few mistakes. Today, I would rewrite them many times. I think this is because writing by hand is slow and makes me think more. When I write by hand, I take my time and write carefully. 
Using a computer is different. It is easy to change things, so people often do not pay attention to their writing. Many writers spend just as much time fixing their work on a computer as they did writing it by hand. Also, emails are not as personal as handwritten letters. Many people now send love letters by email, which is good. At least they are writing in English and using some grammar. But words on a screen can feel boring. People often do not think about their words and can make their meaning unclear. Writing quickly on a computer can make the writing less special than handwriting.
**The CD**
I put down my cup and looked at the CD. The case was not very nice, but the shiny disc inside looked interesting. "Wonderful little things, aren't they?" Mr. Warriston said when he came back into the room. I agreed and carefully gave him the disc. "It’s amazing that they can fit seventy minutes of music on them," he said, turning on the music player. Lights turned on, and he pressed a button. A small drawer opened, and he put the disc inside. He pressed the button again, and the drawer closed. "Some people say they sound cold, but I think they..." 
"Do you have to turn them over, like records?" I asked. 
"What? No," Mr. Warriston said, looking surprised. "You only play one side." 
"Why?" I asked. He looked confused and then thought for a moment. "I don’t know. I guess you could make both sides play and double the music..." He looked at the machine. "You could have two lasers or just turn it over by hand... hmm." He smiled at me. "Yes, good point." He pointed to my wooden chair. "Anyway, let’s get you sitting in the best place for the sound, okay?" I smiled, happy to have asked a question he could not answer.
**Books vs. Electronic Text**
Malcolm Bradbury said that if matches were invented after cigarette lighters, we would think lighters were amazing. Many people say that electronic text is as important as the invention of printing. They think it is almost finished. But it takes a long time for people to change how they think. Some people believe that reading on a screen is better, but many do not enjoy reading long texts on a screen. Most people prefer to read books. 
Some people say that reading on a computer helps us think in new ways. But many books have always been read in different ways. For example, people do not always read religious texts or dictionaries from start to finish. The problem with computers is that they do not encourage people to read everything carefully.
**The Office**
Charles walked into the office and saw everything was neat. The carpet was clean, and the desk was dark wood, just like he remembered from the auction. Neat file holders were in their places. Twelve years of trade journals filled one wall. Kathleen was trying to close the filing cabinet and then looked at him. "You have to use computers, Charles. This is too much," she said. 
"Hello, Kathleen. This is amazing," he replied, admiring the room and its old furniture. He did not think about computers or any machines in the room. "Simply amazing," he said, avoiding the topic of computers. They had talked about this many times over the two years he had known her. She could not understand why he did not want to use technology, even though he was good with computers and had written an important paper about them. She had inspired that paper. She could use any software and make it do amazing things.

"You don’t take sugar, do you?" shouted his secretary. She was not really asking; she was stating a fact because she had been making coffee for Lancelot for many months. She forgot things because he was not usually supposed to be there. But now, he was there all the time. He learned that staying away only caused more problems. 
He thought about how he had changed from a respected advisor who met authors for lunch to someone who was always busy and had no place to park at work. "This came," she yelled, waving a folder before putting it in front of him. "From that guy in Los Angeles. You wanted to see it." The label said: "A World History of the Short, by Ian Cuthbert." Below that, it said "An Expanded Synopsis." Lancelot did not want to see the word "synopsis." He wanted to see "A First Draft." He had already seen a synopsis of this book and did not want to see another one.
Ian Cuthbert had received a lot of money for this book when Lancelot bought the company. Ian was one of Lancelot's old friends, but he was very difficult to work with. Lancelot quickly read the synopsis. He recognized almost every phrase. He closed the folder and pushed it aside. It was clear that Ian's manuscript would not be ready soon. The synopsis was not as brilliant as people said it would be, and it felt like Ian had lost his passion for the book.
Lancelot remembered a famous author who had published an incomplete book after his death. That author had been paid little by little for each chapter. But Ian had received a lot of money upfront, which was not how things should work. Lancelot remembered when Ian was a promising writer in Cambridge. His friends wanted to take over British theater, and they did. But Ian seemed lazy compared to them. He wore his coat like a cape and talked about famous writers as if he had met them.
For some reason, Ian's creative talent stayed hidden. While others succeeded, Ian became harder to work with. He was supposed to edit a magazine about the arts, but it never got published. His contract with a fashion magazine was renewed three times, but he still did not produce anything. At meetings, he was rude and critical of others' ideas. Ten years later, he was so unreliable that Lancelot thought "A World History of the Short" had been a mistake from the start.

**England's Breakfast Revolution**
A good breakfast is very important, according to health experts. But in the past, breakfast was not common in England. You do not see many mentions of breakfast in old stories from medieval times. Sometimes, travelers ate a meal at dawn before long journeys, and sick people had breakfast for health reasons. But most people did not eat breakfast unless they were kings or nobles.
In the sixteenth century, breakfast started to become normal for everyone. Some writers say this happened because there was more food available. However, they did not think about other big changes in society. For example, new jobs meant that people had to work set hours. Many people started work very early in the morning. So, eating breakfast became necessary and was not just for rich people anymore.

**Photography**  
When a photographer takes a picture, they choose what to show based on their skills, personal views, and experiences. They also think about social and cultural ideas. In this book, we will see how these things affect the style and meaning of a photograph. We will also look at how people see and react to these images. For example, when someone reads a newspaper, they usually understand the photos on the page. But instead of just believing the photo, we can ask if it really shows what happened at that time. Does it show the photographer's opinion? Is the exact moment in the photo important, or does it represent something bigger in the world?
**More than a Game**  
For me, sports are more than just a game. The best athletes believe in themselves completely. To be the best, you need to focus only on your goal. Sports can be tough, and no one will do the work for you. You either succeed or fail. Sports have taught me discipline and determination, but they also show the importance of teamwork. My sport lets me shine as an individual, but it is also a team game, and I must balance both. This is like life – you can do well alone, but you must remember others are around you. Sports have given me a lot, not just money. They have opened doors for me and shown me things in the world that many people will never see. But I also had to give up a lot to get these rewards.
**Tuning In**  
Some experiences stay in our memory very clearly. For me, one special moment happened one night in California. I was awake, listening to a mockingbird singing from a tree in my neighborhood. I don’t have trouble sleeping, but the beautiful singing kept me awake. As I listened to the bird's songs, I felt like I was in a special musical world. To understand the bird's patterns, I thought about jazz and Indian classical music. The bird made me feel like I was hearing an amazing live performance. I enjoyed the different musical sounds until I finally fell asleep.

People have always talked a lot about birds. They love them, fear them, and even worship them. But what does this say about us? 
In a greenhouse, a little brown bird called a wren is bumping against the glass. Is it trying to tell us something, or is it just stuck? Depending on how you see it, both could be true. 
Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In medieval times, people believed that the way wrens flew could tell them about their luck. Today, you can still see wrens in pictures and decorations in many British homes. Even if old beliefs about wrens are not as strong now, people still care about them. A place without wrens feels sad. 
This connection with birds comes from a time when people lived closely with nature. They learned to understand the importance of different animals. Over time, people's views about birds have changed. 
For example, the red kite bird was once seen as a helpful bird in London. It would take bread from children’s hands. But later, people thought of it as a pest and many were killed. Now, red kites are protected again and are seen as important birds in Britain. 
Our connection with birds goes back to when humans first appeared. Early humans watched birds to know about danger, weather, and food. Birds also connected them to their dreams. 
Birds are important to us because they represent freedom and beauty. Some people think our feelings about birds are not needed anymore, but they are still a part of us. Losing this connection would be hard. 
Today, birds are also important for understanding the environment. In Britain, 30 bird species are in danger. This is sad because it means we are losing not just birds, but also part of our culture. 
Certain birds, like the skylark and turtle dove, represent love and magic in stories and poems. When we lose these birds, we feel sad. But we often ignore the loss of other birds that are not in stories. 
Folklore, which includes stories and legends, is very important. These stories connect us to birds in a way that science cannot. They help us feel emotions that are hidden in our busy lives. 
Whether we watch birds on TV or in our gardens, the joy we feel cannot be explained by science. Birds are fascinating, and the stories we tell about them help us understand their importance. The wren in the greenhouse connects our present with a long history, and its song makes us think about the future.

**Maps**
A map shows how places and features on the earth are related to each other. This is done by showing distance and direction. In the past, people often talked about distance in time, like "it takes so many hours to walk" or "a day's journey by river." This way of measuring distance helped people understand how easy it was to travel in different areas, but it did not give exact distances.
Direction is also important, but for many travelers, the main questions were "Where do I go from here?" and "How far is it?" So, exact directions were not always very important. Because of this, written directions were often used instead of maps. Even today, some maps, like those for train systems, do not show true directions.
In the past, important landmarks were shown on maps with signs that could be realistic or simple. The way maps were made changed depending on their purpose and location. To understand old maps, it is important to know the specific way they were made.
The history of map-making, or cartography, is about making maps more accurate in showing distance and direction. Over time, cartographers used other sciences to help them. For example, instead of using shadows or stars to find direction, they started using compasses and tools to measure angles accurately.
As people explored the world more, they wanted better maps. Astronomers found out that the earth is not a perfect sphere, which helped improve maps of large areas. The needs of map users also changed. Soldiers needed accurate maps for battles, especially after new weapons were invented. This led to the creation of contour maps, which show the shape of the land.
Other people, like archaeologists and historians, also needed maps for their work. Today, cartographers make maps for many different uses, like showing land use or climate. The importance of maps in many sciences has led to a new interest in cartography.
It is important to know that the development of maps has not always been steady. There have been times when map-making did not improve, and old ideas stayed alongside new ones. Cartographers often had good ideas but had to wait for better tools to use them. Since it is easy to copy old maps, many map publishers have been slow to accept new ideas.
Therefore, we should not always trust maps as the best evidence of what we know today. The many maps we have now are the result of a lot of hard work and thought. They are valuable records for studying human history. This is what makes learning about historical cartography interesting and important.

**Tim Rice**
I went into a young man's living room. It was a nice place, very different from the messy rooms where his family spent time. Moving from the kitchen to his room felt like going from a cheap seat to a better one. This room had the biggest collection of records I had ever seen, the first stereo record player I had come across, and it showed that a teenager named Andrew Lloyd Webber had spent money on nice things like wine glasses and furniture. 
Andrew had a scholarship to Magdalen College, Oxford, to study history. He had nine months before starting school, and he wanted to be a famous composer like Richard Rodgers. I also had big dreams; I wanted to be a pop star for reasons like women, money, and fame. But my dreams were not as important to me as Andrew's were to him. When Andrew suggested I try to be a famous lyricist like Oscar Hammerstein, I was happy to try. 
In just ten minutes, Andrew played me three of his songs on the piano. I could tell he was very talented. He played songs from shows he had written at school, and they reminded me of the best albums from my parents. He needed a new lyricist, and I didn’t have much to show him except for a song I had written that a small pop group had recorded. 
We promised to meet again and write something together. I was still more interested in pop music than in theater, but I knew I had met someone special who would be very successful. Even if we didn’t become famous composers, we could try to write songs for popular bands like the Beatles and Rolling Stones later. 
The next day, back at my office where I was training to be a lawyer, I felt less sure about a life in show business with Andrew. I would still look for ads for groups needing a singer and write more songs, but I thought I would probably end up being a lawyer by twenty-five. My father thought I would stop liking pop music by twenty-one, which worried me. But I wanted to see Andrew again. It would be fun to go to a musical with him and write lyrics for musicals instead of pop songs. 
Andrew was interesting; he talked about good food and old buildings, and he supported a football team. He had been working on a musical about Dr. Thomas Barnardo, a man who started orphanages. I didn’t find the story exciting, but Andrew believed in his music. I didn’t know much about musicals, but I was excited to help. 
I started working hard, especially on the funny songs. Andrew told me the story, played the music, and gave me some titles. I even skipped a day at the law office, pretending to be sick, to write my first lyrics for the musical. That day, I didn’t know it, but I was starting a new career.

**Language**
You and I are part of a special group of living things. We can change how others think and feel by using words. Language is very important in our lives. It is hard to imagine life without talking. When people are together, they usually talk to each other. If someone is alone, they might talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I think of language as a natural skill. Just like spiders know how to make webs, people know how to talk. No one teaches spiders how to spin webs, and they do not need special training to do it.
**Climate and Weather**
Climate and weather are made by the air around us. They have a big effect on animals and plants. Climate can change how a place looks. For example, warm and wet weather all year helps tropical jungles grow. These jungles have many different kinds of plants and animals. On the other hand, cold and windy places have fewer living things. The weather we see every day is caused by big air movements. The air is always moving because the Earth spins. The sun also helps create air movement.
**Coffee**
As a bar-person, my job was to serve drinks, but I also had to make coffee. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, a restaurant's success can depend on its coffee. I had several days of training to learn how to make coffee. I learned how to clean and take care of the espresso machine. I also learned how to make a good cappuccino. By the end of the week, I realized that making good coffee was harder than it seemed. I thought I might have to go back to cleaning ashtrays. Luckily, my boss was patient. He told me, "Making coffee is both an art and a science, and you need time to learn it."

**Art on TV**
Why does television often not do well with shows about art? Painting and sculpture are good subjects for TV because the camera can show the whole artwork and then zoom in to see the details. But there are not many TV series that show the joy and complexity of looking at art. 
A good example is Robert Hughes's series called *American Visions*. Hughes is a trusted critic with a strong personality. He had almost eight hours to introduce British viewers to American art, which British galleries often ignore. I thought the series would show great artworks. Instead, it focused on how American history and culture are shown in its art and buildings.
**Dealing in Metals**
For 20 years, I worked as a dealer in metals and became known as a speculator. The metals market has fewer rules than other markets. With some luck, a willingness to take risks, and a good understanding of the market, it is possible to make a lot of money. Taking risks is part of this business. This adventurous culture fits well with a free global economy. 
However, the free-trade economists who said the market would keep the prices of rare metals high have found the opposite is true. More minerals are being taken from the ground, and the prices of raw materials are going down. If we consider inflation, the prices of most metals are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to look into claims against a big company that benefits from these cheap raw materials.
**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**
Abaco and its small islands are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas, which stretch from Florida to Cuba. Each island has its own character and something special to offer. To get around the islands of Abaco, you need a boat. If a boat is not included with your room, don’t worry. There are many ferries and water taxis. You can also rent a boat if you want to go by yourself. 
Sailing is the most popular way to travel here. Abaco is called 'The Sailing Capital of the World' for a good reason. The calm waters are also great for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The islands and their beaches stretch for 200 miles like a string of pearls. At night, the lights of the restaurants and cafes in Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay shine brightly.

**Build Your Own Bamboo Bike in the UK**
You can build your own bamboo bike at the Bamboo Bike Club in the UK. This workshop is run by two engineers, James Marr and Ian McMillan. When you join a course, you get a custom bike frame designed by a computer and a fun weekend of bike-building.
It is Saturday morning in Hackney Wick, east London. The Bamboo Bike Club is the only place in Britain where you can learn to build bamboo bikes. I went to see what was happening. There was a lot of energy and fun in the workshop.
Bamboo is becoming popular for making bikes. Some companies, like Calfee Design from California and Bamboo Bikes from Yorkshire, have been making bamboo bikes since 1894. However, many cyclists find these bikes too expensive. A ready-made bamboo frame can cost about $2,995 or £1,868. 
James and Ian wanted to make bamboo bikes more affordable. They spent years working in a shed in Brecon, Wales, to create a business that everyone could enjoy. They wanted to share the joy of making something special and sustainable. Now, the Bamboo Bike Club is more about community than just a business. James works on wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer. They run monthly courses where you can build your own bike frame at a good price.
On the first day of the course, James and Ian teach you how to choose strong bamboo and how to make strong joints. You start by gluing the bamboo tubes together to make the bike frame. They also use metal tubes for parts that need to be very strong, like the handlebars and wheel forks. 
James and Ian help everyone with their work. They check every cut and joint to make sure it is right. If someone has trouble, they will help. Many people in the course are engineers, but Ian says everyone makes mistakes sometimes. If you mess up, just try again with a new piece of bamboo.
On Sunday, you spend time building the lugs, which are the parts that connect the frame. You wrap the joints with hemp and glue them to make them strong. After adding a waterproof coating, your bike is ready for wheels, brakes, and other parts. 
James and Ian say their bamboo bikes are very strong, just like metal bikes. Ian has used his bike for over a year, and James has tested his bike off-road for three months without breaking it. They use thicker bamboo and stronger bindings to make the bikes even better.
The bamboo bikes look different from metal bikes. They may not look as neat, but they are unique. James and Ian believe that the special look is important. I chose a frame that is comfortable to ride. When I tried James's bike, it felt light and smooth, even when I rode over bumps.
James says that some people enjoy building the bike, but the best part is riding it. The bamboo bikes are light and fun to ride. And the price? It is less than £500.

**Self-help Books**
Dione Reverend worked as an editor at Random House in New York. One day, she found a book by a new pop psychologist, Dr. John Gray. She thought the title was great and believed it would be a bestseller. She was right! Dr. Gray became very rich, and Dione started her own company. Dr. Gray's book helps men and women communicate better. It is very popular and is part of a big self-help industry in America. This industry tries to help people improve their lives, but it also creates many new problems. In New York, many self-help books are published, but many more are not accepted because they are too similar or too specific. Editors are always looking for the next big book. They care more about how well a book can sell than how well it is written. Dione says that if someone has a catchy title, it is easier to sell the book.
**Autobiographies**
When someone writes an autobiography, there is an agreement between the writer and the reader that the truth will be told. However, this agreement is often broken. The writer may feel ashamed of some things and not want to share them. They might also think some details are not important. Sometimes, writers create stories that are not completely true but help explain their lives better. They may call their book an autobiography to make readers believe it is true, even if it is not. This can happen without the writer being dishonest.
**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**
People who study detective stories say they show the problems of society in the late 1800s and early 1900s. In these stories, a crime represents human feelings like greed or desire. Solving the crime helps bring order back to society. In Hammett's stories, society is shown to be corrupt. The detective and the criminal are often similar. The detective understands the criminal, and they have a strange connection. The detective is part of both worlds: he is too honest for the criminals and too shady for the law. His job can be confusing because he feels connected to both sides.
**Science Writing**
Stephen Jay Gould is a famous science writer. I met him at the Grand Hotel while he was promoting his new book. He said that writing in a fancy place like that is hard. He believes that only scientists can write well about science because they understand it. If you do not know the science community, it is difficult to write about it. Gould also says that writers should not talk down to their readers. They can use simpler words, but they should not make the ideas too easy. If readers feel like they are being treated like children, they will not enjoy the writing.

**Air-conditioning**
At Cannons Gym, a popular place for City of London workers, it is very cold inside. This summer, the gym has used a lot of air-conditioning because of the high temperatures. Sometimes, it feels like the Arctic when it is quiet. This shows how people often use air-conditioning too much. It is now a big part of our lives, helping us control the temperature. However, many buildings could be cooler without so much air-conditioning. They could use sunlight and fresh air, and have thicker walls that keep heat out during the day and let it go at night. These ideas are simple but can really help reduce the need for air-conditioning.
**Sundials**
It is interesting that more people are looking at sundials again. Sundials are tools that tell time by the sun's position. A hundred years ago, they were very important for keeping time. But as clocks and watches got better, sundials became just decorations in gardens. Now, people are starting to appreciate them again. David Harber, who makes sundials, thinks they are special because they connect us to the planets. He says there is a magical moment when a sundial starts to work. They are calm and beautiful objects that remind us of our place in the universe.
**Paint Your Own China**
I remember seeing china-painting at an arts and crafts show. Older women painted flowers on teacups with great skill. It was amazing to watch them. Their hands were steady, and the paint looked perfect. I wondered if anyone would be brave enough to take a china-painting class. Would beginners be good at it? When I went to a class, I found out it was not scary at all. Everyone was there to have fun, and even the teacher did not want to paint like the women I had seen before.

**The Wrong Country**
Uncle chose a holiday for Keith and Dawne. It was a good price: a flight from Gatwick Airport and twelve nights in Venice, a beautiful city, at the Pensione Concordia. When Keith and Dawne went to the travel agency to book the trip, the clerk told them that other people in the package were a school group from the south coast, all learning Italian.
But something went wrong. At the travel agency or at the check-in desk, a mistake happened. Dawne and Keith ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, in Switzerland. At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their tickets and said everything was fine. 
An hour later, they were surprised to hear older people on the plane speaking with accents from the North of England. Keith thought there must have been a cancellation or that the Italian class was on another plane. They ordered drinks, and then more drinks. 
When they landed, a woman with glasses said, "The coach will take us on. Stay together now." The brochure did not say anything about an overnight stop, but when the coach arrived, Keith realized that this was what it was. 
It was close to midnight when they got off the coach. They were tired and did not feel like asking about the beds they were given. But the next morning, they found out they were supposed to stay in the hotel for their whole holiday. They were worried. 
The receptionist smiled and said, "We have the lake and the water birds. You can take a boat to Interlaken." Keith said, "There has been a mistake. We were meant to be in Venice, at the Pensione Concordia." The receptionist replied, "I do not know that name. This is Switzerland." 
Keith explained that an official said a coach would take them on. The receptionist said, "Your group is booked for twelve nights in the Edelweiss Hotel. If you want to change, it is too late." 
Dawne said, "The man who made the booking was bald, with glasses and a moustache." She gave the name of the travel agency in London. A woman smiled at Keith and said, "Some problem, have we?" She was the same woman they saw at Gatwick. 
Dawne asked, "Are you in charge, Mrs. Franks? We are in the wrong hotel." Keith added, "We got into the wrong group. We told the Your-Kind-of-Holiday girl and left it to her." Dawne said, "We should have known when they weren't from Dover."
