Keith was frustrated and wanted to talk. He said, "We noticed you at Gatwick. We knew you were in charge." Mrs. Franks said, "I counted you, but you didn’t see me. Let me explain. Your-Kind-of-Holiday has many different trips. There are villa holidays for young people and treks to Turkey." 
She continued, "All tickets and labels look the same, yellow with two red bands. If you followed others with the same label, you might end up in a wildlife park! But that could never happen." 
Keith insisted, "We are not meant to be in Switzerland." Mrs. Franks said, "Let’s see." Then she walked away, leaving them there. The receptionist was gone, and they could hear typing. 
Dawne whispered, "She seems kind." But Keith was not listening. He thought about everything that happened: giving the tickets, waiting, and getting on the plane. 
An old man interrupted his thoughts and said, "Nice to have young people here. My name is Nottage." His wife said they had the best sleep because of the lakeside air. Dawne said, "That’s nice." 
Keith walked out of the hotel, and Dawne followed him. They did not say anything about the funny situation they were in. On their first holiday since their honeymoon, they found themselves on a trip with older people when they wanted to escape from that. Uncle had said so himself when they tried to get him to come with them.

**He Was a People Person**
American business leaders are looking to Ernest Shackleton, a famous polar explorer, as a good example of management. Eluned Price reports.
Many people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and what he did. In America, people are just starting to learn about him. The Wall Street Journal called Shackleton "an Antarctic explorer whose feats went mostly unnoticed for most of the 20th century," but this is not completely true. Now, Americans are very interested in him. Many books and stories about Shackleton's journey on the Endurance are being made. The American Museum of Natural History is planning a big exhibition, and a film about Shackleton's life is also in the works.
Some American managers see Shackleton as a role model. They tell stories about his actions and find lessons in his leadership and communication skills. They even say they are "speaking Shackleton." Shackleton, who used a reindeer sleeping bag and a blubber stove, is now a model for modern management consultants.
Jim MacGregor, a managing partner at a New York firm, has looked up to Shackleton for many years. His firm helps with communication during business changes and crises. For example, they help when a factory has an explosion or when many workers must be let go. MacGregor believes that Shackleton is a good model for management because he was a strong leader and communicator. Shackleton knew what was important, especially when lives were at risk.
One important decision Shackleton made was to turn back when he was only 97 miles from the South Pole. He had to make this tough choice because they were running out of supplies and needed to return to their ship safely. In a crisis, people want to know who is in charge. While many managers today avoid responsibility, Shackleton was ready to take charge.
In 1914, Shackleton's expedition became famous. His ship, the Endurance, got stuck in ice for nine months and was eventually crushed. When the ship sank, Shackleton told his men, "We should all reach safety if you do your best and trust me." From the diaries of the men, it is clear that Shackleton was always in control. He planned carefully, kept his men informed, and listened to their ideas. He was flexible and willing to change plans if needed.
Shackleton believed that an explorer needs to be optimistic, strong, and patient. MacGregor says that in difficult times, it is hard to wait for things to get better, especially in America, where people want quick solutions. For example, if you invest money and make a mistake, it is better to wait and not sell right away, as this could lead to a big loss. Also, if a new product is not selling well, it is okay to stop selling it.
Shackleton led by example. On the way back from the Endurance, he saw Hurley, the photographer, without gloves. He gave Hurley his gloves and said he would throw them overboard if Hurley did not wear them. During a previous expedition in 1905, Shackleton did something similar with a biscuit when they were very hungry. He said he would leave the biscuit in the snow because it was so valuable.
Caroline Alexander, who wrote about Shackleton's expedition, says that people today want to hear stories of heroism. Shackleton shows that true heroism is rare now, and he represents the ideals that many people long for today.

In the forests of Madagascar, there is a special animal called the aye-aye. It has a way of finding food that is similar to a woodpecker. Both the aye-aye and the woodpecker look for insects in wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes in the wood and its long tongue to get the insects. The aye-aye uses its sharp front teeth to chew into the wood and its long third finger to reach inside and get the insects.
Scientists have studied how aye-ayes find insects. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University looked at two male aye-ayes named Nosferatu and Poe, and a female named Samantha with her baby, Annabelle. He wanted to see if they could find insects by looking for signs, like holes in the wood where insects might be.
Dr. Erickson gave the aye-ayes logs with small holes. Some holes had food inside, and some were empty. The aye-ayes went straight to the holes with food, showing they did not need to see the holes to find the insects. They might have found the food by smell or sound, but tests showed they did not use these senses either. They could find food even when the smell was blocked or when the insects were quiet.
So, how did the aye-ayes find the insects? Dr. Erickson found that they could feel the empty spaces in the wood. When looking for food, an aye-aye taps the wood with its long finger and listens carefully. It seems to be using a method called echo-location, which means it listens for sounds that bounce back to find hollow spaces.
Some people think the aye-aye acts like a woodpecker in Madagascar, but there are also birds that look for insects in wood. The aye-aye is not just like a woodpecker; it also acts like a squirrel. Its front teeth keep growing, just like a squirrel's teeth. Recently, it was seen in the wild chewing through nuts and using its long finger to get the nut meat inside.

**Ordinary People, Ordinary Lives**
Many of us have pictures of our grandparents, but how many of us know what their lives were like when they were young? Sometimes, diaries and family stories do not tell us everything. And what will our grandchildren know about us? We often plan to write things down, but we do not do it. We might leave videos instead of photos, but videos are still just images.
Hannah Renier has a solution. She writes life stories for other people. She makes a book with at least 20,000 words and pictures if needed. These books are not about famous people, but about ordinary people. Hannah got this idea when she talked to her family and saw how much of the past was being forgotten.
"When I started, I did not take it very seriously," she says. "But then I met people who have interesting stories to tell. They say they do it for their children or for the future, but they enjoy it too."
People feel safe to share their stories with Hannah. A 62-year-old man said, "I was honest. I talked about my divorce, and it still hurts." He wrote his story for his family, but he has not let his children read it yet. He wants to protect them from some painful details. He thinks they should read it after he is gone.
Hannah has noticed that many people are affected by their childhood. "Many people repeat the same mistakes because of their parents," she says. "They marry people their parents liked or choose the opposite to rebel." 
Many people still feel sad about things that happened with their parents, even many years later. They try to impress parents who were never happy. Some people even want to say, "I can't stand my mother."
Hannah listens to people without judging them. "I am not here to be nosy," she says. People sometimes share things and then worry if it should be in the book. But Hannah usually includes it. Most people want to be honest about their lives.
Hannah's books are not for everyone to read. They are personal stories. She believes we are losing touch with our past. Writing these stories helps people connect with their family history. 
Each book takes about 30 hours of interviews. Hannah uses these talks to write the life story, organizing it well. The final book looks nice and costs nearly £3,000, with extra copies costing £25 each. She gets about 10 requests each week, but the price stops many people from buying.
"I thought more people would want this service," she says. "But the people I have worked with are often from wealthy families, like those who used to have their portraits painted."

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**  
The Museum of Classical Archaeology has many copies of Greek and Roman sculptures. There are over six hundred pieces in total. It is important to know that these sculptures are not real. They are copies made from the original sculptures, mostly made in the late 1800s and early 1900s. The Museum has a special gallery with good natural light. The plaster copies are useful because they allow people to see many sculptures that were originally together but are now in different museums across Europe. You can see many famous Greek and Roman sculptures in just one afternoon.
**B. Cambridge Darkroom**  
Cambridge Darkroom is a place for photography. It has darkrooms for developing photos and a gallery that shows different photography exhibitions. We offer courses and workshops for everyone, including a popular Beginner's Course, a shorter Induction Course, and Master Classes with special photographers. Members can use the darkrooms. We also have a program for young photographers aged 12 to 16 to help them improve their skills. We sell photography books and materials.
**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**  
The Sedgwick Museum has a great collection of fossils, rocks, and minerals from all over the world. It also has the oldest geological collection in Britain, started by Dr. John Woodward. This collection has nearly 10,000 rare items kept in old cabinets from the early 1700s. Adam Sedgwick was a professor of geology who added many items to the collection. The items are organized by age, so you can see how life on Earth has changed over time. The new Whewell Gallery shows beautiful minerals and gems, with labels that explain what they are and how they are used today.
**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**  
The collection has over 400,000 air photographs taken by university staff over the last 45 years. The university has its own aircraft at Cambridge Airport and takes photos all over Great Britain. These photographs are interesting because they show the landscape and how it has changed from ancient times to now. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the library staff can help with questions. You cannot borrow the photographs, but you can buy copies, which usually take about a month to make.
**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**  
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is one of the oldest and most unique tourist attractions in the world. Visitors can enjoy making wall hangings by rubbing over one of the more than one hundred brass plates from the tombs of medieval knights and ladies. The centre makes resin copies to protect the original plates while allowing people to do brass rubbing. These brass plates were used as memorials and came from Germany to medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Many beautiful brass plates were destroyed during revolutions, but most of the remaining ones are in Britain, and you can see many examples at the Cambridge Centre.

**From Here to Fatherhood**
A. **The Theatre Director**  
I have had a strange personal life, but I have enjoyed 35 years with small children. This morning, I fed the baby, and that is what being a father means to me. I feel very lucky with my children. We all love the same things: opera, theatre, books, and music. This brings us close, especially now that they are older and I am more like a friend than a father. I do not believe in hitting children. I have slapped my kids when I was angry, but I do not think it is right. I may not have been the best father, but I always tried to be there for them. I wait for them to call me. If I chase them to ask why they haven’t called, it makes them feel guilty. My parents did that to me, and I will not do it to my children.
B. **The Advertising Executive**  
I was young when my children were born, only about 25. I found the responsibilities hard, but they also kept me young. As they became teenagers, they showed me new things like music and fashion. This helped me in my job. I missed some important events when they were young, like their first concerts and sports days, and I feel sad about that. But now, I can take them on holidays to nice places, and they enjoy being with my friends at parties and events. I think it is good that my job is interesting to them.
C. **The Politician**  
My first child was born just before I started my political career. My wife and I promised to spend time with our kids, but as I got busier, it became harder. I only go to meetings on weekends if my kids can come with me. This way, they see what I do and do not feel like I am disappearing. I have noticed more politicians bringing their kids to work. Maybe we all want our children to be part of our lives.
D. **The Writer**  
My first marriage ended when my daughters, Kate and Bonnie, were young. I had to think a lot about being a father. I tried hard to stay close to them. My ex-wife and I even lived next to each other for a while so they could visit easily, but I think it confused them. Kate has said I was always there for her, but I am not sure I was a good father. I was around a lot, but I treated my kids like adults too soon. Kate said we were too relaxed with rules. I wish I had been stricter. I still worry about my daughters, no matter how old they are. 
E. **The TV Presenter**  
I was ready for kids when I turned 30. I met my wife, and we had a nice home, so we thought, "Why not have a child?" Having my daughter, Betty, made me think about who I am. It feels special to have a child, but it also makes you just one of many parents. Sometimes I feel frustrated, but when I see her smile, all my irritation goes away. A baby's smile is very powerful.

**THEATRE**
**A. Tamburlaine the Great**  
This play by Marlowe is about a strong warrior. It is long, but the director Terry Hands makes it exciting. He cuts parts of the text to make the show faster and more energetic. Antony Sher plays the main character and does amazing things, like jumping from the balcony and sliding down a rope. He keeps the audience's attention with his powerful performance.  
*Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*
**B. Women Laughing**  
This play by Michael Wall is now in London after being shown in Manchester. In the first part, two married couples talk on a sunny lawn, but it feels a bit scary. In the second part, the story changes and shows how illness affects people. Michael Wall was a talented writer who died too young at 44.  
*Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)*
**C. Amphibians**  
Billy Roche is a new Irish playwright. His plays are set in Wexford, and this one talks about the problems in the fishing industry. It has strong characters, deep feelings, and funny moments. Sometimes the story feels a bit slow, but it ends with a strong finish.  
*Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*
**D. Murder by Misadventure**  
This is a traditional thriller about a perfect murder. Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play two crime writers who want to kill each other. The story is familiar, but it has interesting twists.  
*Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)*
**E. The Alchemist**  
Young director Sam Mendes brings out the best in Jonson's funny play about tricksters from the 17th century. The show was first seen at the Swan Theatre and is now at the Barbican. Jonathan Hyde, David Bradley, and Joanne Pearce give great performances as the three con-artists.  
*Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*

David Thacker's production of Shakespeare's funny play is not very good, but the actors Ron Cook and Anton Lesser are great. They play funny characters that make the show better, even if the design is not good.
