**Hide and Seek**  
Emma and her friends are playing a game during the holidays. They are watching a strange bookshop when Emma sees her Uncle Jim. He tricks her and tries to make her turn against her friends. When Emma's life is in danger, the story becomes very serious. She is trapped in a dark cellar of an old house. This book shows family life, childhood friendships, and that sometimes adults are not as safe as they should be. It is an important and interesting read.
**Backtrack**  
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, work together to find out what happened in a train accident in 1915 that killed eight people. They look at different documents like maps and personal stories to understand the event. This is a smart and complex story that makes the reader think hard.
**Pigeon Summer**  
Mary Dyer feels different from her family. She loves her father's racing pigeons. When her father leaves for work, Mary takes care of the pigeons and wins prizes, even though her mother is upset. Set in 1930, this story teaches that there are many kinds of intelligence. Thoughtful readers will enjoy it.
**Yaxley's Cat**  
In this story, a woman named Rose wants to escape her unhappy life. She moves into a cottage with her two children. A fierce cat and strange things in the house help her discover what happened to the previous owner, Sepp Yaxley. But the locals do not like them, and their lives are in danger. In the end, the violence stops, but Rose is still worried about her son.
**Someone's Mother is Missing**  
Sam is a chubby and talkative boy who admires his cool cousin, Lisa. When Lisa's life falls apart, Sam helps her find balance. They both learn about family and what is important. The story is a bit slow in places, but it has gentle humor and shows how the two teenagers grow closer. It can be interesting for both boys and girls.
**Stanley's Aquarium**  
Barry Faville tells a funny and engaging story set in New Zealand. Robbie works in the garden for an old man named Stanley. At first, she finds him interesting, but later she is scared of him. When she discovers what is in his aquarium and his plans, the story becomes thrilling but still focuses on the characters and their relationships.
**Dodger**  
This is a sad story about Mick, who has problems with his family and school. The story is told through flashbacks, letters from a teacher, and Mick's own notes. Mick learns to deal with how others see him and his low self-esteem by acting in a school play and with help from a caring teacher. It is a highly recommended book, even though it is very emotional, especially at the end.

**Science Flying in the Face of Gravity**
Journalist Tom Mumford joins students who are testing their ideas in weightlessness. The plane looked like a normal aircraft from the outside. The pilot told the 13 students from Europe and America that it was built in 1964. It was a Boeing KC-135, which is based on the Boeing 707. But inside, it was very different. The inside was a long white tunnel with few windows and lights on the padded walls. Most of the seats were taken out, except for a few at the back where the nervous students sat.
For 12 months, these students had worked hard to join this special flight. The European Space Agency asked them to come up with creative experiments to do in weightlessness. The students with the best ideas won a spot on this amazing flight, which felt like a big roller-coaster ride.
For the next two hours, the plane would fly up and down like a bird. The pilot would turn off the engines at 3,000 meters, and the plane would go higher for a moment before falling back down. During this time, everything inside the plane would be weightless. The students would feel like they were closer to the moon than to the Earth.
The plane took off smoothly, but soon the pilot made the plane climb steeply. The engines roared, and the students felt the blood rush from their heads. Then, the engines stopped, and they experienced weightlessness. For 20 seconds, they floated in the air, like they were on a trampoline. They could not tell which way was up or down. 
After 10 seconds of falling, the pilot pulled the plane up again. Gravity returned, but not as quickly as it left. Some students landed hard on the floor. They had 30 curves to go through, which gave them 10 minutes of weightlessness for their experiments. 
The Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to see how cats always land on their feet. They released a device to help with this experiment. The German team looked at how metal joins are affected by weightlessness, which could help build future space stations. Another team from Utah State University tried to create solar sails from thin liquid films in microgravity. They believe these sails could help satellites use the sun's energy like a yacht uses wind.
After two hours of flying, the students felt excited, not sick. One student said, "It was an unforgettable experience. I wanted to be an astronaut before, but now I want to even more."

**With the Trees: My Experience in New Zealand**
Jonathon Porritt talks to Danny Danziger. Jonathon Porritt is the author of "Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology."
I had a strange time in my life when I did not have any summers. I went to New Zealand every summer, which is actually winter there. So, I had nine winters in a row, which was great because I like winter. My parents had an idea to buy a small piece of land for my brother, sister, and me to take care of. My mother said, "If you plant trees on it, you can have it." This way, we would always have a connection to New Zealand, which is nice because my father grew up there.
They found a piece of land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land was not very good, but it was good for planting trees. I have always liked land. I spent a year in Australia working on farms, so I was excited about planting trees. I started planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, my siblings and I had planted the whole 70 acres.
In 1968, it rained a lot in New Zealand. It was strange to think of that time as happy because it rained almost every day we were planting. I remember every morning getting ready to plant. I would come out of the Land Rover warm and dry, but then the rain would start. My clothes were still wet from the day before, and my hands were cold. 
In that first year, I worked with a man who knew how to plant trees. This was helpful because I had never done it seriously before. I had a planting bag around my neck to carry trees. When the bag was full, it was heavy, but when it got lighter, it was easier to work. 
The hardest part was making sure the lines were straight. You have to decide how far apart to plant the trees and then use poles to make straight lines. Once you are in line, you can plant all the way down and then come back. I enjoy hard work, and it helped me get fit. After a while, planting trees became easier. You learn a rhythm and use fewer movements to dig the hole and plant the tree.
While planting, I had a lot of thoughts about life and nature. Many of my ideas about the natural world started during that time. I have been back to New Zealand four times since then and watched the trees grow. It feels good to see the trees I planted. I worry when I read news about storms or droughts in New Zealand, but the trees are now 20 years old and doing well.
In 1984, I took a break from teaching and went back to New Zealand alone for three months. I wrote my first book, "Seeing Green," there. There is a small cabin on the tree farm with just a bed, a table, and a chair. In the mornings, I wrote, and in the afternoons, I pruned the trees. The connection I have with that place is very strong. It is where I feel closest to the bond between people and the earth.

**Taking Care of Badger Cubs**
One day, I was surprised when one of my helpers brought me a cardboard box. My husband Derek and I have an open farm in Somerset where we take care of orphaned animals. I heard strange noises from the box, so I looked inside. I saw three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. They had soft coats and looked up at me with their milky eyes. I had never seen badger cubs before.
Most badger cubs are born between January and March and live underground. If they lose their mother, they often die from hunger. These three cubs were found by builders who accidentally dug into their home. Their mother was dead, but the cubs were alive. They were cold and scared. I took them to my kitchen to keep them warm. I named the two girls Primrose and Bluebell, and the boy Willow.
At first, I fed them with a syringe. I had to wipe them with a warm cloth to help them feel like their mother was licking them. This helped them go to the bathroom. For the first few days, I fed them every four hours. After a week, they learned to drink from a bottle and started to move around. They were happy with each other and a warm pad to cuddle.
Three weeks later, I noticed Willow was not as active, but he was still eating. I should have acted quickly, but I didn’t. The next morning, I found him dead. The vet said he had a lung infection. It is important to feed animals slowly, or they can get sick. I felt sad about Willow, but I continued to care for the other two cubs.
Then, a local farmer came to see me. He had found another male cub, alone and hungry. I named him Willow II. He was younger than Primrose and Bluebell. Feeding him was hard. I had to move the bottle around to get him to drink. After a week, he learned to eat sausages, and soon he was ready for more food.
By five months old, all the cubs were eating cereals, meat, vegetables, fruit, and nuts. Badgers usually eat a lot of earthworms, but it was a hot summer, and finding food was hard. By August, the cubs started to come out at night. They loved to play and chase each other in the orchard.
One night, I saw other badgers in our field. They were looking for food, but badgers can be aggressive. We were told to protect our cubs, so we put metal over the gate to keep them safe. The local press took pictures of me walking the badgers, and many people wanted to help build a home for them.
With help from our son Daniel, we designed a new home for the badgers. It had tunnels and a special gate. Many people donated money and materials. Finally, the badgers moved into their new home. I watched them settle in and then left them alone.
Now, I don’t walk with them as much because they stay up late. Primrose has moved to another home, but Bluebell and Willow II still come to say hello before they run off into the night. This is their home now, and they are happy.

**In Search of True North - and the Man Behind Halley's Comet**
Dr. Toby Clark is a researcher at the British Geological Survey. He wants to follow the journey of Sir Edmund Halley, who studied compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports.
Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. But he also did important work by studying how compasses work. He used his sea trips on a warship called Paramore to find out about the "variations of the compass." These variations are now called "declination." Declination is the angle between magnetic north and true north. Sailors needed this information to correct their compasses and navigate the oceans.
Halley was one of only two men in England paid to do scientific research at that time. He planned to sail to the Cape Verde Islands to study declination in the North and South Atlantic. However, his first trip ended early because the crew did not listen to him. Halley tried again and traveled to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. In 1701, he published a map called "New and Correct Chart showing the Variations of the Compass in the Western and Southern Oceans." This map helped sailors for over a hundred years until changes in the Earth's magnetic field made it less accurate.
Dr. Clark wants to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's trip by following the same route. He needs to raise £70,000 before he can start. Sir Vivian Fuchs, who led the first expedition across Antarctica, is helping him.
Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while he was in Antarctica for two years. He read about Halley's life and said, "Halley led a remarkable life. He was a respected scientist and led expeditions. He was not just an astronomer but also studied geophysics." Halley created a diving bell and helped Sir Isaac Newton with his famous book, Principia Mathematica.
Dr. Clark believes that retracing Halley's journey will give him the recognition he deserves. His trip, called "In the Wake of the Paramore," will also have scientific value. He will take measurements like Halley did, but with better tools. The Earth's magnetic field is always changing, so these new measurements are important.
Dr. Clark explained, "It is common to measure the size of the magnetic field but not the direction. You need to know true north to measure the direction." On this trip, they will use satellites to find true north. The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments for the measurements. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements, and Dr. Clark hopes his work will help fill in any gaps in the data.
Halley's journey was very important. It was the first scientific expedition at sea, and he was the first civilian to be a naval captain for this kind of work. 
Dr. Clark has the experience to make his trip successful. He spent two years in Antarctica and worked at the British Geological Survey. He has already sailed 13,000 kilometers from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with different crews.
When asked if he shares Halley's obsession with this work, Dr. Clark said, "I am ready to give up my life for eight months to do this. Some people might think I'm obsessed, but I want to have a good reason to sail across the Atlantic again. Halley and his fascinating life have given me a real sense of purpose."

**POWER DRESSING**
Every summer, the peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful feathers to the hens. This behavior makes people think about a question that Charles Darwin wondered about: how can birds have such fancy feathers in a world where survival is tough? 
Darwin believed that animals change over time through evolution, not by special creation. He thought that the strongest animals survive and have babies. But he also thought that the peacock's tail was not useful for survival. So, he suggested another idea called "sexual selection." This means that female birds choose males based on their beauty.
Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, had a different idea. He believed that if hens liked the peacocks with the most beautiful tails, there must be a good reason for it. He thought that the tail was not just for show but showed something important about the male's ability to survive.
Now, 100 years later, scientists are still trying to find the answer. At Whipsnade, there are 200 peacocks that live like wild birds but are used to people. Marion Petrie and her team are studying two main questions: Do peahens really choose the males with the most beautiful tails? And do these peacocks have other good qualities, or is it just for show?
The scientists watch the peacocks and take pictures. They found that the hens do prefer the males with the most eye spots on their tails. The more eye spots a peacock has, the more mates he attracts. But they still need to find out if these beautiful males are better in other ways.
William Hamilton from Oxford University thinks that male birds with fancy feathers are healthier and have fewer parasites. This idea has been seen in other birds, but the scientists at Whipsnade have not yet checked the peacocks for parasites.
This year, Dr. Petrie is comparing the babies of attractive peacocks with those of less attractive ones. She wants to see if the babies of the attractive males grow faster and are healthier. If they are, it would support Wallace's idea that the hens choose wisely.
There is also an interesting idea from a mathematician named R A Fisher. He suggested that if a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail, their sons will have long tails, and their daughters will like long tails too. This could lead to more and more peacocks with long tails over time. This idea also supports Darwin's thought that females might choose beauty for its own sake.

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**
Tom Cunliffe believes that the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He did this with his own boat, called 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of beautiful yachts with new technology. Most of these boats come from a big change in boat design that happened 25 years ago. 
In contrast, my boat is quiet and sits in a tidal creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it is 100 years old. Some people might think I am a romantic for owning such a boat. Maybe I am, but I don’t think so. My boat uses the best parts of old boat design, but it also uses modern technology to make it easier to build.
However, modern technology can sometimes keep sailors away from the real experiences of being at sea. These experiences are often what they want to find when they go sailing. I don’t think sailors should go back to suffering all the time. I like my boats to have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable places to sleep. But why go sailing if everything is done for you? Dealing with sails that flap in the wind is part of being a sailor.
Also, why should we change the steering position to a place that is less safe? This change makes the inside of the boat feel like a big house, with a bed bigger than the one at home. For me, a boat should be a boat, not a house on the water.
When I bought my first boat, Hirta, to race around Britain for a TV show, the previous owner said it had comfort but no luxury. I learned he was right. Hirta had heavy sails, no running water, no electricity, no fridge, no central heating, and no electronics for navigation. But she was the easiest boat I ever sailed.
On land, classic boats like Hirta need a lot of care. When I hurt my back, I knew I had to stop sailing her. I looked for a younger boat but couldn’t find one, so I decided to build a new boat from scratch. The Westerman has never let me down. 
The designer, Nigel Irens, and his assistant, Ed Burnett, are good with computer design, but Irens first drew the boat on a paper napkin. Then he made a model, just like boat builders did in the past. We worked together to improve the design using a computer. The final design was perfect. 
The Westerman has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of her first six races. She looks timeless, moves beautifully in the sea, and feels peaceful inside. This is because she was designed only as a sailing boat, without thinking about furniture. 
She is made from wood treated with special glue, so she does not take in water. This means she has the advantages of a fiberglass boat but still looks, feels, and sails like a real boat.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**
Health farms and country hotels with spa services are very popular now. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.
**A. HENLOW GRANGE**  
I was happy to go to Henlow Grange for six days because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the big 18th-century house was very comfortable. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I started to join classes like yoga and body conditioning. The teachers were very good. I felt more flexible as the week went on. They offer many treatments, like aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The facial treatment made me feel like a new person. The staff were very friendly and professional. The place felt lively and positive. Henlow is planning to make some big changes this year, including a new swimming pool. You can also ride bicycles around the grounds. If you want to relax, you can read a magazine or take a quiet walk in the garden. I felt great and full of energy when I left. I want to visit again. This is a perfect place for busy women. Save Room 5 for me!  
*Marcella D'Argy Smith*
**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**  
The calm and relaxing feeling of this big house was clear as soon as I walked in. The Hall has a nice library and a lovely conservatory. There is a lot of space, so you can be alone if you want. When you arrive, everyone gets a health check, which includes checking your weight and blood pressure. They called us patients, which felt strange because I am healthy. However, they found a shoulder problem during my check, and I worked on it in group classes and private sessions. Each person gets a special diet to follow. I lost weight without starving, but I was still hungry and got a headache on the second day. My daily meals included grapefruit and honey for breakfast, salads for lunch, and fruit, yogurt, and hot broth for dinner. If you are not on a diet, you can eat in the main dining hall, where the food is tasty. You can have a massage or water therapy every other day. Extra treatments cost more.  
*Liz Gregory*
**C. CAREYS MANOR**  
Careys is not a health farm, but it is a nice old manor with cozy fires and a big lounge. If you are counting calories, you might want to skip the gourmet food. The French chef makes rich sauces and creamy desserts. Luckily, the hotel has a gym and a soft-water pool to help you stay fit. You can choose a healthy diet if you want to lose weight. There is a spa bath, steam room, sauna, and treatment rooms. A big draw is the sports injury clinic. I got advice for an old shoulder injury. The physiotherapist suggested good posture, exercises, and massage. Careys is comfortable and luxurious, but also relaxed. If you want to explore, there is beautiful countryside around.  
*Beverly D'Silva*
**D. CLIVEDEN**  
Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel that treats guests very well. It offers health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, a swimming pool, tennis, horse riding, and more. There are beautiful walks and gardens in the 376-acre estate. Waldo's is a famous restaurant with amazing food. It took me a long time to read the dinner menu because there were so many choices. The meal was wonderful, especially the sticky-toffee pudding with banana ice cream. I went to bed very happy! The next morning, I spent some time in the gym to burn off some calories. I enjoyed a facial and an aromatherapy massage. Cliveden has many fitness and beauty treatments if you want to use them before enjoying a meal at Waldo's.  
*Kay Letch*
**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**  
The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It is the best because it is very delicious, but it is also very high in calories, which is not good if you want to lose weight. You have been warned! The second best thing is the wonderful aromatherapy massage. I chose relaxing oils and fell asleep during the massage. I had the best sleep in years. The place is modern and well-organized, with nice rooms. There are many therapists and beauty rooms, so it is easy to book treatments. They offer many services, from manicures to deep-cleansing facials. The guests are a mix of people, from football teams to mothers and daughters. I would love to take a break here every month.  
*Eve Cameron*

**NATURAL TALENTS**
In the last seven million years, humans and chimpanzees have changed very little. We are still more than 98% similar to chimps. This means that the differences between humans and animals are very new. Our ability to create art and other things we think are special to humans comes from just a small part of our genes. 
Studies of animal behavior show that many things we thought were only human are also found in animals. For example, chimpanzees use sticks as tools, and sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys also have a simple form of language with different sounds for different dangers, like leopards and snakes. This means that besides art, there are not many clear differences between humans and animals.
If human art comes from special genes, it is strange that our ancestors did not make art for almost seven million years. The first art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but we cannot find these because they do not last long. The first clear evidence of human art is from about 35,000 years ago, with cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments.
Some people say that human art is different from animal art in three ways: 
1. Human art is not made for a purpose.
2. Human art is made for beauty and pleasure.
3. Human art is learned, not instinctive.
Let’s look at these points. First, Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." This means that human art does not help us survive or pass on our genes, unlike many animal behaviors. While some human art does communicate ideas, it is not the same as passing on genes. Birdsong, on the other hand, helps birds defend their territory or attract a mate.
The second point is that human art is made for beauty. We cannot ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mostly sing during mating season, so they might not sing just for pleasure. This makes human art seem unique.
The third point is that human art is learned. Different human groups have different art styles that they learn. For example, songs in Tokyo are different from songs in Paris. But some birds are born knowing how to sing their species' song, even if they have never heard it before.
Human art changes quickly. For example, people can tell when a painting was made just by looking at it. In 1957, two chimpanzees named Congo and Betsy had an art show in London. Congo made many paintings and seemed to enjoy it. Their paintings sold well, which is something many human artists cannot do.
These chimpanzee paintings show that the line between human art and animal behavior is not so clear. Like human art, the chimpanzee paintings were not made for a specific purpose; they were created for the enjoyment of the painter. Some might say human art is different because it is meant to communicate, but even some famous human art was made just for the artist's own pleasure.

**An Awfully Big Adventure**
The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last places on Earth that people have not explored. It is also very dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed this desert and lived to tell his story. There are not many big adventures left and not many heroes. In the past, children's stories had brave explorers with sunburnt skin and narrow eyes, looking into the distance on their journeys. Today, we do not see such people in stories or in real life. But then I met Charles Blackmore.
Blackmore's big adventure was leading a group across the Taklamakan Desert. The name means "once entered, you never come out," but local people call it the Desert of Death. He remembered the dangers and excitement of that amazing journey while sitting in his family home. His team had four British people (one was a doctor), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were long-distance truck drivers. This misunderstanding could have been very dangerous for everyone.
This mixed group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of the desert. Charles Blackmore wrote a fascinating story about their journey. At that time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun and to find out more about himself. "I thought I would spend my whole life in the Army. I was offered a promotion, but I wanted to see who I really was outside of that. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was very worried that I would not come back because nobody had ever done that route before; we went into it without knowing what would happen. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was very good to us."
Anyone reading his amazing story will wonder why he said the desert was "kind." The team faced many problems: sickness, extreme heat and cold, thirst, and losing some of their water. "But," Blackmore said, "when we were very tired and the camels had not had water for seven days, we found some. We did not have the famous sandstorms of the Taklamakan. And we did not feel the freezing cold that could have stopped us. But we still had many challenges. The fine sand got into everything, especially our blisters and wounds. The high dunes were hard to climb for us and for the heavy camels, which sometimes fell over onto us."
"What pushed me to keep going was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Our budget and time did not allow for one. No planes flew over us. Once we entered the sandhills, we were completely alone. I knew I could handle the mental part of the trip, but I was scared about my physical strength. I remember the first day — we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot that it was hard to breathe. I thought, 'We have to do this now!' At that moment, I was very scared."
If it was hard at the beginning, how did they feel at the end? "After walking for 1,000 kilometers, you are not going to give up. You have gone through so much. We were very thin but also strong. My body was fit, and my legs were strong. I could walk over anything."
In the middle of the book, Blackmore described lying in the desert, looking at the full moon and thinking about his family. How did he feel about what they went through? "Inside me, I am trying to find peace. When I have doubts about myself now, I think back to the desert and remember that we did it together. I feel prouder of that expedition than of anything else I have done. But when I think about my life, I think of my family and the happiness we share. Compared to that, the desert does not measure up."
Has Charles Blackmore found peace? "I long for the challenge and the open spaces. We felt good because we had a purpose. Now, it is hard for me to be part of the same routine of modern life."

Life Without Gadgets**
Susan Harr decides to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it gives us useful tools that make life easier. But sometimes, we rely too much on these gadgets. For example, when Susan's word processor broke, she had to pay a lot of money to fix it. This made her think that gadgets can be more trouble than they are worth.
Susan started to stop using some of her household gadgets. She wondered if technology really gives us more time. Does it just make us buy more gadgets? When her broken machine made strange noises, she left it outside. Now, she enjoys taking her time to sew by hand. She feels free and not tied to a noisy machine.
There are some gadgets Susan still likes, like her washing machine. But she found joy in giving up others. For example, they returned their color TV and went back to a small black-and-white one. This made them spend more time walking their dog, reading, and talking with each other. 
Susan used to think sewing by hand was hard and boring. But now, she finds it relaxing and satisfying. She can listen to the radio or talk with family while she sews. She enjoys sitting by the fire with a cup of tea. 
Now, Susan thinks about what gadgets she really needs. Do they need a freezer, a microwave, or even electric lights? She realizes they could save money by doing without some of these things.

'Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker who makes beautiful furniture. Joanna Watt meets him. When I arrive at his workshop in East London, he shakes my hand quickly and says, "Well, fire away then!" He seems busy, and his workshop is full of furniture pieces and wood in many colors. Hurst has been making furniture for ten years and has a good reputation. He has many orders and does not need to advertise. People know that if they want a nice cupboard, table, or bookcase, Hurst is the right person.
It is not hard to find a furniture-maker, but it is harder to find one who makes furniture with good quality and simple designs. Hurst says, "There are few real cabinet-makers now. Many people call themselves furniture-makers." He is often disappointed by the quality of some modern furniture. He does not like cheap, mass-produced furniture and wants to make perfect pieces. This desire for perfection helps him succeed.
Hurst is confident in his skills. He says, "I have a huge natural ability. I have always been good at making things." He learned by asking questions and teaching himself. Most of his work comes from private clients, and some come back for more. He enjoys doing complete projects for their homes. However, he finds it frustrating when clients do not know what they want.
Hurst is also kind and praises others when they deserve it. He says, "There are people far better than me." He does not like when craftsmen try to be artists and take too long to make one piece. He thinks furniture should be useful, not just a fashion statement. Hurst is confident but also humble. As I leave, he says, "After all, I am only making furniture."

**Three Theories About Sleep**
People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This shows that sleep is very important. But, scientists do not agree on why we need sleep. There are three main ideas.
The first idea says that sleep is important for our bodies. It says we sleep to keep our bodies healthy. While we sleep, our bodies fix any damage from the day and help us feel better.
The second idea is about learning. This idea says that sleep helps us understand and remember what we learned during the day. Without sleep, we might not learn well.
The third idea is about energy. It says we need sleep to recharge our energy. This helps us have enough energy for the next day.

**ECCENTRICS**
An eccentric is someone who acts differently from most people. They do not follow the usual rules of their society. This makes us think, "What is normal?" Many of us have our own strange habits. For example, some people love to enter contests in newspapers, collect beer mats, or write letters to the newspaper about many topics.
Being eccentric shows our individuality. Inside us, there is a struggle between wanting to be ourselves and wanting to fit in. It is like having two trains on the same track, pushing against each other. One train is called individualism (being yourself) and the other is conformity (fitting in). Most of the time, we want to fit in more than we want to be different.
People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often find each other. They create clubs, hold meetings, and organize events to talk about what they love or their problems. They want to be with others who understand them, even if others think their interests are strange. Being in a group can make us feel safe.
Many of us feel a pull between being ourselves and fitting in. Even when we follow the crowd, we might not like it if someone points it out. For example, a man at a bar might say, "I say what I think," to show he is different. Or a new person might say, "You must take me as I am," to show they do not care about rules.
Anyone can choose to be more individual. Some people become very successful by being themselves. Bob Dylan, a famous American singer, said, "When you feel what you are doing and go after it, you will surprise many people." But at first, this is not true eccentricity. If a pop singer wears strange clothes just to get attention, or a hostess makes shocking comments to be noticed, that is not eccentricity. 
However, if they keep doing these things until it becomes part of who they are, then they are eccentric. The key to eccentricity is being natural. Eccentrics do not try to be strange; they just are. They do not care much about what others think. They act based on who they are.
This makes eccentrics different from other people like enthusiasts, pranksters, or attention-seekers. These people are aware of society and often act to impress others or to escape from it. But eccentrics live their lives happily, no matter what others think.

**Natural Books**
We asked four nature experts to share the wildlife book that has influenced them the most.
**A. Geoffrey Lean**  
It was easy for me to choose the author. As an environmental journalist, I have met many important people in this field. One of the most important is Barbara Ward. She has worked hard on environmental issues in Europe after the war. She combined her experiences into her own strong ideas. When I was a young journalist, she helped me understand everything better. Choosing her book was harder. It could have been "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." But I think her most important book is "The Home of Man." This book talks about the fast growth of cities and important themes in her life. It is a strong call for what we now call "sustainable human development." I have read many books since, but none are as good as this one.
**B. Linda Bennett**  
When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of the guano in the sun. This book explains very well, with words and pictures, how animals communicate. If you read "Signals for Survival" and then watch a gull colony, you will see how their chaos turns into a smart social structure. You can see which birds are partners and recognize families later in the season. Niko Tinbergen was a great behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. His work with talented wildlife artist Eric Ennion made this book special and interesting for anyone who loves wildlife. Ennion's paintings show how one gull can be aggressive while another is calm. This is the art of a true naturalist.
**C. Lee Durrell**  
The book that has influenced me the most is "My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell. This book not only led me to a wonderful husband but also to a great career in conservation. It made me love the natural world. I was doing research on animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read this book. I had been there for two years and was feeling down because of many problems. But when I opened "My Family and Other Animals," I felt happy again. The book shows animals and people together, creating a beautiful world worth saving. Some people say humans are bad because of what we have done to nature. But I remember Gerald as a boy in the book, seeing all living things as a family. This idea is important for everyone to understand.
**D. Bruce Pearson**  
I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library after it was published in 1966. I was immediately interested, especially in the 48 colorful bird pictures by Eric Ennion. I already had other bird books and had spent holidays learning to identify birds. These books made me start sketching what I saw. But "The Shell Bird Book" had even more. It included beautiful paintings, chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and even a chapter on birds in music and art. This book helped me appreciate birds and nature more. It showed me that my feelings and creativity about nature are just as important as scientific facts. Since art was my stronger subject, I felt like I had a new path opening for me.

**DO REVIEWS HELP SELL BOOKS?**
We asked five British publishers if book reviews help sell books. Here is what they said.
**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. They look at reviews first in newspapers. A study showed that many people buy a book because of reviews, more than because of ads or recommendations from friends. Authors feel sad when there are no reviews, but publishers are okay with bad reviews. They think that any review can help sell books because readers want to see for themselves. Publishers like reviews that match their own feelings about a book.
**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers both want good book reviews, but they want different things. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed positively. Book reviews are better now than 40 years ago, but many paperback books still do not get enough attention. Publishers need reviews to help readers find out about books and authors. Good reviews from trusted sources can really help sell books.
**Publisher C**  
Reviews are very important for publishing. Many of the books we publish are not by famous authors, so we need reviews to help sell them. Good reviews are better than ads because they show that the review is honest. Publishers often say they care more about the size of the review than the content. Good reviews can help a book and its author become very popular, but they need help from other things like recommendations and good marketing.
**Publisher D**  
I am not sure how publishing and reviewing work together in Britain. In the United States, a review in the New York Times can make a book very popular. In Britain, bookshops sometimes do not pay much attention to reviews. Sometimes it takes many years of good reviews for people to notice a good writer. Some books that get bad reviews still sell very well. It is hard to predict what will happen. Non-fiction books allow reviewers to talk more about the subject than the book itself.
**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers want great reviews. But do they help sell books? I once published a biography that got great reviews, but it did not sell well. Many people thought they could just read the reviews instead of buying the book. Does the name of the reviewer matter? Thirty years ago, if certain reviewers liked a book, people would pay attention. Now, sometimes an unexpected reviewer or a clever review can make people want to buy the book.

**WEATHERVANE MAKER**
Making weathervanes is an old skill that started in ancient Egypt. Today, Graham Smith continues this craft in his workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who makes weathervanes by hand. Graham creates special designs for his customers. He says, "This way, I can make a unique item." Many of his customers are women who want to buy special gifts for their husbands. They look for gifts that show the man's job or hobbies.
Graham's weathervanes are different from the usual cockerel design. The first weathervane he made was a witch on a broomstick for his wife. His friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them. Graham realized he could make many different designs. He decided to start a weathervane business. Before this, he worked as a precision engineer for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, changed their roles. Liz went to work, and Graham stayed home to take care of the children and grow his business. This was five years ago, and he is happy with his choice. He says, "My old job was not creative, but this work is exciting and artistic. I love designing."
Graham has made over 100 original designs. He pays close attention to detail and always asks for the customer's approval before cutting the design. He also keeps some traditional designs in stock because people like them too. Graham says, "People enjoy handmade items. They want something a little different."
Graham does not want to grow his business too much because he wants to keep it a rural craft. He feels he has found his place in the market. He enjoys seeing a simple shape turn into something beautiful. For many years, weathervanes have helped people understand the weather by showing wind direction. Now, more people are moving to the countryside and want to add special touches to their homes. This has helped crafts like his.
Graham is now very busy, sending weathervanes to customers all over the world. He has many buyers from America and Denmark. He explains that the price depends on how detailed the design is. His latest request was for a weathervane of a curly-coated dog. No matter the occasion, Graham can create a special gift.

**Beginner Takes All**
Before it was published, *The Horse Whisperer* was the most talked-about book of the year. It is the first novel by British writer Nicholas Evans, and it made him a lot of money. Here, he shares his story and success.
At the start of the year, Nicholas Evans was not doing well. A film he had worked on for months was canceled suddenly. He felt sad and worried because he had not earned money for two years. He needed that film to help with his bills. A smart person in his situation would have found a job. He could have gone back to working in television. But instead, he made a surprising choice. He bought a ticket to America to research his first novel for three months.
Nicholas had an idea for the story from a farrier he met while visiting a friend. The farrier told him about a calm horse that suddenly became wild. The owners were very worried until they heard about a gypsy who could talk to the horse and change its behavior in just a few hours. These special people are called "horse whisperers." This story inspired Nicholas.
He started to learn more about horse whisperers and wanted to write a movie script. But after the film project failed, he decided to write a book instead. During the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. He said, "It was a funny time. I was watching people, but I felt alone and worried about my life. I had tried for ten years to be a filmmaker, and now I was in debt and worried about my family."
By the end of August, he returned home and had written the first half of the book. His bank manager was becoming very strict, and he needed to know if he should continue writing. He showed the book to a friend who was a literary agent. The friend said it was "fine" and thought Nicholas could get $30,000 for it. Nicholas needed more money to pay his debts. He had spent seven months on *The Horse Whisperer* and still had two months of work left.
In October, he sent the first two hundred pages of the book to seven publishers in the UK. Soon, his agent called to say that they had turned down the first offer of $75,000. Nicholas was shocked. His agent felt something good was going to happen. 
A week later, the book was sold for $550,000 in the UK and $3.15 million in the US, both record amounts for a first novel. Nicholas and his team could not believe it. They had not even sent the book to New York, but soon major movie studios wanted to make a film from it. 
Nicholas's agent in the UK worked with an agent in the US. When they said they could get $3 million for the book, Nicholas and his team laughed in surprise. They decided that the studios should each present their ideas to Nicholas. One night in October, he sat in his study while four famous filmmakers called him to ask for the rights to his unfinished novel.
Nicholas told me this story while we drank coffee on his porch at home. He said he turned down an offer to write the movie script for *The Horse Whisperer*. He felt it was like a fairy tale and did not want to ruin it. Writing for movies is very hard, and he did not want to become just an employee. He wanted to stay involved but keep some distance.
The success of his novel also brought new interest in the film *Life and Limb*, but he was not sure if he wanted to make it anymore. He said, "I think I would be foolish not to write another novel."

**Young Masters**
Bobby Fischer is trying to come back to chess, but he is not as young as he used to be. Chess is now a game for younger players. After being away from chess for 20 years, Bobby Fischer is playing against his old rival, Boris Spassky. He won the first game, which was very good, but he is not the same player he was in 1972. He is now 49 years old, not in good shape, and has not played much recently. Boris Spassky is also older.
Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Bobby Fischer helped make chess more popular, and now it is more professional. Today, players focus more on winning than on the art of the game. In international chess, a player needs to be strong mentally and physically. The pressure is high because players have to make their moves in a certain time. If they do not, they lose the game. Games are now longer, and many are played without breaks. This makes it harder for older players.
In the last 30 years, every new world champion has been younger than the last. Most of the top ten players in the world are under 30. The way chess is played has also changed. Many players prepare before their matches, using computers to study many games. A small computer can hold one million chess games and help players learn about their opponents. In recent matches, players have had teams of helpers to find weaknesses in their rivals' games.
Today, there are more great chess players than ever before. Many grandmasters compete for small prizes around the world. Playing chess is hard work, both mentally and physically. A game can last up to eight hours, and players must stay focused. If they lose concentration, they can lose the game. The chess clock adds to the stress. At the end of a game, players often rush to make their moves, which can be very exciting.
Losing is very painful for top players. Winning feels great, but one win is not enough to win a tournament. Players must be ready to compete again the next day. Most chess tournaments last 9 to 11 days, with games every day. World championship matches can be even harder. For example, a match in 1984 between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov had to stop after several months because both players were too tired.
Can Bobby Fischer succeed again? He once said, "All I want to do is play chess." This makes his long break from chess surprising. If he is back for the money, he will earn a lot from this match with Spassky. But if he wants to prove he is still the best, the result could be very sad for him.

**Fame and Fortune**
Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are becoming famous.
**A** Nick Grosso is a playwright in his early 30s. He has written three successful plays. Now, he is turning his first play, *Peaches*, into a movie script. He says, "It is a low budget, but we don’t know how low. It won’t be over £30 million, but it could be £30." Nick is very talented, but the surprising thing is that before he wrote *Peaches*, he had never been to a play or read one. He says, "When I wrote the play, I never thought it would be performed. It is set in a car. I probably wouldn’t do that now because I know it is hard to do." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After finishing A-levels, he joined the Young People’s Theatre. He realized he wanted to write for actors. "I wanted my writing to be heard, not just read," he says. "I was finally with people who thought like me. It was the first time I enjoyed learning."
**B** Simon Pegg is a 28-year-old comedian. He studied drama at Bristol University. Now, he is writing a TV comedy series and just finished a tough tour with comedian Steve Coogan. Simon has always worked hard. He practiced his comedy in clubs while at university. He remembers, "University was very theoretical. I realized I didn’t want to be a serious actor; I liked comedy more. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it isn’t. If you have courage and good material, it is great to make people laugh." He has worked with the comedy group Funny Business, but his best work has been with Steve Coogan. "He saw my show, and I was a big fan of his," Simon says.
**C** Ciaran McMenamin is 24 years old. He became famous as the lead in the show *The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star*. People liked his performance, and now he can choose what roles he wants. "It has been a great chance for me," he says. Ciaran started acting in school and then joined the Ulster Youth Theatre for four years. He laughs, "I used acting to avoid homework. But then I decided I wanted to do this seriously because I loved it." Now, he is waiting for more praise, but he thinks about fame. "When you are 18, you think you will love the photos and interviews, but you realize it is not why you act. It is about getting respect for good work."
**D** Neil Taylor is 25 years old and the lead singer of the pop band Matrix. They just signed a deal for three albums. Neil and his bandmate, Rick Brown, are expected to be very popular when their single, *Chimera*, comes out. Neil says, "The record company has different ideas about success than I do. They want a big hit, but I will be happy if two people buy it." Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and tried to get into music for eight years. "It is funny how things happen," he says. "I was about to give up when I met Rick, who had connections in the music industry. It was a great time for me."
**E** Stephen Richards is a 27-year-old poet and author. He has won many awards and is well-known in the poetry world. He has been touring and giving readings for six years. His first novel, *Hidden*, will be published in March. "It is a story about obsessive love. It was too strong for a poem," he says. Stephen loved creative writing in school but lost interest in education later. He decided not to go to university but changed his mind when he got bored working at a theatre. After university, he published his first book, a children's book, in 1992. "My parents didn’t think I would be a writer; they thought I would just read," he says. Now, he is brave to write novels. "Poetry has rules, but novels can be any length. I want to make sure my work is good and not just write a lot."

A. Isabel is a 31-year-old art student who thinks she looks good in jeans, but she rarely wears them. She is afraid of meeting the wrong people. Isabel wants to find the right man but worries that her knees are not attractive. Still, she has hope, which helps her and others in the story. The author writes in a fun and lively way, using chapter titles like "Our Hero Feels Inspired."
B. This story is about a local radio station in America that almost fails. It is told from the view of a smart child named Francis With. Francis works for WLT (With Lettuce and Tomato) Radio, which was started by two brothers to promote their sandwich shop. The station plays music and has different speakers. The author uses humor to show life in a small town and takes readers back to the simpler times of the 1940s and 1950s.
C. In this story, it is normal for a second husband to talk to his wife's first husband. Professor Richard Vaisey falls in love with a Russian poetess. He tells his wife's ex-husband about her. The poetess writes bad poetry and wants Richard to help her brother, who is in prison. The author tells this story in a funny and clever way, making it enjoyable to read.
D. In 1960s London, two sets of best friends, two women and two men, are connected for 25 years. At the start of the story, James Hudson, a rich American, is starting a newspaper with his friend Richard Blake. This is important, but so is the fact that a woman they both loved was killed years ago. The story has murder, ambition, love, and jealousy, and the writing is good. This book lets you really get to know the characters.
E. This story is written by a great American author. It is funny and kind. Ian Bedloe feels guilty about something and decides to take care of his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, he is becoming a strange bachelor. The story shows the strong bond he forms with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm book that balances sadness and laughter.

**Volunteer Tourism**
Four writers talk about international volunteer work. 
A. It is hard to say that volunteer work helps development a lot. Volunteer tourists can help build homes or schools, but they usually pay a lot of money to do this work. If this money was given directly to a local community, it could pay for more help than one volunteer can give. This is especially true for young people who take gap years, as they often do not have special skills or experience. Many studies ask if young people volunteer to help others or if they want to improve their own careers. However, these projects can help people learn to be kind and help those who have less.
B. Volunteering can help people understand each other better. It can also help solve problems, encourage people to participate in global issues, and create international friendships. In this way, everyone benefits, and it helps the world. But if only rich people can volunteer, it may help them in their careers but not help the communities that need it. Those who volunteer will keep getting benefits while using the communities they help.
C. Sometimes, international volunteering can be seen as a way for rich people to feel good about themselves or to help in a way that does not really change things. At its best, volunteering can help both the volunteers and the communities they work in. It can also help people understand and care about the problems of poverty and injustice.
D. Volunteer tourism fits well with the idea of helping others. This idea can seem good, especially when people feel that big governments and businesses do not help. However, it can also ignore the need for real change and reduce development to just individual acts of kindness. While volunteering is good, when it is sold as a way to help develop communities, it can make people forget about the real issues of poverty and inequality in the world.

**Sound the Alarm**
Stuart Harris reports
Many people listen to the radio in the morning. Most of us need something to help us get out of bed. This is why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one? I, along with inventor Tom Granger and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five clock radios that you can buy now.
One model has a 'dual alarm function'. This means you can set two different wake-up times, one for work days and one for weekends. But who really needs that? This model costs about the same as another one we tested, and it has a cassette player. You can listen to your favorite tapes to fall asleep and wake up without news. We all thought the radio quality was very good, but the clock radio is very big, like a rugby ball. Paul Bridges said, "Any clock radio I buy must leave space on my bedside table for my keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. I always book a wake-up call just in case the alarm doesn’t work."
This model was voted the best-looking and the overall winner. Paul Bridges said he was "in love with it," but the clock he tested kept getting stuck at 16:00. I liked the digital display with its nice grey numbers on a soft green background. The snooze button is wide, so you can tap it easily with your eyes closed. However, the buttons felt nice to touch, and I ended up playing with them. This made it hard for me to understand the instruction booklet. 
The clock has a backup battery, so you don’t have to reset it if someone pulls the plug. We all liked this feature. However, we found it hard to set up. But once we figured it out, we felt cool and smart. Tom Granger thought this model, which has a built-in lamp, was "very cheap" in how it was made. He had to read the instructions twice to get it to work because the clock kept changing from 12:00 to 02:00. The lamp was hard to position, and you couldn’t read by it because it only shines on the clock.
Paul Bridges thought the lamp idea was funny but agreed that the radio was hard to tune. The buzzer sounded like an alarm on a submarine, and it made me want to throw it across the room. Interestingly, this model is the third most popular one on the market. It is bright and colorful, which Tom Granger and I liked. Tom said, "I would choose this one because it stands out." The controls were easy to use, and we set it up without reading the instructions. But the alarm can be 20 minutes early or late, which is funny. Paul Bridges laughed and said this model was "very annoying" and "useless."
The simplest and cheapest model we tested was liked by Tom Granger because it was small and had old-fashioned dial tuning. He said, "It’s easier to set up. With modern buttons, you are never sure if you pressed them in the right order." He agreed that companies had to make better radios because of button tuning. I thought the tuning was not very good, but we agreed the radio quality was fine. The buzzer on this model worked well; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

Hedgehogs
A hedgehog is a small animal with sharp spines on its body. Hedgehogs live in many parts of the world, but they are not found in America or Australia. When a hedgehog is in danger, it can roll into a tight ball. This way, its spines point outwards to protect it. How well this works depends on how many spines the hedgehog has. Some hedgehogs that live in the desert have fewer spines. They may try to run away from danger instead of rolling up.
Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day. They often sleep under bushes or in holes in the ground. All hedgehogs can hibernate, which means they can sleep for a long time in winter. However, not all hedgehogs hibernate. Some stay awake all year if the weather is good.

**Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**
It is hard to be good at any sport, especially for women. They have to work even harder. Training and competitions take a lot of time, so they must make sacrifices. But despite the challenges, they are proving people wrong and breaking records. Here are some amazing British sportswomen who are reaching their goals.
A. **Jill, 27, Skier**  
"I love to ski and feel great when I jump and land well, but it can be scary. Sometimes I don’t feel good or the weather is bad, but I keep going. I train for ten months each year, so I miss a lot of time with friends. There are six men and three women on the British team, and we all compete together."
B. **Caroline, 22, Cyclist**  
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike for a charity race and won! I was surprised because I had never cycled before. Now, I earn good money as a professional cyclist. I train for at least four hours every day, plus I do some stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands how much time it takes."
C. **Annabel, 26, Rower**  
"Rowing is hard for girls because not many schools have rowing teams. Most girls start when they are older, which makes it harder to compete internationally. Coaches often change, so it can be difficult for the women’s team. But I enjoy it and like being fit, plus I have fun with my teammates."
D. **Ffyona, 24, Long Distance Walker**  
"When I was 13, I wanted to walk around the world. I didn’t know how big it was! Walking across Australia was very painful for me. I walked 50 miles a day with little sleep and many blisters. But I set a record! Some people think women are less likely to succeed, so it is harder to get sponsors."
E. **Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**  
"Some men think they are better drivers. When I do well, they ignore me. Being a woman in racing can be tough. Men often want to beat me, and I have had many accidents. It is hard to earn money, and what I do make goes back into racing. More women are starting to race now, which is great!"
F. **Alison, 28, Triathlete**  
"I wake up at 5:30 AM three days a week to swim. I need to sleep more on other days. In the evenings, I cycle or run. Sometimes I feel very tired! Racing is hard, but I feel happier when I stay fit. Men and women usually compete together, but the news often focuses more on the men. The prize money for women is not as good, but we are working to change that."

**The Day I Met Picasso**
Richard Cork remembers the day he met Picasso. He was 78 years old and a famous artist. Even from far away, you could see it was him. I was 18 years old and traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old van. I had no money, so I found a job painting boats. But I spent a lot of time drawing. One day, I was lucky to have my sketchbook with me when I saw Picasso at a restaurant in Cannes. 
Picasso usually stayed away from people and worked in the hills. So, I was surprised to see him sitting with his wife, Jacqueline, and some friends. I was nervous, but I asked him for his signature. To my surprise, he agreed. He wrote his name on my paper and then drew some lines on it. His art often showed real things, so I thought his lines might be about the clouds or the sea.
I thanked him and tried to talk to him. Picasso did not speak much English, and I did not speak much French. An American woman at the table helped us talk. She called him "the Maestro," which made it hard for me to speak. But I told Picasso that I loved art and admired his work.
After a while, I went back to my boat and showed my friend the signature. He asked, "Is that all?" He told me to go back and talk to Picasso again. So, I took my sketchbook and returned to Picasso's table. I didn’t ask if I could draw his portrait because I was afraid he would say no. Instead, I just started to draw.
When Picasso saw me, he smiled and made funny faces to distract me. He rolled his eyes and stuck out his tongue. It was hard to draw him, but I felt like he wanted to see how determined I was. Finally, he sat still for a few minutes, and I could really look at him. He looked strong and young for his age, with bright, dark eyes.
Even though he was with friends, he seemed alone and deep in thought. When the American woman told me that Picasso wanted to see my drawing, I felt shy and said it wasn’t good enough. But Picasso insisted, and when I showed him, he nodded happily. Then, he surprised me by saying it was his turn to draw.
I quickly gave him my crayon, and he drew a face on my paper in just a few seconds. His drawing was very different from mine. He made my eye look like it was on my nose and my smile was just one line. I looked like a character from one of his fun drawings.
I thanked Picasso and asked if he would sign my drawing. The American woman said he said I already had his signature. So, he didn’t want to give me another one. But I felt very lucky to have met him and to have his attention. It meant a lot to me.

**Shopping Tricks**
Have you ever gone into a store and bought more than you planned? Here are some tricks that shops use to make you spend more money.
**A. Freshness First**  
Supermarkets know that people like fresh food. They often put fruits and vegetables at the entrance of the store. They might also have a bakery that makes the smell of fresh bread fill the store. The colors in the store, like green, can make you think of fresh food. But most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen food and cleaning products, is not fresh.
**B. Smart Placement**  
Where products are placed in the store is very important. Supermarkets use computers to find out where shoppers look for items the most. They put the most expensive products in these spots. Items at eye level are very popular because people see them easily. Special offers in big bins can also attract shoppers. Sometimes, stores place items that go well together, like ice cream and toppings, near each other.
**C. Spreading Essentials**  
Supermarkets often place cheap items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, shoppers have to walk past more expensive items to get to them. Stores also put popular products far away, hoping that loyal customers will look for them and see other tempting items on the way.
**D. Less is More**  
Some chain stores have changed how they show their products. For example, Next stores display fewer items to make them look special. This design makes shoppers feel like the clothes are exclusive, even though they are still mass-produced.
**E. Total Costs Matter**  
Shoppers often care more about the total cost of their shopping than the price of each item. Supermarkets mix cheap and expensive items to attract customers. They sometimes sell cheap items at a loss to bring people in, which is called "loss leaders." They also get discounts from manufacturers by buying in large amounts.
**F. Price Tags**  
In chain stores, shoppers usually buy fewer items and pay more attention to prices. For example, pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 can make a difference. This also helps reduce theft because staff must ring up sales to give change.
**G. Lighting**  
Both supermarkets and chain stores think carefully about lighting. Chain stores try to use natural light so shoppers can see the true colors of clothes. Supermarkets use special lights to make fresh fruits and vegetables look better.
**H. Store Layout**  
Many chain stores use different carpets to guide shoppers. One pattern shows the paths to walk, and another shows sales areas. This helps shoppers move through the store, but some people may not want to explore the sales areas.
**I. In-Store Ads**  
When you enter a supermarket, you often see big pictures of delicious food. In some places, supermarkets are trying out shopping carts with screens that show ads for products as you shop. These carts are made to catch the attention of shoppers and can increase sales by about 30%.

**Sea, Ice & Rock**
Chris Bonnington, who is 58 years old, is famous for climbing Mount Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing paths in Britain and the Alps and has written many books, like *Quest for Adventure* and *Everest the Hard Way*. 
Robin Knox-Johnston, who is 53, started his career at sea in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-1969, he was the first person to sail around the world alone in his boat called Sunhaili. He also set a record for crossing the Atlantic Ocean, taking only 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard in England.
Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland. They wrote about their trip in a new book called *Sea, Ice and Rock*. In 1979, Chris was working on *Quest for Adventure* and called Robin for an interview. Robin invited Chris to join him for a sail. Chris could teach Robin some climbing skills, and Robin could teach Chris how to sail. This was Chris's first time on a yacht.
They sailed for a while and then stopped. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while Chris and Robin went to the shore to practice climbing. The climb was hard, but Chris was impressed with how steady Robin was. When they reached a big drop, Chris asked Robin if he had ever climbed before. Robin had not, so Chris showed him how to do it. Robin wanted to climb down using ropes like on his boat, but Chris wanted him to use his legs. Chris was not very happy about it, but Robin got down safely.
During this trip to Skye, Chris and Robin became good friends. Robin suggested they should go on a big trip to Greenland together. Robin was a great leader. Normally, the captain makes all the decisions, but Robin asked everyone for their opinions first. Most of the time, people did not give advice, but it felt good to be part of the decisions.
Chris found sailing boring and hard. He did not like being in the middle of the sea for many days. He preferred being on land. Robin, however, loved sailing and enjoyed fixing things on the boat. Chris sometimes felt useless because Robin did not really need his help. The boat was also very small for six people, which made it hard to be close together.
When they reached Greenland, Chris had to lead the climbing expedition. He felt nervous about keeping Robin safe. Climbing the highest mountain in Greenland, called the Cathedral, was very difficult. Robin was not a natural climber, but he tried very hard. The first time they tried to reach the top, they climbed for 24 hours. On the way down, they were so tired that they almost fell asleep on steep slopes. Robin trusted Chris completely and followed him. When it became too hard, Chris decided they had to turn back, and Robin accepted this.
Robin was also worried about their boat and whether it would be okay in the ice. But he wanted to try climbing the mountain again. The only time they had a problem was on the way home. They were taking turns to watch the boat. Chris was supposed to wake up at 4 am for his turn, but Robin did not wake him. Robin thought he could do it alone. Chris felt that Robin did not trust him, and he told him so. Robin quickly reassured Chris that he was wrong to think that.
While they enjoyed the trip to Skye, they really got to know each other during the Greenland expedition. Chris found that Robin was a kind and sensitive person, even if he seemed tough on the outside.

**A History of the Apple**
Apples have been around for a very long time. They come in many colors, shapes, and sizes. But today, we might lose some of the old types of apples.
**Prehistoric Times (8,000 BC)**  
People have eaten apples since ancient times. In Britain, they threw away apple seeds. About 10,000 years ago, people found apple remains near lakes in Switzerland and Italy. In these places, ancient people stored wild apples for winter. These apples were small and different from the apples we eat today.
**Norman Times (1000 AD)**  
The French learned how to grow fruit from the Romans. They brought this knowledge to Britain. Some apples, like the dessert apple called Decio, came from the Romans. But many Roman apples did not grow well in Britain. British monks started to create new types of apples, and many of today’s apples come from these old varieties.
**Medieval Times (1200)**  
In the thirteenth century, several apple types became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain was a main dessert apple until the 1700s. The Costard was a cooking apple sold in markets. But bad weather and diseases made it hard to grow apples, so people started to import them. In the 1500s, King Henry VIII sent a man named Richard Harris to France to learn about growing apples. Harris brought back many new apple types and started the first modern orchard in Kent.
**Settlers and Apples (1750)**  
By the seventeenth century, apples were very popular in Britain. When people moved to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand, they took apples with them. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia, and the Pilgrim Fathers took them to America. A famous apple planter in North America was John Chapman, known as "Johnny Appleseed." He planted many apple trees and was loved by the Native Americans.
**Modern Apples (1850)**  
In Iowa, a farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new apple tree and named the apple "Hawkey." At a fruit show, a judge tasted it and said it was "Delicious!" This apple became very popular. Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was found in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. She discovered a small tree growing from old fruit and grew the first green apples, which became famous worldwide.
**Uniformity in Apples (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown all over the world, but most come from just a few types. These apples are often chosen for their looks or how well they travel, not for their taste. Many old apple types are disappearing. In the UK, some gardeners keep old varieties alive, but in the US, many apples from 100 years ago are gone. People want more types of apples. We need to care about keeping different kinds of apples and other foods for everyone.

Richard Nerurkar is a long-distance runner from Britain. He is one of the best 10,000-metre runners in his country. He visits a training camp in Kenya, which is ten miles south of the equator. There is a mountain path that starts from a quiet road in Nairobi. This path leads to Mount Kenya, the highest mountain in Kenya. For three years, Richard has trained in this beautiful but lonely place called Nanyuk. 
On his fourth trip to Kenya, Richard decided to train with Kenyan runners. He ran in his first race in Kenya, where the air has less oxygen. He stayed at the national team training camp, where the best Kenyan runners prepare for big competitions. Richard was invited by the national team coach after he finished fifth in the World Championship 10,000 metres race. This was a great chance for him.
Training at high altitude helps runners make more red blood cells, which helps them carry oxygen better. This is one reason why many Kenyan runners are successful. Richard's first race in Africa was also special because it was the first international cross-country race held in Africa, in Nairobi. He finished behind 41 runners, most of whom were Kenyan. He felt he did well, but he knows that Kenyan runners are not just successful because of the altitude. They have a simple and relaxed way of training and competing.
Richard learned about how Kenyan runners train at their camp. The camp is at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up Mount Kenya. The athletes live with regular students in simple rooms. Their daily routine includes three training sessions: a morning run, interval training in the middle of the day, and a steady run in the late afternoon. They start their day at six in the morning. The coach tells them to run easy because they have a hard day ahead. They run about 40 kilometres each day, except on Sundays when they run 20 kilometres.
Life at the camp is simple. They wash their faces and brush their teeth before breakfast. Breakfast is tea, bread, and boiled eggs. Lunch and dinner are similar, with ugali (a maize dish), stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, they drive to a stream to wash off in the evening.
By the end of his stay, Richard understood more about why Kenyan runners are so successful. It is not just because of their genes or where they come from. He thinks that the simple life in the mountains, hard training, and their love for running are the real reasons for Kenya's success in long-distance running.

**The Problems with Mass Marketing**
Almost everyone knows that advertising is not doing well. This is not just because of the recession. Advertising started to go down in 1989, before the recession really began. The problems with advertising are more serious and happen all over the world. The sad truth is that advertising has not kept up with changes in the economy.
Advertisers like to think about big groups of people and big media, but as more brands and media appear, the target audiences have become smaller and more specific. Even big brand campaigns should focus on smaller groups, but they usually do not. This is a big reason why advertising is not working well.
Think about your own shopping. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or even 50 items. Most of these items are not from advertised brands. You might buy a few advertised brands, but there are many more products in the store. In a year, you probably buy only a few hundred different brands. For things like cars, you might only buy one every three years. You do not buy many clothes either, and most of them are not from advertised brands. Overall, you likely do not buy more than 400 different brands in a year.
Now, compare that to the 32,500 brands that are advertised. If we look at the 9,500 brands that are listed and analyzed, the average person only buys about 400 of them. This means that about 96% of advertising is not effective, but no one knows which part is wasted.
When you watch TV, count how many ads are for brands you buy or might buy. Most people find that only about 1 in 16 ads (6%) are for brands they are interested in. This means that 94% of the ads are not useful for them.
Many people think they are different and that they do not pay attention to advertising. But the truth is, most people do not buy most of the brands they see in ads. There is always waste in advertising because people only remember a few ads and ignore the rest. 
However, advertising can still be effective. Many ads have shown that they work. Advertisers need to reach many people to find the few who will buy their products. Even with smart targeting, advertisers cannot know exactly who will respond to their ads.
