In face-to-face selling, a salesperson might succeed with every person they talk to, but this is not possible with media advertising. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they would not need to use media at all. 
Any advertiser who can get one million new customers (about 2% of adults) is doing well. For popular products, gaining a million new customers would be a big success. To make advertising work again, the messages need to be more focused on specific groups of people.

Charles Clover visits a very eco-friendly home in Southwell, Nottinghamshire, England. This town has some interesting places. One is Southwell Minster, a little-known old cathedral. It has special carvings of 'green' men made by craftsmen in the 1200s. The second surprise is the 'autonomous house,' built by Robert and Brenda Vale. 
The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking. They recycle their waste into compost for their garden. They also heat their house using heat from their appliances and their own body heat, along with the heat from their three teenage children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house looks traditional with a clay tile roof and is located 300 yards from the Minster. It was designed to match the old buildings in the town and was approved by planners, even though it is in a protected area.
When you ring the solar-powered doorbell, it is very quiet inside. The house is very well insulated, with special windows that keep out noise. Inside, it feels calm and peaceful. On a sunny summer day, the windows are closed, and the conservatory warms the air before it goes into the house. Robert opens special windows to let in fresh air. They have made sure that there are no drafts in the house, even the cats have their own small door.
Robert and Brenda teach architecture at Nottingham University. They cared about the environment long before it became popular. They wrote a book about green architecture in the 1970s called The Autonomous House. They wanted to build a house that did not produce carbon dioxide. They also decided to not use mains water. They created special toilets and put rainwater tanks in the cellar. They use copper gutters to keep the drinking water clean, which they filter before using. Water from washing goes into the garden, and they do not use a dishwasher because they think strong detergents are not good for the environment.
Robert says, "We wanted to show that it is possible to design a house that is better for the environment without living in the dark." The only old-fashioned part of the house is the hall, which has a fireplace and a staircase that goes up to the top of the building. The Vales do not pay for water. Last winter, they used only nine units of electricity a day, which cost about 70p. This is much less than what other four-bedroom houses use.
Soon, they will add solar panels to generate more electricity. The house will still use some electricity from the mains for cooking and appliances, but it will make extra electricity. One day, they hope to have enough to charge an electric car. The only heating in the house is a small wood-burning stove, which they only use when it is very cold.
When I visited in February, Robert was reading and said it was too warm to light the fire. The temperature on the first floor was 18C, which is lower than usual, but he said it felt comfortable because there were no drafts. He explained that people used to feel comfortable at lower temperatures because of their warm clothing. 
The secret of the house is that it is simple and easy to maintain. Most materials were bought from a local store and installed by local workers. This made the house cheap to build, costing the same as low-cost rental housing. Many big building companies do not like this idea.

'The Camera Never Lies
Arthur Conan Doyle was the writer of the Sherlock Holmes stories. He thought he was a logical man and a scientist. In 1920, he saw photos of fairies in a garden. He believed these photos were proof that fairies really existed. He published the photos with an article, saying that fairies are amazing creatures.
In 1939, the two women who took the photos said they were fake. They cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The photos looked very nice, but the trick was simple. This goes against a common idea that cameras always show the truth. 
Today, we can use computer programs to change our digital photos. It is not true that photography has always been innocent. From the beginning, when cameras started taking pictures, the reality was changed.'

**Blacksmiths**
For a long time, iron has fascinated people, and blacksmiths, who work with iron, have been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were as important as doctors and astrologers because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also seen as artists. In the 1700s, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for places like St Paul's Cathedral. The lovely metalwork in French and Belgian buildings was also made by talented blacksmiths.
However, by the late 1960s, there were very few blacksmiths in Britain. Heavy industry did not need them anymore, and modern buildings often did not use beautiful ironwork. In the last 10 years, there has been a small comeback in blacksmithing because more people are interested in decorative architecture and new interior design styles. Still, much of the work looks similar, with many companies calling their products "classical" or "Victorian-style." You can find many trendy stores selling rusty candlesticks with extra pieces hanging from them.
Fortunately, there are new events to support blacksmiths. One event is an exhibition of ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA). This exhibition opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, says, "We might be starting a new Iron Age because both the public and blacksmiths are seeing things differently now." Power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to work with metal. They can now bend, twist, and weld metal more easily. Dawson explains, "These artists can now use metal to show their creativity."
About 250 pieces of work are in the exhibition, including bookends and a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and can go much higher. Most of the money will go to the artists, but some will be kept by the Association to help promote good ironwork. Dawson has made an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. He says, "My style comes from letting hot steel bend into shape. It's like drawing with metal in space."
Many artists love working with iron. Unlike other metals, iron is tough and needs special care. Susan May, a jeweler, says, "It's magical because it is soft when hot, but when it cools, it becomes hard and strong." Ann Catrin Evans makes door knockers and handles that look like they belong in scary castles. One design looks like a ball and chain, and another looks like a Celtic cross. She says, "I love that steel is cold and hard, and it feels like it will last forever."
Iron has given people a lot of beauty and a sense of safety. It is likely that iron will be used for decoration for many years to come, as long as we do not have to see any more rusty candlesticks!

**The Day I Gave Up Smoking**
I thought my friends would be happy when I stopped smoking, but one of my coworkers was very angry. She said, "What do you mean? If it was easy, why didn’t you stop before?" I found it hard to explain how I went from smoking a lot every day to not smoking at all in just a few hours. 
Two months and three weeks ago, I went to a stop-smoking session. I did not plan to stop smoking, and I did not really want to. I felt pressure from people who don’t like smoking, and I still feel that way. I also had good health and did not feel sick. I thought I was healthier than some of my friends who tried to live healthier lives.
On that Thursday afternoon, I went to the session in Birmingham to write an article about people trying to quit smoking. I said, "I won’t try to stop. I am here to write, not to quit." I really enjoyed smoking. It made me happy. The counselor looked at me like she understood. 
We could smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was full of smoke. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn’t want to. The messages about stopping smoking started to make sense to me. I began to think that stopping smoking could be a good thing. I felt strong because I thought I could stop. 
It was not too hard to stop. The cravings for nicotine, which felt like hunger, went away after a few minutes. I only felt them for four or five days. I thought working without cigarettes would be hard, but it was easy. I was surprised that doing things at home on weekends was the hardest part. 
I realized that smoking helped me when I was bored. Having a cigarette was something to do. I do miss smoking a little, but not too much. Now, I have to deal with new experiences as a non-smoker, like eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, or during a break at the theater. These are moments when I used to smoke.

**Dorothy Hodgkin: A Scientist You Should Know**
Dorothy Hodgkin was a British woman scientist who won the Nobel Prize. She is not very well known in her own country, which is surprising. For the last four years, I have asked my friends if they know about her. If they do, I know they are informed. 
Dorothy Hodgkin is important because she is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize. If someone in literature won a Nobel Prize, everyone would know their name. Hodgkin, who died in 1994, was a very special person. Her life shows important changes in the 20th century, like the growth of women's education and the sharing of science around the world.
When I started to learn more about her, I wanted to read biographies of other scientists. A friend of Hodgkin suggested I read about Linus Pauling, who was also a famous scientist and a friend of hers. I went to a bookstore but found no books about Pauling. I was surprised because he was a very important chemist and won Nobel Prizes for chemistry and peace.
Many people think that biographies of scientists are boring. Peter Medawar, another Nobel Prize winner, said that the lives of scientists are often dull. If scientists think this way, it is not surprising that publishers and bookstores feel the same. 
People often see a big difference between the arts and sciences. Only a few famous scientists have biographies in bookstores. But it is not true that scientists have less interesting lives than artists or writers. Some scientists do not want to be in the public eye because they think it looks like they are trying to promote themselves. This can make young people less interested in science.
Luckily, things are changing. Scientists are now appearing more in public, not just in interviews. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins gives prizes on TV, and geneticist Steve Jones advertises cars. These activities help people see scientists as real people.
The way we write about scientists is also changing. In the past, scientific biographies were often boring and focused only on work. But now, books like Richard Feynman's "Surely You're Joking, Mr Feynman?" show scientists as interesting people with lives outside of work. 
Dorothy Hodgkin worked hard in science. She discovered the structure of penicillin and vitamin B12, which won her the Nobel Prize in chemistry in 1964. She also helped solve the structure of insulin in 1969. She was a dedicated scientist but also a mother of three children and a wife to a husband who was often away.
Her personal life is important, too. It shows how she balanced her work and family. Many people can learn from her ability to connect different parts of her life. 
Understanding science can be as challenging as reading Shakespeare or learning a new language. It just takes practice. It is sad that many educated people do not know about important scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin, even though they would feel embarrassed if they did not know famous writers or artists.

**Margaret and Her Water Finding Skills**
Margaret Wilkins is known for her special ability to find water. She can use a forked hazel stick to detect water underground. Many farmers need her help because their wells have dried up. Margaret and her husband have a well-drilling business. They use machines like drilling rigs, but Margaret only needs her hazel stick to find water. They have a success rate of over 90%.
This ability to find water is called dowsing. Some people think it is a special skill, while others believe it is based on science. One idea is that everything vibrates, and water vibrates more than other things. Some dowsers say they can feel or smell water. 
Recently, many farmers have asked for Margaret's help because of droughts. Most of her customers only need her services once because wells last a long time. Some customers have holiday homes where it is too expensive to run water pipes. Others are building golf courses.
Margaret looks for water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She must be careful to avoid any waste getting into the water. The water she finds is usually clean, but she has to be careful about minerals in the water. She also needs electricity to pump the water, so the well should be close to power sources.
To start, Margaret uses a map and a pendulum. She holds the pendulum over the map, and it swings when she is above water. After that, she walks in the fields with her hazel stick. When she is above water, she feels a strange sensation. She uses the stick to find the exact spot to drill. 
Margaret holds the stick with both hands. If water is below, the stick will rise. It is very important to drill in the right place. If she and her husband do not agree on where to drill, they will keep looking until they do.
Margaret's ability to find water is interesting to many people. She calls it an "intuitive perception of the environment." This means she has a special way of sensing her surroundings. This skill helps her family run their well-drilling business successfully year after year.

**We Changed Lives for a Day!**
Have you ever thought about living someone else's life for a day? It could be fun to try something new! We helped four people do this. Here is what happened.
**Amanda's Story**
Amanda is 23 years old and has two daughters. She swapped lives with her friend Cindy, who is 30 and works as a waitress in a busy restaurant in London. 
Amanda had never been in a place like that before. It was dark, loud, and full of people. It was very different from her hometown, and she felt nervous. Being a mother is busy, but waitressing was even harder! She had only fifteen minutes to learn how to carry drinks on a tray. The other waitresses made it look easy, but Amanda dropped the drinks on the floor. She felt embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed and said it was okay. 
When the restaurant opened at 11:30 am, there was already a line of customers. Amanda was worried about remembering the orders, but the computer helped her. After a few hours, her feet hurt, and the loud music was hard to handle. She often had to say "Pardon?" when customers spoke to her, which made her feel shy. By the end of her shift at 5 pm, she was very tired and wanted to soak her feet in hot water. One waitress told her it was a "quiet" day, and Amanda was surprised at how tiring waitressing was. She thought it would be easy, but it was not. She was happy to go back to her children because being a mother felt easier after that day!
**Cindy's Story**
Cindy is 30 years old and swapped lives with Amanda. She was nervous about being a mother for a day but also excited. She had to get Amanda's two daughters ready for the day. After dropping one daughter at school and the other at nursery, Cindy thought she would have some quiet time. But she had to clean the house and do laundry too!
After picking up the younger daughter, they went to the supermarket and then home for lunch. When the older daughter came home from school, things got wild! The girls jumped on the couch and screamed loudly. Cindy thought they would get tired, but they did not! She finally got them to bed at 8 pm, but then they kept asking for water to come downstairs and watch TV. Cindy realized that taking care of two small children was very tiring. She enjoyed the day but felt very responsible for them.
**Rosemary's Story**
Rosemary is 42 years old and runs a dairy farm. She swapped lives with Hilary, who is 30 and a teacher. 
On the farm, Rosemary usually wakes up at 5:30 am, but on this day, she could sleep until 7 am. At school, she felt nervous in front of about 400 students. She helped in a math class and a nature project. By lunchtime, she was tired but only had five minutes to eat. After lunch, she attended a meeting and helped with sports trials. She enjoyed a reading lesson and a fun French lesson, but she was very tired by the end of the day. Speaking in front of the class was hard for her. Even though teachers have more holidays, she decided she prefers farming.
**Hilary's Story**
Hilary is 30 years old and swapped lives with Rosemary. She arrived at the farm early in the morning, but Rosemary had already been working for three hours! The farm has many animals, including cows and sheep. 
Hilary spent the morning in the ice-cream shop, filling milk containers and making ice-cream. At lunchtime, she checked the sheep and helped a fallen one. She learned that if sheep are not helped quickly, they can die. After feeding the calves, she started milking, which took two and a half hours. Rosemary does this every day, twice a day! 
Hilary felt lonely because she missed being around children. She realized that farming is not as easy as it seems. The work is hard, and it is difficult to take time off. Farming can be romantic, but it is also very challenging.

A trumpet isn't just for Christmas. It is interesting that many musicians come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger is a special trumpet player from southern Sweden. He is 30 years old and is known around the world. He plays old music and new music. When you see him, he looks young and friendly, just like the sound of his trumpet. 
Recently, he played the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in a big concert hall in London. He also had a TV show about his work, filmed in London and Sweden. Hakan was born near Malmo. When he was eight years old, his father gave him a trumpet as a Christmas gift. His father liked Louis Armstrong's music, so he bought a real trumpet, not a toy. Hakan loved the trumpet and played it all the time. 
His mother found a trumpet player from the Malmo Symphony Orchestra to give him lessons. This teacher, Bo Nilsson, saw Hakan's talent right away. Hakan is thankful for having such a good teacher. Bo was very passionate about the trumpet and always wanted to learn more about it. 
Hakan explains that the trumpet is a simple instrument, and it is hard to make a perfect one. Each trumpet is a little different. He learned to accept these differences and work with them. Even as a child, people could recognize his special sound. 
Unlike another famous trumpet player, John Wallace, who played in orchestras, Hakan always wanted to be a solo artist. He admired the French trumpet player, Maurice Andre, and bought all his records. His parents supported his dream to be a trumpet player. 
When Hakan was 15, he needed to choose a place to study. His teacher wanted him to go to America, but it was too far. Instead, he went to Paris at 16 to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud told him that playing in an orchestra was not as exciting as being a soloist. 
Hakan knew he played better than many other young players. When he was 17, he entered a competition in Paris. He only prepared for the first round but made it to the second round. He knew most of the pieces for that round too. In the final round, he faced a difficult piece. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed playing and realized that people listened to him. 
Hakan is realistic about his talent. He does not want to explain how he connects with people through music because he believes it might ruin the magic. He thinks music has the power to move people.

**New In Paperback**
A. The story of Tristan Smith takes place in the made-up country of Efica. It is a special tale about power, history, and humor. The author has created a world with its own history and customs. The book is funny and shows the author's unique ideas. It is a challenging but rewarding read.
B. Harriet is a middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. She usually would not meet Sheila, a working-class woman who cares for her old father and raised her grandson, Leo. Their lives change when Leo attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys do not talk about what happened. Leo, who was a good student and never fought before, cannot explain why he did it. Joe gets better physically but becomes quiet. Harriet is very worried about her son, and taking care of him takes over her life. Sheila feels guilty and asks to meet Harriet, and this leads to an unusual friendship. The author shows how people react to big changes in their lives and how mothers feel they can never do enough for their children.
C. This book was nominated for the Booker Prize. It tells the story of a lonely Scottish island and its people over a long time. The story includes important moments in Scottish history, seen through the dreams of a young boy named Throfinn Ragnarson. He disappears for a while and comes back after the Second World War, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.
D. After his big success, the author has written a sequel with the same gentle humor about family life. Fifteen years after her daughter died, Aurora Greenway is now in her seventies and has a lively friend named Rosie Sunlap. Aurora still has her charm and kindness, and Rosie helps her with her relationships. By the end of the book, Aurora realizes that time has passed and a new generation is now important. The author skillfully shows the sadness that can be found in everyday life.
E. Six different people come together because of millionaire Logan Urquhart. He takes them on a yacht called the Ardent Spirit to sail around the South Pacific islands. The author uses beautiful language to describe how each person learns about themselves during this journey. The story shows themes of memory and awareness through surprising images that can be both strange and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**
Rebecca Cripps meets five women who talk about their jobs: the good parts, the bad parts, and what they do every day.
**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**  
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  
**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7 am, and get to work by 8 am. I start surgery at 8:30 am. I do surgery all day on Mondays and Wednesdays, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most brain surgeries take about three hours, but some can take all day. Sometimes, I work for ten hours without eating or going to the bathroom. Deciding when to do surgery can be stressful. I don’t feel stressed while I operate, but I worry about the next day. Brain surgery is usually a last option for patients, but when it works, it feels amazing. From 10 am to 1 pm, I meet with patients to explain their surgeries. I like this part of my job and find it easy to talk to them. If they are upset, I try to comfort them, but I have to be quick. I leave work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Sometimes, I have to be on call at night and on weekends. When I am on holiday, I worry about my patients and dream about surgery."
**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**  
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  
**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, and take the train to work. I arrive at 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to talk about our work and any problems. I work in a team with three senior designers, a partner, and a junior designer. Most of my work is not design; it is production. I get a brief from the client about what they want. I spend three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After that, I show my ideas to the client. If they like them, we make plans and budgets, and I hire photographers and illustrators. I also work with printers to make sure everything is done on time. I have to talk to many people, and it can be stressful. Lunch is at 1 pm for one hour. I usually eat sandwiches and work through lunch. It feels great when a client likes my designs, but it is disappointing when they do not. I get home at 7:30 pm or later."
**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  
**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at about 7 am, but sometimes I have to get up at 4:30 am for long flights. At 10:30 or 11 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. I have to be careful about my diet because I sit a lot during my job. I usually have a big breakfast and snacks during the day. People ask me for restaurant or shop recommendations, so I need to know the area well. Many jobs are booked in advance, so I can check the routes. Some passengers are rude, but most are nice. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day. I try to go to bed by 11 pm."
**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  
**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up at about 7 am, leave home at 7:30 am, and go to my first job. My assistant and I take care of gardens we designed. We work mostly in private gardens. We spend about an hour and a half at each place. At 11 am, we go to a cafe for a big breakfast. In summer, I may work until 10 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. I work from home in the office, listening to messages and returning calls. If someone wants a new garden, I meet them in the evening. We use old materials to make gardens look historic. It is very satisfying to see a garden we created bloom. I find it hard to relax in the evenings because I can hear the phone. I sleep well because my job is very physical."
**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  
**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the work site by 8:30 am. I help manage the building of bridges and a wall. I check that the workers are doing their jobs safely and correctly. I talk to the workers and solve problems. The workers start at 6 am, so I first find out what happened since I left the night before. I usually have lunch for half an hour between 2 pm and 2:30 pm, but I often eat while I work. I need to keep a good relationship with the workers, so we can work well together. I leave the site at about 6 pm and I am always on call."

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Typical Working Day**
**A. Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7:30 am. I work with customers who use our credit cards. I help to start and manage a rewards program for card users in Europe. I talk to current card users, find new ones, and work with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes planning my day and then check my emails. I have many meetings during the day, but I keep my door open for anyone who has questions. I travel to different countries in Europe once or twice a week to solve problems. I usually leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.
**B. Record Company Executive**  
I start work at 10:00 am. I check the mail, which includes demo tapes, letters, and invoices. The phone rings a lot after 10:30 am, and I have meetings to discuss projects for artists. When I listen to demo tapes, I know it is important for the artists, so I try to give good feedback. If I sign a band, we begin working on their first album. I also manage budgets and spending. I leave work by 7:00 pm and often go to concerts in the evening. Sometimes I don’t get home until 1:00 am.
**C. Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving at 9:30 am. I check the mail and my schedule for the day. I enjoy showing customers our furniture and helping them buy pieces. We sell antiques that cost between £1,000 and £6,000. I work with restorers to fix the furniture we buy. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette to stay updated on the business. I do the accounts once a month and tax returns every three months. I go home at 5:30 pm and it takes me about an hour to relax.
**D. Air Traffic Controller**  
I work in shifts. If I have an early shift, I leave home at 6:00 am. I start work at 7:00 am and take over from the night shift. I control aircraft movements with my team. In winter, we manage about 1,000 flights a day. Night shifts are quieter, and I can read about new rules. This job is stressful, and I need to be alert. I want to become a watch manager and then a general manager of the airport.
**E. Shop Manager**  
If I have an early shift, I leave home by 8:00 am. I start the electronic sales system and make sure someone is at the cash register. I help customers find and order books. I enjoy helping them, but it can be hard when they expect me to find many books quickly. From 2:00 pm to 4:00 pm, I meet with publishers to discuss new books. I need to make sure new titles arrive on time. My early shift ends at 5:45 pm. Two days a week, I work late and close the shop.
**F. Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then get up and take a taxi to work by 8:45 am. I contact reporters to learn about my area. I assess financial risks for companies working in other countries. I provide three services: a quick news update, a security forecast, and a travel security guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with editors to discuss stories. I have deadlines to meet, so I work quickly. I travel to Africa three times a year to report on events. I leave work around 6:00 pm, but I often stay awake until 1:00 am.

**Career Power: Take Control at Work**
A. **What Makes a Good Leader?**  
A good leader inspires others and helps them grow. Leadership is not about being tall or very smart. Pat Dixon, who wrote a book about men and women at work, says that leadership is about making things happen with people who are excited and interested. A good leader should speak clearly and confidently. It is important to say "I believe" instead of "I think."
B. John van Maurik, who teaches a Leadership in Management course, says that many people can be great leaders if they recognize their talents and develop them. We all have the potential to be leaders; we just need the right situation to grow. It is easy to see leadership in famous people like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, but it can be harder to see it in our own jobs. However, being a good leader is very important for good management.
C. Think about the best and worst boss you have had. They might have been good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they achieve these goals? The best leader motivated you and supported you. The worst leader made you feel unimportant and blamed you when things went wrong. The first leader was very good; the second leader was very bad.
D. Leaders and managers are different. Managers like to work within set rules. Leaders create new ideas. Micheal Shea, who wrote about leadership, says a good manager can keep a company running, but a good leader can change a sad organization into a happy one.
E. Whether you are the boss or a middle manager, you can improve your leadership skills. Here are some tips:  
- Leadership works best when you choose to lead. Find what you are passionate about and act on it.  
- Start thinking of yourself as a leader. You have the power to lead.  
- Sometimes you need to be a strong leader. Try different styles. If you usually ask others for their opinions, try taking the lead instead. See how this changes things.  
- Set goals and try to achieve them. Look at your job and see where being a leader can help you do better.
F. Leadership does not just happen. You need to take the lead, take risks, and learn from mistakes. Learn to delegate tasks, motivate others, and give praise.  
- Don’t think your way of leading will always be liked. Keep working on how you communicate. You don’t have to be liked, but your ideas should be respected.  
- Be visible and available to important people.  
- Remember, you don’t have to lead all the time. Know when your help is needed and how you can help others become leaders too.

**Films on Video: Reviews by Nick James**
**A. Abyss**  
Before Titanic, director James Cameron made a tense movie about oil workers and navy experts trying to save a nuclear submarine deep underwater. The main character, Bud, and his team remind us of tough heroes in older movies. The special effects and set design are very good, but the dialogue and characters are not as strong. The story feels like a simple B-movie.
**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This movie is based on a book about the battle for Guadalcanal. It is directed by Andrew Marton and is different from Terrence Malick's version. Marton’s film is more traditional and focuses on one soldier and his tough sergeant. Malick’s film is richer and more complex, but Marton’s version has some good moments, like a scene where the soldier dreams of his wife.
**C. On Guard**  
This fun movie is based on a novel from 1875. It is better than many other musketeer films. The villain, played by Fabrice Luchini, is a sneaky politician causing trouble. Vincent Perez is a lively hero, and Daniel Auteuil plays a moody character who is also a swordsman. The film has many clichés, but it is entertaining.
**D. Character**  
This serious film is set in Rotterdam at the start of the 20th century. The detailed costumes and sets make it look like a museum. Jan Decleir plays a harsh bailiff named Dreverhaven, who is cruel to his tenants. His difficult relationship with his son is the main story, but the film focuses too much on the details and not enough on the dark story.
**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This re-released film shows the skill of director Leone. The sound is very clear, making every step and noise stand out. The story is harsh, and when it slows down, Morricone's great music brings excitement. The characters, the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Ell Wallach), all act in selfish ways in the post-Civil War West.
**F. The Longest Day**  
This war movie features many international stars and has four directors and 23,000 extras. The early parts of the film, where soldiers wait for news about an invasion, feel slow. While it is impressive in scale, it is better to watch on a big screen. Watching it on video does not give the same experience.

**BOOK A** Steve Martin's *Compelling Evidence* is a very interesting story. The main character is a lawyer who has to start a new job after leaving a big law firm. He ends up defending his boss's wife when she is accused of killing her husband. The trial scenes are exciting, and the ending has a surprising twist. This is a great first book in a popular genre.
**BOOK B** *Curtains for the Cardinal* starts with a lot of action. The main character, Sigismondo, helps rich people in Italy during the Renaissance. He gets involved in politics and a murder case, but we believe he will find out who is guilty. The story is complicated and a bit long, but it is still very enjoyable.
**BOOK C** *File Under: Deceased* introduces a new detective named Leah Hunter, who is a tax inspector. She starts investigating when a strange man dies in front of her. Even though she faces problems and the local detective does not support her, Leah is brave and smart. She is a great character.
**BOOK D** *Double Deuce* by Robert B. Parker features Spenser, a private investigator. He helps his friend Hawk get rid of drug dealers in a poor area of Boston. The dialogue is quick and clever, and there is more thinking than usual. It is always good entertainment from Parker.
**BOOK E** *False Prophet* by Faye Kellermann has detectives Pete Decker and Marge Dunn looking into a robbery at the home of a famous actress's daughter. The author's easy writing style and focus on strange human behavior make this a fun mystery.
**BOOK F** *Blood Red, Snow White* is written by husband and wife team Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock. It features another lawyer and a female client, but most of the action happens outside the courtroom. The lawyer becomes a victim as the story unfolds. It has romance, money, and violence, making it a gripping suspense novel.
**BOOK G** *Dead for a Ducat* by Simon Shaw shows actor Philip Fletcher in a new role as a target. A funny group of characters comes together to film a Robin Hood story, but Philip feels this is not the right direction for his career. Simon Shaw usually entertains well, but this time the story is not as strong.
**BOOK H** *Fall Down Easy* is Lawrence Gough's best book in a while. Canadian police are looking for a clever bank robber who targets female bank tellers. The story builds tension slowly and shows the smart but troubled robber, making it better than an average detective novel.

I might be too old for this, but here I go! Tim Pozzi is 34 years old. He has left his good job to go backpacking. He thinks about why he and others his age want to travel. This summer, he quit his job, rented out his flat, and plans to travel in South East Asia for a year. Some people might think he is lucky, but he feels nervous. He has traveled before. After university, he spent two years backpacking in North and South America. When he came back, he wanted to travel again, but then he fell in love, started a career, and got used to earning money. 
Tim realized he was giving up his happiness for his job. When he quit, he felt like he was in control of his life again. Many of his friends are now married with children. They do not want to change places with him, but they envy his freedom. Tim is not in a relationship and does not have big career goals. He feels he should enjoy his freedom, especially for his friends.
But why is he so nervous? First, he has to make plans. He worries about someone else living in his home and how to rent it out. He also needs to decide where to go. He is a big procrastinator and is already behind on his plans. He thought about enjoying the summer in England and waiting for the football season to start. 
Tim is also worried about leaving his comfortable life. He wonders if he can still handle backpacking. Will he fit in with younger backpackers? Many people in their late twenties and thirties in Britain want to leave their normal lives and travel. Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says more people are realizing they can have adventures if they are brave and organized.
Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, see this trip as a last chance before settling down. They bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. Danny says he is ready to give up job security for this trip. He knows he might return to the same job position, but he thinks it is a risk worth taking. 
For Matt, who just left the Army, traveling helped him change his life. He needed to break away from the strict way of doing things in the military. There are many reasons for people to travel at this age. Angela Baron from the Institute of Personnel Development says more people work on short-term contracts, so if a contract ends, they have nothing to lose. Some big companies even allow career breaks.
Dan Hiscocks, who runs a company about travelers, says many people in their thirties are thinking about their lives. If they are not happy, they know they can change things. Travel gives them a chance to think about what they want. 
Is wanting to travel just a sign that my generation cannot handle being adults? Jennifer Cox does not think so. She believes it shows we are better educated and want a balanced life. We are asking ourselves, "Is this what I want?" Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher, is going to Central America for a year. He does not think he is running away; he is running towards something he wants. But he feels nervous about leaving his comfortable routine.
I understand Ben's worries about leaving a stable life. I might not be going on this journey if I had not found my boss so difficult. Jennifer Cox says this is common. Sometimes a big change, like a breakup or losing a job, pushes people to travel. 
Even though it took a push for me to start, I am excited about the next 12 months. No matter what happens, I will feel good about taking this chance. I believe many older backpackers feel the same way.

**Plugging in the Home**
Georgina McGuiness took a long break from her job as a journalist. She felt lost because of new technology. In this story, she explains how she changed her home into a good place to work.
The Christmas before last, I turned 37. I realized I needed to get back to my journalism career. I felt like my skills were old-fashioned, stuck in the 1980s. Back then, we used typewriters, and I didn’t know how to use a computer. Many job ads asked for skills in desktop publishing, which I didn’t have. I thought it would be easier to host a seminar on nuclear physics than to use a computer for work. I was scared of technology; even calculators confused me, and I didn’t know how to use the timer on the video.
I knew I had to change quickly. I thought leaving home before my kids would be hard. But then, I entered a contest in a local newspaper and won a computer package! We got a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for the family. We jumped into this new world of the Internet and started chatting with people from around the world. My kids stopped watching TV, and I set up a small office in the kitchen with a phone, a fax machine, a CD-ROM, and a modem to connect to the Internet. I had everything I needed to work from home and still take my kids to school.
My children were good with computers because they learned at school. I was nervous and thought I would lose my work if I pressed the wrong button. But I was wrong! I learned the basic skills I needed. It was logical and easy. With practice, I learned more every day. Now, I write articles for a magazine, about two each month. I feel proud that I can balance work and family.
How has the computer helped me? In school, my desk was always messy, and I lost important papers. Now, the computer helps me stay organized. I can keep track of money and create invoices easily. As a journalist, I can research stories online and talk to other writers from around the world.
But working from home has some downsides. I can feel lonely without seeing people. There are also distractions at home, like chores, and my kids sometimes argue about who gets to use the computer.
Many people in my neighborhood have bought computers, not just for learning but also for fun. More people are working from home instead of commuting to the city every day.
A report called "PC Usage in UK Homes" says that most home computer users are 38 years old and well-educated. Most own a personal computer, and many have printers and modems. I feel like I am doing well with my computer skills. One day, I might even send an article to a newspaper in Melbourne or start my own magazine from home. The possibilities seem endless!

**The Tartan Museum**
The Tartan Museum is in Edinburgh, Scotland. It has modern buildings that look very different from the old city around it. Sally Varlow visited the museum before it opened.
You cannot miss the museum. It is on the corner of Chambers Street. The building has a big yellow tower and unique shapes. Some people think it is beautiful, while others do not like it at all. 
Now, the inside of the museum is almost ready. The exhibitions will tell many stories about Scotland. There are important objects, like jewels from Mary Queen of Scots. The museum wants to show these treasures without too much national pride. 
Dr. David Clarke is in charge of the exhibitions. He wants the museum to be fun and easy to understand for everyone, not just experts. He believes that the museum should show the truth about the past. 
Visitors will see explanations and pictures to tell the stories of the objects. There are also computers to help. But it is still unclear if this will be enough to keep people interested.
When you enter the museum, you will notice the different spaces. The galleries connect to each other, and the walls look like big stone blocks. Light comes in from the windows and the roof, making it bright inside. There is space to enjoy each item on display.
There is also a Discovery Centre for children, thanks to a group of kids aged 9 to 12 from all over Scotland. They wanted to ride through the displays, but instead, they got a special area for hands-on activities.
On the top floor, there is a gallery about the 20th century. It will change every three years and shows items chosen by Scottish people. Some suggested things like electric guitars, televisions, and toys. 
Dr. Clarke believes that objects can tell stories about the past better than anything else. The museum's modern design is impressive inside, but some wonder if it is in the right place.

**The Future of Newspapers**
The change from print newspapers to online news is happening slowly. Some people are scared of this change, while others find it challenging. Transition means moving from the present to the future. But the change for newspapers to go online is not easy. Many people think it will happen eventually because print newspaper sales are going down, but visits to their websites are going up.
For example, newspapers like The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have seen their print sales drop by 8% to 10% each year. However, their websites are getting more visitors. This is true, but it depends on many factors like time and location. 
A recent survey showed that worldwide newspaper sales actually went up by 1.1% last year, reaching 512 million copies a day. While sales in Western countries went down, sales in Asia increased. News magazines also saw a 5.4% rise in sales. So, while some areas of magazines are struggling, many are growing quickly.
E-books are also becoming very popular, with sales increasing a lot this year. But when bookstores looked at the sales of physical books, they found that sales were only down by 0.4%. This shows that people are buying both e-books and physical books.
Many people think young people are not reading newspapers anymore, but this is not true. The latest survey shows that nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 still read the main newspapers. Different countries have different trends. In Britain, print sales have dropped by 10.8%, but in Germany, the drop is only 7%, and in France, it is just 3.1%.
In the past, experts thought that online advertising would help newspapers succeed. But now, online ads are actually going down. Many US newspapers have started charging for online access. The best way to get readers to pay seems to be offering both print and online access together. 
Print newspapers are still important for selling online subscriptions. They make much more money from print ads than from online ads. However, it is hard and expensive for newspapers to keep both print and online versions. But print newspapers still have a strong presence, while it is harder to get noticed online.

**Photographing People**
People are very interesting to photograph. A photo with a person is usually more exciting than one without. However, taking good photos of people can be hard. The photographer must pay attention to how people move, their gestures, and their expressions. Sometimes, just having a camera can make people act differently.
**A. Grouping People**  
When taking pictures of groups, avoid straight lines. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances. You can have some people sitting or kneeling in front so you can see all their faces.
**B. Posing for Pictures**  
People often feel stiff in front of a camera. Help them relax by suggesting comfortable positions, like folding their hands or putting them in their pockets.
**C. The Right Approach**  
Do not pretend you are not taking a picture when it is clear you are. This can make people feel tense. Most people will agree to have their picture taken, but they might feel shy. You may need to guide them. A picture can be less interesting if the person looks away.
**D. Eye Contact**  
A photo looks better if the person is looking at the camera. Ask them to look into the lens. They do not have to smile. If they seem distracted, remind them just before you take the picture. You can also say something funny to get a real reaction.
**E. Candid Concentration**  
Instead of looking directly at the camera, the person can focus on something else in the picture. This can make the photo feel more natural. Candid shots can be very interesting, and the person's expression is important.
**F. Expressions and Gestures**  
Expressions and gestures tell us a lot about a person. A laughing child can make us smile, while a sad face can make us feel sad. Look for common expressions like smiles, frowns, or thumbs-up. They are a quick way to show feelings.
**G. Situation Interest**  
While close-up shots of a person are powerful, the background can add more interest. Make sure the background does not distract from the person. A wide-angle lens can help make the person look bigger compared to the background.
**H. Interaction**  
Good pictures often happen when people are interacting, like talking or laughing together. Couples, mothers with babies, and teams can make great photos. Look for moments of connection, like eye contact or a handshake.
**I. People and Places**  
Many photos of people are taken on trips. To show people with a nice background, step back to include the whole scene. Ask people to stand close to the camera while keeping the background visible. A higher camera position can help with this. A good photo shows both the people and the place equally.
**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**  
Decide why you want to take the picture. If you want to remember someone you met on holiday, ask them to pose in front of a nice background. Family photos can be boring if they are all posed. Candid photos of events are often more lively and can bring back memories better than posed pictures.

**Under Sarah's Spell**
Sarah Janson is an artist who creates trompe-l'oeil paintings. These paintings look real but are actually tricks for the eyes. Joanna Watt interviews her.
Not many artists do not sign their work unless someone asks them to. Sarah Janson is one of these artists. She does not think the artist is important; she believes the work is what matters. She says, "It's not the artist who is important, but the work." Sarah is very humble and makes it seem like her paintings create themselves. This makes the interview a bit difficult. She says, "I just don't like to shout about myself," and she looks scared when asked to take a photo.
After 30 minutes, Sarah feels more comfortable. The interview becomes interesting and funny. Sarah has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. She studied drawing for two years at art school, got a degree in graphic illustration, and worked at a publishing house. But she was not happy with illustration. She started working with a decorator named Jim Smart, who asked her to create one trompe-l'oeil painting. After that, she knew this was her path. She left to work on her own, not knowing exactly what would happen, but feeling it was the right choice.
Sarah's skills in observing details helped her become a good trompe-l'oeil artist. She says, "People often ask me where they can learn trompe-l'oeil. But no one can teach you. Trompe-l'oeil is the school of life. It's all about observation." She believes she is still learning. She is honest about her weaknesses, saying, "I can't paint bread; it always looks like grey concrete." She also struggles with math. When she had a big job to paint a ceiling, she got confused with the measurements and thought, "You're not Michelangelo. Who do you think you are?"
Sarah often talks about herself in the third person. After finishing a big project, she thinks, "Well, I didn't do it, she did." Her trompe-l'oeil paintings are very special and different from others. She has many important clients. Most of her work is inspired by buildings. For example, she created a trompe-l'oeil dining room that looks like a beautiful Venetian building.
With trompe-l'oeil art, there is a risk that once people understand the trick, they lose interest. Sarah knows this and says, "Trompe-l'oeil has to do two things. First, it must draw you in; it's got to trick you. Secondly, it has to hold you and engage your imagination." She believes that trompe-l'oeil art should also be personal for the client. She enjoys working with clients because that is where the best ideas come from. Some clients know exactly what they want, while others do not. She listens to them and tries to understand their ideas.
Many of her clients become friends because she spends a lot of time with them while working. Sarah is thankful for her clients, saying, "I am very grateful for the mad ones who have let me loose on their walls." They are happy with her work, which is why she is always busy. Even though she does not like to talk about her talent, she says, "I really don't like to shout about myself. Like my work, I am very restrained. I don't want it to shout."
It is true that Sarah does not want to be loud, but her work is very special and deserves more attention.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**
Daniel Goleman talks about the important "people skills" needed to succeed in our jobs.
A. The rules for work are changing. We are not only judged by how smart we are or how well we were trained. Now, we are also judged by how we manage ourselves and how we get along with others. This new way of judging is used to decide who gets hired and who does not. It helps to show who will do very well at their job and who may not do as well. These new rules are important for our future jobs. They are different from what we learned in school. Doing well on tests is not as important anymore. Now, it is more about social skills and personal qualities, like being proactive, understanding others, being flexible, and convincing people. These skills are called emotional intelligence.
B. Today, many jobs do not offer security, and we need to have skills that we can use in different jobs. Personal qualities are becoming very important at work. For a long time, people have talked about these qualities using different names, like "character" or "soft skills." Now, we call them emotional intelligence. This means being able to understand and manage our own feelings and the feelings of others. In our work, emotional intelligence includes being aware of ourselves, controlling our emotions, being motivated, understanding others, and having good social skills. Some people think emotional intelligence just means being nice, but it can also mean being honest, even when it is hard. It is not about showing all our feelings but managing them so we can work well together.
C. More businesses are realizing that emotional intelligence is very important for good management. The more complicated a job is, the more emotional intelligence matters. If someone lacks these skills, it can make it hard for them to use their knowledge and skills. Many people have succeeded despite having low emotional intelligence, but as work becomes more complex and requires teamwork, companies that work well together have an advantage. In today’s workplace, where teamwork and good customer service are important, emotional intelligence is essential for doing well in any job.
D. Unlike IQ, which does not change much, emotional intelligence can grow as we live and learn. Studies show that most people get better at managing their emotions and understanding others over time. This growth in emotional intelligence is called maturity. We can learn these skills and use them to help us in our jobs, especially now when jobs are less stable. Emotional intelligence is not a magic solution for companies that are not doing well, and it does not guarantee success. But if we ignore the human side of work, nothing else will work as well.

'Should the media make money from content they do not own? Digital cameras and camera phones make it easy to take pictures of news events. Social media has changed how people share these photos. Now, some journalists use social media to find images of fast-moving events. But some reporters have used pictures from users without asking for permission. There are rules that say images on social media can be used without permission in special cases or if there is strong public interest. However, people still argue about whether this is right. Research shows that about one in ten people would take pictures or videos of a news event. This means user-generated content (UGC) is important for the future of the media. To keep a good relationship with the public, the media should make sure that people are paid for their work and that they always ask for permission.'

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West**
Acupuncture is a type of treatment that is over two thousand years old. It comes from traditional Chinese medicine, which also includes using herbs, massage, diet, and exercise. Acupuncture is often used to help with pain, and many doctors in the West use it for this purpose.
**What is Traditional Chinese Medicine?**
In traditional Chinese medicine, health means that the mind, body, and spirit are in balance. There is a special energy called Qi (pronounced "chee") that flows through the body along paths called meridians. There are twelve main meridians, each connected to an organ. If the flow of Qi is blocked or weak, a person may feel weak or sick. 
When you visit an acupuncturist, they will check your pulse, look at your tongue, and ask about your health, feelings, and habits. They use very thin needles to help the flow of Qi. Sometimes, they also use heat from herbs or apply pressure to certain points.
**Acupuncture Points**
The points where acupuncturists place needles are connected to the meridians and may not be near the area that hurts. People often feel a mild ache or tingling when the needle is moved. This shows that the needle is working with the Qi. There are over three hundred acupuncture points on the main meridians.
**How Does Acupuncture Work?**
Even though Western doctors do not fully accept traditional Chinese medicine, many believe acupuncture can help with pain. They think it might work by blocking pain signals or by releasing natural pain-relieving chemicals in the body.
**What Pain Can Acupuncture Help?**
Many people with long-term pain try acupuncture when other treatments do not work. It can help with back pain, arthritis, headaches, and pain after surgery. Acupuncturists also say it can help with menstrual pain and pain in terminally ill patients.
**Modern Use of Acupuncture**
Acupuncture has been used in China for over 2,000 years, but using it instead of anesthesia during surgery started in the 1950s. This helped some doctors outside China see that acupuncture is more than just a mental trick. In China today, acupuncture is used in many surgeries, and it can help reduce pain without the side effects of regular anesthesia.
**Effectiveness of Acupuncture**
Research shows that 50 to 80 percent of people find acupuncture helpful for chronic pain. Acupuncturists say it usually takes six to seven visits to feel real relief, but some people may feel better after just two or three visits.
**A Different Way to Treat Pain**
Acupuncturists look at the whole person, not just the pain. They spend time understanding the pain and what might be causing it. They ask questions about how the pain feels and what makes it worse. This is different from how many regular doctors treat pain.
**Choosing an Acupuncturist**
Some doctors have training in traditional acupuncture, while others use scientific methods. Traditional acupuncturists believe that using their methods can lead to better healing. It is important to choose a good acupuncturist, and they should refer you to a doctor if needed.

P.D. James is a famous crime writer. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James. She seems very confident, but she is actually shy. She has created a detective named Adam Dalgliesh, who is a bit like her. Dalgliesh likes to solve crimes alone, just like P.D. James prefers to write alone. She needs quiet time to write and feels she can write anywhere if she has privacy.
Many people read her books, and she is considered one of the best crime writers in Britain. She enjoys reading books by other women writers, but she also likes some male authors. P.D. James became successful later in life. She was 42 when her first book, Cover Her Face, was published. 
She was born in Oxford and grew up in Cambridge. She met her husband there, who was a student. Life was not easy for her. Her husband became very sick after the Second World War, and she had to work hard to support him and their two daughters, Clare and Jane. Her husband’s parents helped take care of the girls during this tough time.
P.D. James worked for the National Health Service and later for the Home Office. She learned a lot about crime while working there. She liked writing detective stories because it allowed her to create order from chaos. She believes that solving a crime in a story shows the importance of life, even if the characters are not very nice. She has always loved reading detective stories and wanted to be a writer.

**The Pen is Mightier than the Psychoanalyst**
The study of handwriting to understand a person's character is becoming more popular. In some countries, if you apply for a job, you will likely be asked to give a sample of your handwriting. This handwriting can help decide if you are right for the job. Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is seen as a real science in many places. 
Researchers say handwriting analysis can help show certain health problems, like heart disease and cancer. It can also show emotional issues. More companies are using handwriting analysis to help with job interviews. Many big companies hire graphologists to look at the handwriting of people who want important jobs. However, many doctors and psychiatrists are not sure if graphology is useful.
Patricia Marne is a professional graphologist with over 20 years of experience. She thinks doctors should take handwriting analysis seriously. She believes handwriting can show psychological traits and some health conditions. She says, "Handwriting can show social class and intelligence. It can also help decide if someone should focus on arts or sciences and if they are honest or tricky."
According to Ms. Marne, handwriting can help find possible criminal behavior. She says, "Criminals often have messy handwriting. Many come from difficult backgrounds and have emotional problems. This can show in childish handwriting or in writing letters many times." 
Ms. Marne can tell if people are honest or if they might manipulate others. She says young male offenders often have tall letters, which means they dream big. Graphologists can see if someone is under a lot of stress or if they might hurt others. Handwriting can even help predict if someone might think about suicide. 
She also says heart and lung problems can show in handwriting. "You cannot make a diagnosis from one sample unless the writing is very shaky. But if the handwriting changes over time, it could mean something serious is happening," she explains. A big emotional upset can also change a person's signature for a short time.
Ms. Marne says handwriting can show other psychological traits. For example, people who write with letters that connect are often clever and tricky. Those who write mostly in capital letters may be hiding their true selves. Light pressure in writing shows sensitivity. Original handwriting shows confidence and creativity. Disconnected writing means the person may be a loner. Small signatures can show shyness, while circles over the letter "i" can mean someone wants attention.
Ms. Marne believes it takes six years of study to analyze handwriting well. She thinks more research is needed to make graphology a real science. She believes it is more accurate than psychoanalysis because it can show a person's history and emotional problems without asking questions.
However, many psychiatrists do not agree with her. They say handwriting is just a result of education and the way people are taught to write, and it does not mean anything else.

**Is Your Office Working Well?**
Fresh air and good chairs are important for a happy and healthy workplace, according to a new survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they are. We had three experts with us: a building health consultant, an ergonomist (who studies working conditions), and an occupational psychologist. Here are their opinions.
**Office A: Advertising Agency**
- **Building Health Consultant:** This office is very simple. It has no central heating and no mechanical ventilation. The windows open to the street. It is surprising that this office works well, but the small team of seven people seems happy. They change the office temperature by opening doors or using electric heaters, just like at home. This may be why they feel comfortable.
  
- **Ergonomist:** The furniture does not match, and some chairs are old and broken. This can cause bad posture. However, the workers have different tasks, like meeting clients and making presentations. This variety helps them avoid tiredness and boredom.
- **Occupational Psychologist:** The staff enjoys the different types of work and the size of the office. It is small enough to know what others are doing but big enough to work alone. The office looks nice and is fun.
**Office B: News Service**
- **Building Health Consultant:** This office is not very exciting, but it is comfortable. The air quality is good, and there is a No Smoking policy.
- **Ergonomist:** The company has good chairs and lighting. The space is okay, but the layout could be better. The office feels impersonal with plain grey walls.
- **Occupational Psychologist:** The walls are mostly bare, except for some planners and a poster. Most staff have worked there for over five years, and they get along well. The office could be better if desks were arranged to share information easily.
**Office C: Bank**
- **Building Health Consultant:** This office gets mixed feelings from workers. It feels like being in a glass box. The air is not stale, even with smokers nearby.
- **Ergonomist:** The office is standard and not very inspiring. The desks are okay, but some chairs are not good for computer work. The computer screens are not set up well.
- **Occupational Psychologist:** The staff helps each other and uses technology well. There are many awards on display. The office is busy, but the colors make it feel a bit dull.
**Office D: Newspaper**
- **Building Health Consultant:** This office has many problems. The air conditioning does not work well, and the temperature changes a lot. The space is messy, and there is not enough desk space. It is also very dusty.
- **Ergonomist:** The furniture is not suitable for a modern office. Many chairs are old and do not help workers, especially shorter people.
- **Occupational Psychologist:** The office is dirty, with old chairs and carpets. It needs cleaning and better air conditioning. There were not many conversations when we visited; everyone seemed stressed. The company should encourage teamwork.

**Chewing Gum Culture**
Chewing gum is popular and many Americans chew 12 million sticks of it every day. It is a big business that started from an old custom. Each stick of chewing gum has less than ten calories, but it is considered food and must follow rules from the American Food and Drug Administration.
Today, most chewing gum is made with synthetic materials. These include pine resins and softeners that help keep the flavor and make the gum feel better. Long ago, the ancient Greeks chewed a gum-like substance from the mastic tree, which grows in Greece and Turkey. Women in Greece used mastic gum to clean their teeth and make their breath smell nice.
American colonists learned to chew gum from the Native Americans in New England. They chewed resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, people in the eastern United States sold spruce gum, which was the first commercial chewing gum in the country.
Modern chewing gum started in the late 1860s when people discovered chicle. Chicle is a milky substance from the sapodilla tree found in Central America. Gum made from chicle was smoother and more enjoyable to chew, leading to a big industry. However, it is hard to grow sapodilla trees, so many gum makers now use synthetic materials.
Today, the few people who collect chicle, called chicleros, have a tough life. They walk for miles in very humid conditions to tap the sapodilla trees. There are dangers like poisonous snakes and insects. One insect, the chicle fly, lays eggs in the ears and nose of the collectors. Chicleros climb trees to collect the sap, which they carry back to a camp. There, they boil the sap until it becomes sticky and forms bricks.
Life in the camp is not easy. The workers eat a simple diet of maize and drink local alcohol made from sugar cane. Even though their work is hard, chicleros worry about losing their jobs. Not long ago, the United States imported 7,000 tonnes of chicle each year from Central America. Last year, only 200 tonnes were collected in Mexico.
As chewing gum sales have increased, manufacturers have turned to synthetic materials to save money. Gum makers also find clever ways to sell their products. They say chewing gum can help you relax, give you energy, and reduce stress. During the world wars, soldiers were often given gum. One of the biggest claims is that chewing gum helps reduce tooth decay. When we eat, plaque acid forms, but chewing gum can help increase saliva, which protects our teeth.
Research is ongoing to create new textures and flavors for gum. Glycerine and vegetable oils are now used to make the gum base. Most new flavors are artificial, but some still use natural ingredients. In America, a large area is used to grow mint for the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

**REMOTE HOTELS**
A. **INDIA - GHANERAO HOTEL, RAJASTHAN**  
Ghanerao Hotel is in a small village near the Aravalli Hills. The village is known for its craftsmen. The hotel combines English country style with Indian culture. The Ghanerao family has lived here for 400 years. Now, Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests. The hotel has basic facilities, like hot water from a bucket, but this makes it special.
B. **NEW ZEALAND - HERMITAGE HOTEL, MOUNT COOK**  
The Hermitage Hotel is on New Zealand's South Island. I found it by chance while climbing. After climbing a glacier, I was surprised to see this hotel in a beautiful, wild area. It was luxurious, and there was a man playing piano music. It was an amazing experience after a long climb.
C. **MAURITIUS - PARADIS HOTEL**  
The Paradis Hotel is on a quiet peninsula in Mauritius. The road to the hotel goes along empty beaches where only fishermen are found. The hotel is big and offers free water sports, but you can find peace on the nine-kilometer private beach. If you swim a little, you can hardly see the hotel because of the palm trees. In the evening, when everyone leaves, it feels very calm and far away from everything.
D. **ST LUCIA - LADERA HOTEL**  
Ladera Hotel in St Lucia has a stunning view. It is quiet and high up, with open rooms looking at the Caribbean Sea between two mountains called the Pitons. The hotel has a colonial style with wooden furniture and four-poster beds.
E. **TURKEY - THE SPLENDID HOTEL, ISTANBUL**  
The Splendid Hotel is on Buyukada, one of the Princes Islands. It is a great place to escape the noise of Istanbul. The islands are only an hour away by boat. There are no cars, just horse-drawn carriages. The hotel is an old wooden building painted white with red domes. It is a bit old now, but still charming.
F. **FRANCE - CHATEAU D'ETOGES, EPERNAY**  
In the small village of Etoges, there is a beautiful old chateau from the seventeenth century. It has a moat with swans and 20 unique rooms, some with four-poster beds. There are special weekend deals for two nights that include breakfast, dinner, and champagne.
G. **KENYA - THE FAIRVIEW HOTEL, NAIROBI**  
The Fairview Hotel is a comfortable place in Nairobi, Africa. It is popular with travelers who are resting after a safari. Many guests decide to stay longer because of the beautiful gardens and good food. The hotel is on Nairobi Hill, away from the busy city. It is a great place to enjoy the sunset while having a drink and a nice dinner.
H. **ITALY - HOTEL SPLENDIDO, PORTOFINO**  
Hotel Splendido has welcomed many famous people, like the Duke of Windsor and movie stars. It used to be a monastery and is now a lovely hotel. It is still very nice, with simple but delicious food and beautiful rugs.

**Text:**
Sue Brown is a hotel inspector. She checks hotels for her job. Christopher Middleton watched her work. One minute into her inspection of the Globe Hotel, things are already going wrong. The receptionist is talking on the phone and does not notice Sue and Christopher. Sue whispers, "She hasn’t even seen us. Very poor." This is a common mistake that Sue has seen many times in her 11 years as an inspector. 
Sue says, "This hotel has three red stars, so I expect better." The red stars mean the Globe Hotel is one of the best hotels in the guide that Sue works for. But even before they enter, things feel cold. The entrance from the car park is through a door with a buzzer, and the hallway is long and empty. Sue says, "This is not what I expected."
Things get worse when the receptionist says, "We have no record of your booking." There are 15 rooms in the hotel, but only 3 are occupied. One room is on the top floor, but Sue does not like it. It is stuffy, and there is a big hole in the wall behind the wardrobe. 
When Sue started her job, people called her "The Woman in Black," but she never wore black and did not think she was tough. The next morning, after paying her bill, she tells the hotel manager, Robin Greaves, who looks scared. He quickly apologizes for a bad smell in the lounge. He says, "We think there is a blocked drain." 
Sue suggests that he should not let guests go into the room with the smell. She says, "Maybe guide them to the other lounge." Robin nods and takes notes. He has only worked at the Globe for five months and finds it hard to believe Sue when she says her comments will help the hotel in the future.
Not everything is bad. Sue praises Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the young waitress, for their good work. Dinner was also good enough to keep the hotel’s two-rosette food rating. Robin asks, "What do we need to do to get three rosettes?" Sue replies, "Don’t serve a pudding that falls apart." 
Sue’s job is to say what many customers do not want to say. She remembers a time when a woman complained that Sue got her son fired. Sue explained that the son served her apple pie with his fingers. Sometimes, people write angry letters about her reports. Sue says, "You get used to it, but it still hurts."
Sue must tell the hotel what she finds and also write a full report. The hotels pay for her help. It is worth it for them to have red stars. Robin is happy to hear that Sue will not recommend taking away the Globe's red stars. The bad news is that another inspector will come back in two months to check if the problems are fixed. Robin smiles but looks worried. "We’ll look forward to that," he says.

**Climbing the Seven Summits**
Doug Scott is a mountaineer who writes about his experiences climbing the highest mountains on each continent, called the Seven Summits. He started this journey later in life and will tell us about each mountain in the order he climbed them.
**A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**  
Doug and his climbing partner, Dougal Haston, were in a snow cave below the top of Mt. Everest. They talked about sleeping bags, which Doug thought was strange because they were alone. He started talking to his feet because they were cold. Doug remembered other climbers who lost fingers and toes to frostbite. They were not just worried about surviving but also about how well they could survive. Over the next two days, Doug thought about their time on the mountain. He felt calm and believed they would succeed. He focused on climbing better to reach the top.
**B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**  
This mountain is known to be very dangerous. In April 1976, Doug and Dougal arrived at the Kahiltna Glacier and spent four days carrying equipment and food. After the first day, they realized how hard their climb would be. They followed a route from 1967 but then chose a new path to the summit. They carried everything on their backs. They camped under a rocky cliff, and by the third day, Doug's sleeping bag was wet. They spent a night on a windy ridge and felt very tired. The air was thin, making it hard to breathe. Finally, they reached the summit and felt proud.
**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**  
In September 1976, Doug and his friend Paul Braithwaite flew to Nairobi to climb Mt. Kenya. Instead, they got a free ride to Kilimanjaro, Africa's highest mountain. They got lost in the jungle and had trouble finding water. On the second day, they found arrows on trees that led them to a rock pool. Doug was happy to find anything on the mountain. They tried to climb a steep wall but decided to take a safer route to the top.
**D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**  
In January 1992, Doug and his wife, Sharu, arrived at Aconcagua. They met a guide named Phil who invited them to join his group. After waiting for bad weather to pass, they started climbing. The Polish Glacier was icy and windy. They decided to take a different route to avoid the glacier. They walked with many other climbers to the summit. The wind was strong, and they camped outside as it got dark. At base camp, they met a group planning to climb the Seven Summits. They encouraged Doug to do the same.
**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**  
Doug learned that climbing Vinson Massif was possible if he guided enough people to pay for the trip. In November 1992, his team left for the South Pole. The sun was always shining, and it was very quiet. On December 7, they started climbing to the summit. Despite strong winds and very cold temperatures, they all reached the top in eight hours. However, they could not see much because of a storm.
**F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**  
In the summer of 1994, Doug's team met in St Petersburg. They went to Elbrus and had to pay a fee to their guide. After a few days of getting used to the altitude, they took a cable car up the mountain. They walked to a refuge and then climbed in strong winds. They thought they reached the top but found there was more to climb. They returned to the refuge and then went down the volcano.
**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**  
On their trip to Carstensz, Doug and his team wanted to climb the mountain and spend time with the local Dani people. They were warned about possible dangers, but they continued their journey. On May 12, they started climbing. The weather got better, and two team members went ahead. Doug and another member climbed slowly because they were filming. They reached the summit by 11 am, and Doug received a warm welcome for completing his seventh summit. Mission accomplished!

**Style Merchants**
