Style is important in our lives today. It affects our clothes, home decoration, and accessories. Jo Foley shares some fashion trends for this year.
**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**  
Ned Ingham makes beautiful wedding dresses. He says, "People should avoid stiff, traditional dresses and choose simpler styles." Ned has been drawing and designing wedding dresses since he was a boy. At 16, he went to fashion school to learn how to make clothes. You don’t have to be a bride to wear an Ingham dress. He also designs long evening dresses in new colors and fabrics. For those who prefer classic styles, he offers a navy-blue summer suit, which has been popular for many years, but he makes it look fresh and new.
**Sally Quail: Jeweller**  
Sally Quail used to work for an art dealer but did not have formal training in jewellery. She started designing her own engagement ring because she could not find one she liked. In 1990, she became a designer. Now, many famous people wear her jewellery. She uses large semi-precious stones in gold to make beautiful necklaces, bracelets, and rings inspired by the 18th century. Recently, she has started using diamonds. She says, "I wanted a diamond, and that is when I began working with them."
**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**  
Lily Grimson started her handbag business four years ago. She only took a short course in art and design, but two of her bags were chosen for a big design exhibition. All of her bags are handmade in the UK. A Grimson handbag is not just a bag; it is stylish and made from high-quality materials like calfskin and silk. 
**Peter Little: Hairdresser**  
Peter Little has been a hairdresser for over 20 years. Many famous people have had their hair styled by him. He says, "Most women want hair that looks real and is easy to manage." He wants his clients to look natural, not like they just came from a salon. His services are expensive, costing £250 for the first appointment, and there is a long waiting list. He has also created his own line of hairdryers and styling tools for people to use at home.
**Penny Pratt: Florist**  
Penny Pratt runs a small flower shop and works as a flower consultant for supermarkets and restaurants. She has no formal training in floristry and used to be a teacher. Ten years ago, she decided to do something different. Her modern flower arrangements have won many design awards, and she has started her own London Flower School. She has also given successful lectures in Japan and the USA. She says, "Flower arrangements are simpler now. Keep them strong and don’t use too many leaves. For wedding bouquets, remember: use flowers of the same type."

**The Merrion Hotel: Luxury and Technology**
The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It took almost two years to change four old houses into this hotel. The hotel has the latest technology to help both the staff and the guests.
Peter MacCann is the General Manager. He wants his staff to know the guests' names. For more details about what guests like, he uses a computer system. This system helps the hotel give special service to returning guests. It cost £250,000 to set up, but MacCann believes it will be worth it. He likes how well it works. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them when they come back.
Many hotel guests often complain about room temperature. The hotel has a system that lets guests change the temperature in their rooms. They can adjust it by three degrees around the normal 18°C. The front desk can also change the temperature between 14°C and 25°C.
The hotel is also good for business guests. MacCann thinks that about 65% of the guests will be business travelers. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that can also copy and print, and a video-conferencing system. The hotel is ready for new technology, so they have extra cables for future upgrades. They rent televisions and DVD recorders, so they can change them for newer models when needed.
Even with all this technology, MacCann wants guests to feel comfortable. The hotel has 145 large and cozy bedrooms. There is also a swimming pool, a gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a lovely garden.
The food at the hotel is very important. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, has moved his restaurant to the Merrion. He has made a new kitchen that is modern and better than before. The hotel benefits from having a great restaurant without financial risks. With good technology and staff, the Merrion Hotel is likely to be very successful.

**An Eye for Detail**
Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. The big garden around her house gives her many ideas for her art. The garden has many of her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread all over the garden. There are many colors and shapes in the two long flower beds along the path that goes through the garden. This is because the previous owners loved gardening and left plants that Susan likes. She also kept the gardener, Danny. Susan says, "In fact, it was really his garden." They worked well together. At first, Danny would say some of Susan's ideas were not good, but when she said she wanted to paint them, he understood her vision.
Susan likes to paint detailed pictures of single plants instead of the whole garden. Sometimes, she paints a group of plants, but usually, she picks one flower and takes it to her studio. She explains, "I don't set the whole thing up at once. I take one flower out and paint it, which might take a few days, and then I bring in another one." Sometimes, it can take her a couple of years to finish a painting.
Her busiest time is in spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. She says, "They all come out together, and you're so busy." But she also enjoys watching how flowers change as they wilt. For example, with tulips, "You bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for perhaps a day, and they each form different shapes. They open up and look amazing."
Susan has always loved plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers from the countryside. She didn't like garden flowers because they looked fake to her. She was fascinated by how wildflowers could grow in tough places, like cracks in rocks.
Today, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they grow well in her garden. She has a relaxed attitude about her garden, like a kind aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don’t break anything. 
Now, with two art shows coming up and many flowers to paint, it has been hard for her to work in the garden. She has hired an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**No Title**
Many trees in Brackham were knocked down in the big storms last March. The town lost two big lime trees from the old market square. This change made the town look very different, and some people were not happy about it. 
One of these people was Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, the head of the local police. But during the storm, he was very sick with bronchitis. He had a headache and a tight chest. His wife, Molly, wanted him to see a doctor, but he thought he was too important to go. He tried to keep working, but this made him forget things and made him angry.
Finally, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. Pelham was too weak to argue. Soon, he got medicine and went home to Molly, who sent him to bed. 
On Thursday morning, Molly told him that the walnut tree in their garden had fallen during the night. Pelham was too sick to understand. Later, he asked if the house was damaged. When he learned it was fine, he felt relieved and went back to bed.
On Saturday, when the medicine started to work, Pelham got up. He was shocked to see that the living room looked very different without the walnut tree. Their big house had a nice garden, and Pelham was happy he bought it. The garden made them feel private. 
Before, the walnut tree made the living room look nice with light and shadows. But now, without the tree, the room was too bright, and the old furniture looked bad. The view from the window was not nice either. The tall house next door, which was hidden by the tree, was now visible. It had ugly purple bricks and many windows that seemed to watch the Pelhams.
“Doesn’t it look terrible?” Pelham said to Molly. But Molly, standing in the doorway, seemed happy. “I’ve been saying this since we moved here. We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost.”

**Living in the Valley**
We had lived in our valley for sixteen months when we first saw the dangers in the hills around us. It was the year when the storms came early, even before November ended. Until then, we felt safe in our valley, protected by the hills. 
Then, snow began to fall. In one day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. The snow almost blocked our road and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. In the hills, the snow was much deeper and stayed longer. The wind was very strong up there. In our valley, we only felt some strong gusts of wind; the trees moved, but their branches stayed strong. 
We knew we had to worry. The snow and wind were annoying, but they did not really scare us. The river, called the Ryburn, was what worried us the most. It usually flowed gently, but we remembered what could happen if the water from the hills was not controlled by dams built many years ago. 
Soon, the snow started to melt. Every day, we saw dark clouds gather over the hills to the west. These clouds looked dangerous and warned us of what was coming. We watched the river, which was getting fuller and wilder. The snow melted as more rain fell from the clouds, but the reservoir in the hills was filling up and getting close to overflowing. 
Then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. It was like a small Niagara Falls, as water rushed over the dam and into the stream below. The river looked wild as the water rushed down towards us. Just a few meters from our cottage, the stream was deeper than we had ever seen, moving quickly and dangerously. 
For three days, we hoped the river would stay below its banks. Luckily, the dam held, and the water began to go down. In the past, before the dam was built, the river had flooded nearby villages many times. Now, the dam controls the river, and usually everything is fine. The water from the hills, from snow and heavy rain, stays behind the dam, with only a little overflow sometimes. 
Because of this protection, we can enjoy the big clouds over the valley and feel excited by the river's power. Thanks to the dam, we feel our home in the valley is safe.

Film critic Mark Adams thinks about his ten years of work for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing articles about films for this newspaper was his first real job. Before that, he wrote reviews for novels in other newspapers, films for a magazine, and did some work for the radio. He met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who also worked in radio and television. Tom hired him, but he was not a journalist, so he did not choose his staff carefully.
At first, Tom wanted a team of critics to cover different art forms like books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. They would have a lunch every week to choose what to write about, and there would be guests to make it fun. Mark felt like he was in a dream because it was a new newspaper, and he was part of the team. He thought it was strange that a new paper could start in a busy market. He even felt like a rich person was helping him and pretending to hire him. The first time he saw someone reading his review in the newspaper on the London Underground, he felt very shy.
Tom's idea for a team of critics did not work out. They did not meet as planned, so they talked on the phone instead. It turned out that people liked to have one reviewer for each subject, so Mark chose to focus on films. Without Tom's help, they would not have the current way of working, where Mark writes a long article each week about one film. He likes this way of working. He did not want to be a standard film critic who has to watch every new film. That would make him tired and bored quickly.
Mark has the freedom to write more deeply about films, or sometimes he has to make something interesting out of a boring week. He wonders what his role is for the public. He thinks people choose films based on stars, ads, or the director. People usually stick to what they like. Someone who does not like westerns is unlikely to watch one just because of a review, and a fan of love stories will not avoid a romantic film because of what the papers say.
So, if a film review is not a guide for consumers, what is it? Mark does not feel he must be "right" about a movie. He does not think there should be a set number of "great" or "bad" films each year. His job is to present an argument. He does not want to be a judge.

**Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km? Because "it's fun."**
Melanie Sears is a teenager who loves sports. She is looking for a training partner for triathlons, especially a girl. She wants someone who enjoys running long distances (like 15km), swimming in cold water, and cycling long distances (like 100km). It is important to be able to do all three sports without taking a break.
Triathlons are becoming very popular in the Olympics. Many people watch athletes swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km without stopping. It looks hard, but Melanie enjoys it. She started doing triathlons when she was 14 years old. In her first race, she won the junior section, but she was the only one in that group. She felt confident and entered the National Championships. She swam fast and ran fast, but she got lost and cycled too far. She cried while running, but she did not give up.
Melanie is very determined. She sometimes wishes she could stop because it hurts, but she is afraid that if she stops once, she might want to stop again. Steve Trew, the coach, admires her hard work. He said she worked so hard on the running machine that she fell into a wall. Most people stop when they are tired, but Melanie keeps going.
This year, Melanie was the top junior in the European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. She is working hard to improve her cycling because she is slower at it than swimming and running. She is trying to convince her parents to buy her a new bike for the World Championships in New Zealand, which costs a lot of money.
Melanie trains a lot, so she does not have much time for friends. She says, "I don't have a social life." After swimming for two hours on Friday nights, she just wants to sleep. But she still talks to her teammates about their race times, not about boys or clothes.
Melanie has tried other shorter events, like the triathlon "sprint," where you swim 750m, cycle 20km, and run 5km. She wants to try even harder races, but she has no one her age to train with.

**The Collectors**
Amanda Roy talks about collecting things and why many people enjoy this hobby. Many adults like to collect items. It is a fun and exciting world. But if you want to collect something, remember: you should love the item. 
People have always liked to collect. Long ago, early humans collected pebbles and wore them as necklaces. They liked the shapes and colors of the pebbles. This was the first way people gathered objects for fun and meaning. Today, children still collect stones and seashells because they are beautiful.
I have collected things all my life. I have collected flowers like tulips, pottery, and paintings. My first collection was stones from my parents' garden. When I was six, I went to a school in a cold place in England. When my parents visited, they took me to a local museum. The museum had many interesting objects collected by people long ago. I loved looking at them.
Many adults also enjoy collecting. Some people collect because it is the only thing they can control in their lives. For me, I just enjoy it. One famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France. He had a "room of wonders" with many strange and beautiful items. Another collector, Catherine the Great of Russia, had over 4,000 paintings.
You do not need to be rich to collect. I have collected many different things, like tulip bulbs and china cups. I remember when I convinced another collector to give me a special tulip. I planted it and took care of it, but one year it disappeared. Someone stole it!
I once collected 350 American rag dolls. I searched all over the USA for them. Sadly, my collection was lost when my house caught fire. The next day, I saw the remains of my collection and my furniture. I was very sad.
I find it interesting how collections change hands. A silver spoon that belonged to a king or a poet can be very valuable. As small items become popular, their prices go up. For example, toys from the 1950s are now worth a lot, especially if you kept the original boxes. (I threw away the boxes and the toys!)

**My Line of Work**
Four people talk about their jobs.
**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**  
I organize temporary exhibitions. This means I plan and design the exhibition and tell people about it. I read about the topic of the exhibition and talk to important people to find out the main ideas. I decide what objects and pictures to show. I make sure the public can understand the exhibition by planning fun activities, workshops, and shows. I also work with engineers and electricians to keep visitors safe. Before the exhibition opens, I help create brochures and leaflets to inform people.
**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**  
I start my day at 7:30 a.m. by checking the accounts. Then, I see what new maps and documents we need for the taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are in school, learning how to drive in London. They find the best routes and learn about one-way streets and turns. I help when there are disagreements, like if a right turn is allowed. When they are close to the test, I give them a simple route but tell them they must take a different way because the road is closed. This helps them think of new routes.
**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**  
I live by the sea and work from home. I answer phone calls, create educational materials, and set up training courses. Sometimes, I go to our main office, but I mostly work on the coast. I work with schools and run courses for people who manage the coast and make decisions about the sea. I take them out on a boat to show them the life under the water. This helps them understand better than just using a computer. I love my job because conservation is my hobby, but I work for a charity, so I always need to find more money to do everything I want.
**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**  
My job is very varied. I make sure our publishing program meets what people want and keep about 300 books in stock. We have high standards for information and content. We get many letters from readers about things like maps of countries, and I need to respond carefully. I talk about future projects and sales with my co-publishers. I work with a great team, which makes the job enjoyable. The downside is that there is too much paperwork, which takes time away from more interesting work like product development and design.

**No Title**
We always went to Ireland in June. Since we started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of June at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It is a big house by the sea, not far from the village of Ardbeag. The English couple, the Malseeds, bought the house and made some changes, but they did it carefully. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds were still advertising. 
"How about this?" he said one evening and read the details. The summer before, we went to a hotel that friends recommended, but it was not good because the food was terrible. The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, but my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school. He and Strafe were in school together, which is why we call Strafe by his last name like the teachers did. We are all about the same age and live close to the town where the Malseeds lived before moving to Ireland. 
"How very nice," Mrs. Malseed said, smiling to welcome us again this year. She seems to know when guests are coming because she is usually waiting in the big hall that smells of flowers. "Arthur, take the luggage up," she told the old porter. "Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium," she said, naming the rooms we would stay in. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of using numbers. In winter, when not many people come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of little details like that; her husband takes care of repairs and decoration. 
"Well, well, well," Mr. Malseed said as he came into the hall from the kitchen. "A hundred thousand welcomes," he greeted us in the Irish way. He was smiling, and his dark brown eyes sparkled, making us feel special. Everyone smiled, and I could tell the others felt that our holiday had really started. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; everything was good. Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. "You look younger every year, all four of you," she said, making everyone laugh again. 
Arthur led the way to our rooms, carrying as much luggage as he could and coming back for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while, but we did not play long because we were still tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner because Glencorn Lodge is always full in June. From our table by the window, we could see some guests walking on the lawns and others going down the cliff path to the beach. 
In the morning, we would do the same: walk along the sand to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, then return in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. I knew this because over the years, we had made this plan many times. Since we first came here, we all fell in love with the beautiful landscape.

**Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**
Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and from West Sussex, England. This is her second year working in Val d'Isere, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets.
Sarah studied French and History of Art at Oxford Brookes University. She says being a chalet girl is not a career, but a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a regular job. "I meet successful people every week," she says.
Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. She has her own breakfast before making breakfast for the guests. The guests eat porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, Sarah cleans up and either makes afternoon tea or cleans the rooms. She thinks cleaning is the worst part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. "On a good day, I can ski until 4:30 p.m.," she says.
After skiing, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. Dinner is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen. "I hate coming to a messy kitchen in the morning," she says. Sometimes she talks with the guests, but other times they want to be alone. "Good guests can make a week great," she says.
Sarah lives in the chalet with her friends. They go out at about 11 p.m. They usually start at a place called Bananas, then go to G Jay's, and maybe end the night at Dick's T-Bar. But on Saturday nights, she does not stay out too late because Sunday is her busiest day.
On Sunday, Sarah starts work early. Breakfast for guests leaving has to be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, she cleans quickly. "We clean everything," she says. If she has not done the shopping for the week, she does it now. At around 3 p.m., after cleaning, she prepares tea for the new guests who arrive at about 4:30 p.m. Sometimes the new guests are confused and have many questions.
Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need boots or skis. She takes them to the ski shop and gets a ride back to the chalet. Soon, it is time for dinner again. Sometimes she has a drink after dinner, but if she is too tired, she goes to bed early.

Miss Rita Cohen was a small girl with pale skin. She looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but she said she was six years older. One day, she came to Seymour's factory. She wore overalls and big shoes, and her curly hair framed her pretty face. Seymour was surprised that she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania and doing research about the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree.
A few times a year, someone would call or write to Seymour to ask if they could visit his factory. Sometimes, he would help students by answering their questions or giving them a short tour if they seemed serious. Rita was very small, like the children from Marie's class who had visited the factory years ago. Seymour had shown them how he made gloves, especially the special table where the workers shaped and pressed each glove using hot brass hands. Marie called them "pancake hands" because they looked strange.
Rita asked, "How many pieces come in a shipment?" Seymour replied, "Between twenty and twenty-five thousand." She took notes and asked, "Do they come directly to your shipping department?" He liked that she was interested in all the details. He explained, "They go to the tannery first. We buy the material, and they make it ready for us. My grandfather and father worked in the tannery here in town. I worked there for six months when I started." 
"Have you ever been inside a tannery?" he asked. "Not yet," she said. "You should go if you want to write about leather. I can help you visit one. They are old places. The technology is better now, but it is still similar to what it was hundreds of years ago. It’s hard work. Tanning is one of the oldest industries. They found tanning tools that are six thousand years old in Turkey. The first clothes were just animal skins that were tanned by smoking them. It’s an interesting subject. My father knows a lot about leather. If you talk to him about gloves, he could talk for two days. People who make gloves love their work."
"Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?" he asked. "Not really," she replied. "I saw my mother make a cake when I was a child." Seymour laughed. She made him smile. She was eager to learn, and she reminded him of Marie. 
He said, "Let’s do something fun. We will show you how to make a pair of gloves from start to finish. What size do you wear?"

**Is It a Tough Job?**
Chris Arnot talks to four people with dream jobs to see if they are as great as they seem.
**A. Raquel Graham**  
Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She cannot meet us tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she travels a lot. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss. But there is one small problem: she does not like flying. "On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to help me relax," she says. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. "It felt so closed in with those tiny windows." When she is not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She does some boring tasks like organizing schedules, attending meetings, and making travel plans. Raquel did not apply for this job. She met a pop group manager by chance and got the job. She also took secretarial classes at night. Five years later, she became a personal assistant.
**B. David Brown**  
David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy, which means he carries a golfer's bags. He prefers being a caddy because he loves golf. However, there are some downsides. He earns a small flat fee and a percentage of the winnings. Most caddies earn between £25,000 and £35,000, but they spend a lot on travel and hotels. David was 31 when he first caddied for golfer Greg Norman. "You do more than just carry bags. You give advice and try to understand the course," he explains. Recently, his accounting skills were recognized, and he became a statistical data administrator for European Tour Productions. He collects and analyzes statistics from the caddies, which are important for TV commentators and golfers.
**C. Martin Fern**  
Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a daily newspaper. One of his easier tasks is to try food at fancy restaurants. What does he think about expensive restaurants? "If people can pay, it's their choice," he says. "I would rather spend £120 on a meal I will remember than buy a microwave." His friend, who was an editor, offered him a food column because Martin is a good cook. At that time, he worked in advertising and it helped him earn extra money. When he was 42, another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "It meant I would earn less money, but it was a chance to turn my passion into a job." He still cooks at home and tries to stay fit by cycling to the nearest tube station.
**D. Dick Prince**  
"I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago," says Dick Prince, a popular children's writer in Britain. "Before that, I loved words but mostly wrote poems. Then I had an idea for a story. I was a farmer and knew about chickens being killed by a fox. So, I wrote a story called The Fox Busters, which was my first published children's book." Where do his ideas come from? "It is not easy; I have to work hard for them," he says. "I usually write in the mornings. I do not wake up very early. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing what I wrote in the morning. I use an old typewriter, not a laptop." He receives 50 to 100 letters a week, which he enjoys. He tries to answer them all, but now he has some help.

In the lumberyard by the lake, there was an old two-story brick building. Outside, there were big piles of soft sawdust. The sawdust looked like golden mountains and covered the ground near the blue lake. 
One afternoon, Michael and his friends were bored. They climbed up a ladder to the roof of the old building and sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down!" Without thinking, he jumped off the roof and landed in the sawdust, rolling around and laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards!" 
His friends looked scared but then one by one, they jumped down and laughed with relief. They all lay on the sawdust, telling jokes. After a while, one friend said, "Let’s go back up and jump again." They were not very excited, but they climbed back to the roof and jumped off quickly. 
Soon, only Michael was left on the roof. His friends called up to him, "Come on, Mike! What’s wrong?" Michael wanted to jump down too, but he stayed at the edge, feeling nervous. He tried to count to ten and take a deep breath, but he couldn’t jump. His friends started to laugh at him because he was taking too long. They got tired of waiting and began to walk away, still shouting at him. 
Michael felt sad and alone. He stayed on the roof for almost an hour, watching the sun go down. His clothes were wet from sweating. Finally, he closed his eyes and jumped down into the sawdust. He lay there for a long time, and the yard was quiet because the workers had gone home. 
When he got up, he felt ashamed and walked home slowly. He was late for dinner, and his stepmother said, "You should be able to get home on time. If you can’t, maybe you should stay out tonight." She was a kind woman with soft skin and a little grey in her hair. But Michael didn’t really hear her. He was still thinking about his friends laughing at him.

**Careers Advice**
Are you unhappy in your job? Do you want to change but don’t know how? Kitty Doherty has some good advice for you. Many people who want to change their job go to a careers adviser. 
First, you will write a short history about yourself. Then, you will take some tests called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, you will get a summary of the results. The adviser will suggest different careers and any training you might need.
I tried Career Analysts, a big organization that gives career advice. Taking the career test felt like being back in school. I was with about ten other people, and we had to answer questions quickly. I reminded myself that it was not about passing or failing. The tests were hard to understand. They included finding mistakes in lists and matching shapes.
After the tests, I talked with an adviser. He gave me a report with his thoughts and suggestions. I agreed with most of what he said, but I was surprised to learn that I did not do well in the science and technical tests. I was glad to hear that I made the right choice in journalism.
Changing your career does not always mean a big change. Last March, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager after five years. Her friends told her to go to Career Analysts for help. Donna said, "Losing my job was a good chance for me to think about my career. I wanted to look at my skills and interests." Some results surprised her. "I didn’t know I was good at design. But I had to think about the cost of training in design," she said. 
Other ideas included taking a year off to work in the Far East. In the end, she decided to use her skills and find a job that suited her better. Now, she works as a Public Relations officer. She believes she could have found this job without Career Analysts, but they helped her understand what she really wanted to do. She has sent many friends there, and they are all happy with the service.
Some people feel they really needed help. Juliet Greene, 26, went to Career Counselling Services and made important decisions. After working at a bank for six years, she thought her job was boring and wanted a new challenge. She didn’t know what to do, so she went to the service with an open mind. The tests showed she was interested in sciences. 
She had four meetings with an adviser. The third meeting was recorded, which helped her remember what she said. After the fourth meeting, she decided to study geology and start a degree later this year. She thinks the advice from Career Counselling Services was worth the money. Now, she is much happier.
However, career advice does not work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, 24, was a sales representative. She felt lost in her career and hoped a careers adviser would suggest something new. Although she got many ideas, she did not like them because they needed a big pay cut or a lot of retraining. She felt she did not learn anything new about herself. "You have to share a lot of personal information, and I think a friend would give me the same advice," she said.

**Fun at the Dentist's?**
If you go to W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in Glasgow, you will see bright paintings on the walls and a nice blue couch. Patients sit on this couch while he checks their teeth. Jerome says, "Fifty percent of people only visit the dentist when they are in pain. They are scared." To help with this, he wants to make the office a place where people feel safe. That is why he does not wear a white coat. Many people think a white coat means pain. Jerome believes that dental visits should be relaxing and enjoyable.
This is surprising for many people who think going to the dentist is scary. Jerome says, "If people feel relaxed and happy, they will forget their bad experiences." One of his new ideas is to use virtual-reality headsets. "We were the first dental office in Britain to use them, and they are very popular." Patients wear the headsets during their check-up. They sit on the blue couch and watch a movie about underwater animals while Jerome checks their teeth. Then, the headset shows them a special view of their mouth.
Most patients like this part of their visit. The office also smells nice, like a perfume shop. Today, it smells like oranges. Jerome wants people to feel that this is not a normal dentist's office. The usual dentist smell can make people feel scared. I thought the nice smell in the office was very pleasant.
Jerome is known as Glasgow's most stylish dentist, but he takes his work very seriously. The relaxation ideas are important, but giving good treatment is the most important thing. For example, he uses a special tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth instead of scraping them. It feels a little strange at first, but it is not painful if people are relaxed.
Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn about new dental methods. He says, "When you make it easier for the patient, it is easier for you too." He believes that his way of treating patients is changing the serious style of British dentistry.
At that moment, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly goes to him, offers a cup of tea, and asks what video he would like to watch. He gently leads the patient to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this special treatment. The office feels more like a beautiful salon than a regular dental office.

**Bitter Water Becomes Popular**
Chocolate comes from South America and is now a big business around the world. In Britain, people spend over £230 million on chocolate at Easter. This is about eight percent of all chocolate sales. People eat more chocolate at Christmas than at any other time.
The cacao plant, which is used to make chocolate, was first grown by the Aztecs, Toltecs, and Mayans in Central America over three thousand years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and South-East Asia. The fruit of this tree is big like a melon and has 20 to 40 seeds inside. When these seeds are dried, they become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, these are often called cocoa beans, but this is a mistake from the 17th century.
The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and made a drink called xocoatl, which means "bitter water" in their language. They added spices to this drink for special occasions. The Spanish liked the drink better with cinnamon and sugar, but it took a long time for this recipe to reach Europe.
In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in big cities in Europe where people could drink chocolate. Until the last century, people made chocolate drinks from solid chocolate blocks that had to be melted in hot water. In 1826, a man named CJ van Houten from the Netherlands created chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the beans. 
The chocolate bar we know today started in 1847 when a company in Bristol, Fry and Sons, mixed cocoa butter with chocolate and sugar to make a solid bar. A Swiss company later added milk to make milk chocolate. 
At first, French companies sold most of the chocolate in Britain. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their factory Bournville, hoping to attract customers with a French name. Then, in 1905, Cadbury created the Dairy Milk bar, which became very popular because of clever advertising that linked it to healthy milk from the countryside. 
Today, people in Britain eat about four chocolate bars each week. Chocolate companies are trying new ideas to attract customers, like making chocolate bars into ice cream or desserts. 
However, cacao farmers are still struggling because cocoa bean prices fell in the late 1980s. Many small farmers went out of business. So, next time you enjoy a chocolate bar, think about the farmers who grow cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**
Peter Cooke is 83 years old and is very good at his art. He wants to try new things like making paper and working with feathers, but for now, he is happy making beautiful objects from shells. 
As he shows me his work in his apartment, he asks, "Am I boring you?" He is not boring at all. He is very interesting and his creations are beautiful. He shows me some shell-covered decorations above his fireplace. He says, "I don’t mind if people don’t buy them because I love them." Peter never planned to sell his work. About five years ago, some friends told him he should have an exhibition so more people could see his art. They helped him talk to a gallery owner.
His first exhibition was in London, and 70% of his pieces were sold. His second exhibition just opened yesterday. The prices for his work are high, around £2,000 for some decorations. There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell flower in a crystal vase. Peter says he does not set the prices, but he knows his work is special. The gallery owner told him that one day, when he stops making art, everyone will want his pieces.
Peter wishes he had started making art earlier in his life. He thinks he could have made even more wonderful things. Now, he feels he cannot do as much because he is older. However, his work is very different from the common shell items you find in seaside shops. He has a creative mind and makes boxes covered in tiny shells, pictures made from shells, and baskets of very realistic flowers.
Peter has his own way of working. He uses materials he finds, like cardboard from shirts for flower bases, glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. He says, "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just happens." His work is very detailed and beautiful.
Peter travels to many places to find tiny shells. He has been to France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He lies on the beach to look for shells to take home. He only collects dead shells and does not take shells with living creatures in them. He explains that many people walk on the beach and break shells, and the sea also breaks them. He believes it is okay to collect shells that are no longer home to any creatures. 
Peter’s argument about collecting shells is strong, especially when you see how beautiful his work is.

**The Schoolgirl Model**
Kira Langer is a 15-year-old girl who is a model. When she is not traveling to exciting places or appearing on magazine covers, she studies for her school exams. 
One day, I was waiting to meet Kira for an interview. The receptionist told me that Kira would be late. I started to worry. I had read some bad things about models, like they can be difficult or vain. I thought, "What if she doesn’t come at all?" But when Kira arrived, she was smiling and friendly. She was with her mother and was wearing a simple black dress and trainers, not fancy clothes. 
Kira explained that all models under 16 must have an adult with them when they work. Her mother looked proud of her. Kira seemed a bit surprised by her fame because it was unexpected. It was her older sister who encouraged her to enter a model competition. Kira said, "I didn’t want to, but she sent some photos anyway." When she found out she was a finalist, she was at school. This made her feel confident, and she won the competition easily. After that, a model agency in London offered her work.
Now, Kira has to balance her life as a model and a student. Her friends and teachers are proud of her, but some people at school are not nice. They say she thinks too highly of herself. Kira finds this hard to handle, but she says, "I am still the same person. I am just more confident now."
Being a busy model affects her social life. The agency can call her at any time for a job. She cannot always make plans with her friends because she doesn’t know what she will be doing. But her friends understand and do not complain.
Kira has the looks and support to have a great career. Not many people can say that before finishing school. At the end of the interview, I asked her what she would like to do if she wasn’t a model. She thought for a moment and said, "I would like to do what you are doing."

**Father and Son Search for Gold**
Terence and Chris Madden are a father and son team. They have traveled from the cold north of Canada to hot Africa looking for gold. They think their mine on a Welsh mountain could have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging, they believe they are very close to finding a lot of gold worth five million dollars. Terence, who is 68 years old and from Liverpool, said, "As we dig, we are finding high levels of gold; now we just need to dig a little more to find it all."
The Maddens have spent their lives looking for gold. Their search started when Terence read about gold hidden in the "Dolgellau gold belt," an area near the town of Dolgellau in Wales. They read old mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth. They chose the best area to explore. After clearing the land, they found pieces of gold in the rocks. They have spent ten years getting permission to work, taking soil samples, and cleaning up old cars and trash. They dug out 150 tonnes of rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter deep hole.
Now, they need more money. They have used their savings to chase their dream. They need to find someone to invest £50,000 to dig deeper where the gold is. Chris says it looks difficult, but they have some people to contact for help.
As news spread about their digging, many people in the area became interested in gold. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and the locals are hopeful. Peter Woolven, the manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "If they find gold, it could bring more visitors here, but I hope many people do not come and damage the hillside."
The gold industry in Wales has declined since the late 1880s when many people worked in mines. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen, closed a month ago. Now, more individual gold diggers are coming back. George Hall, another gold seeker, plans to dig a tunnel on the other side of the hill from the Maddens. He is 70 years old and said, "Searching for gold is very emotional. It is exciting to find hidden treasure. Maybe I will be lucky this time."

**IN HOT WATER**
Rachel Mills is a scientist. She spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel teaches and does research about marine geochemistry. This means she studies the chemicals in the sea. She works at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University.
When Rachel is not teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle. This vehicle is for exploring underwater and is the size of a small car. She dives three kilometres down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, there is very little space. Rachel says, "I can reach out and touch the two pilots." They cannot stand up or move around. They must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside.
A dive can last for 16 hours. It takes three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and then three hours to come back up. If there is a problem and they need to get to the top quickly, they can press a panic button. This makes a small escape vessel come out, which goes quickly to the surface.
Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. She got in with an instructor on a ship. He explained what to do in an emergency, like if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would react in a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place five days away from the Canary Islands. There, they found many underwater volcanoes that blow out black smoke.
When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre. She loves teaching, but she also wants to do research on "black smokers," which are underwater volcanoes. Water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. This water comes out very fast and is very hot.
Rachel felt scared the first time she dived with an American team. They were using equipment when suddenly there was a loud explosion. She thought, "I'm going to die." They waited in silence, but they were still alive. The relief was incredible!
Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels amazed. She thinks, "Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else has ever seen this." Rachel studied black smokers for three years for her PhD. When she finally saw them, it was an amazing feeling.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a little sunburned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was tired, and my mind was confused by different train times, money, and languages. I said, "Never again," when I got home. I said the same thing the next year and the year after that. 
All I needed was one train ticket. Because I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. Sleeping in a train corridor is different from sleeping in a bed. The train rocks you to sleep. Carrying all my things in a backpack made me travel simply. I learned to throw away things I didn’t need, like old socks and books. This way of traveling is part of the fun of Inter-Rail. You can forget about rules and just enjoy the trip. 
Having a ticket in my hand made me feel free. This ticket lets young people travel to many countries in one day. On my first trip, my friends and I didn’t know how great this ticket was. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to our campsite in southern France. But we wanted to see more countries. The extra travel didn’t cost us anything. 
We were excited to travel without our parents. We made our own plans and only saw the things that were easy to find. It was a chance to do something different. I was proud that sometimes all I wanted to see was the view from the train station. We just wanted to enjoy ourselves, like many other Inter-Rail travelers who shared the train with us. 
The excitement of travel comes from seeing a place you only knew by name. When the train arrives, you see the city for the first time. You can only understand Europe by seeing it yourself. Everyone knows about Europe, but it is different when you experience it. This is why other people’s holiday photos can be boring. 
Traveling by train may not show you new things in the world, but it is a special experience. Europe is big, and Inter-Rail helps people see this, even if it doesn’t happen right away.

It is very disappointing to arrive at an airport in another country and find out that your luggage is missing. You may have to wear the same clothes for a long time until the airline finds your bags. Sometimes, you might be in a different place with a different weather and have to wear clothes that are not right for that place.
Airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, but it happens to many travelers. Even good airlines can make mistakes. It is hard for any airline to promise that your checked luggage will be on the same flight as you, especially if you have to change planes.
Here is how it works: Airlines ask passengers to arrive at the airport early. This is to give enough time for the luggage to be checked and put on the plane. There is also a minimum time needed to change from one flight to another. This time is often longer to help with luggage transfers. Usually, this system works well. But sometimes, extra security checks and air traffic problems can cause delays. These delays can make it hard for the luggage system to work properly. 
Human mistakes can also happen, like if a label on a bag gets torn off. This can be a bigger problem at large airports, called 'hubs', because many bags are processed there. For example, last year, Heathrow airport in London had over 41 million passengers, and many of them were changing planes. British Airways had two million passengers changing planes at Heathrow.
Even busy airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich can have problems. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing luggage when passengers quickly change planes to go to Latin America.
To avoid losing your luggage, try to book direct flights when you can and check in early. If you have to change planes, try to use the same airline for all your flights. Allow extra time for connections by taking an earlier flight. Make sure to label your luggage with your home address and your holiday address, including your flight numbers.
If your luggage is still missing after all this, you should talk to the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a report about your missing luggage. You need to do this before you leave the airport.

**The Kingfisher**
Wildlife photographer Charlie James knows a lot about the kingfisher. This is a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and eats fish. Old trees grow over the stream, giving some shade to the shallow water. The main colors around are soft greens, browns, and yellows from the sunlight. The sound of the water is gentle in the breeze. 
The kingfisher moves quickly and looks like a flash of light. It is there for just a moment, but you remember it because it is so special. Charlie James loved kingfishers when he was young. He feels very strongly about this little bird, but he does not know exactly why. 
In Greek myths, the kingfisher is a bird that was once a moon goddess. Another story says that the kingfisher flew so high that its top became blue like the sky, while its bottom was burned by the sun. There is some truth in this story. Kingfishers do not have blue color in their feathers. Instead, the way their feathers are made makes them reflect blue light. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or green depending on the light.
Many wildlife photographers love kingfishers. They are shy birds, but you can watch them easily from a hiding place. Charlie James's first hiding place was an old blanket he put over his head while he waited near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird came back in just a few minutes and sat very close to him. But it took him four more years to take his first good picture.
Charlie spent a lot of time by a stream where kingfishers lived. However, school took away some of his time with the birds. He missed classes and called himself an "academic failure." But people noticed his interest in kingfishers. At 16, he started working as an advisor for a nature magazine. Later, he became an assistant to the editor and then worked as a freelance wildlife cameraman.
Now, Charlie wants to make a special kingfisher film. He wants it to have no words, just beautiful images. He likes to take pictures of the kingfisher's wings. He thinks about the colors of the bird he has loved for many years. His photographs show some of his feelings, but Charlie knows there is much more to his love for the kingfisher than what his work can show.

**Conducting an Orchestra**
Giving directions to an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work.
**A. ANNE MANSON**  
Anne Manson is 30 years old. She asked conductor Claudio Abbado if she could watch his practice sessions in Vienna. When an assistant could not come, she helped out. Later, she was asked to help with another opera. "I had to lead the first rehearsal for Abbado. I was not nervous. I always feel good about standing in front of an orchestra." Anne Manson is from America and works with a famous opera company in London that focuses on modern music. She is also becoming known in other European countries, thanks to support from the British Arts Council. Since her first experience, she has helped Abbado on many projects.
**B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE**  
Andrew Constantine is 31 years old. He says the hardest part of being a conductor is getting the right chances. He won a big competition in 1991 after trying twice before. He is thankful for the timing: "If I had won earlier, I would have been forgotten." The competition gave him many chances to perform and work as an assistant to a famous conductor. But he finds it hard to shake off the "competition" label. "If in three years my name is still linked to the competition, I will be worried," he says. "But orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra are inviting me back. If this does not happen, my career will fall apart."
**C. WASFI KANI**  
Wasfi Kani started Pimlico Opera and loves the long practice time for opera productions. "The music needs four weeks of attention," she says. She began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. Taking lessons with Sian Edwards was very important for her. "I saw her conduct and realized she was my size. I had always learned from bigger people, which makes a big difference." She enjoys the complex nature of opera: "There are many arguments, and you have to think about the singers' personalities."
**D. ROGER VIGNOLES**  
Roger Vignoles is 48 years old. He says, "Conducting surprised me, but I find it very interesting." He started as a musician in an opera house and worked with good conductors. Last year, he was asked to direct Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival, something he had never done before. "It was easier than I thought. I knew the music well and what I wanted it to sound like. I tried my best to get the performance I wanted. People respect my skills as a musician. I learn from every experience I have had, both in music and performing. Now, I will do whatever people ask me to find out what I enjoy."
**E. WAYNE MARSHALL**  
In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed Wayne Marshall, a young assistant conductor, and told his agent about him. Now 32, Marshall soon found himself conducting a musical in London at short notice, which was hard. He had to deal with some musicians who were too relaxed and reading newspapers during the show. "I was strict with them. I always gave a clear beat and did my best. Many musicians do not seem to need advice from a conductor. But I am not afraid to say what I want. If people see you are worried, it gets worse. I have never studied conducting formally, and no book teaches you how to conduct, but people have been nice to me. I am determined and know what I like."

**Variations on a Theme**
If you want to take children to a theme park, there are many in Britain. We asked five families to try some of the best parks.
**Fun Island - The Burns Family**  
Last year, we went to a big theme park in the US, so we thought Fun Island would be boring. But we were surprised! The park is good for younger children, so our three-year-old had fun too. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for little kids, which was very popular. For older kids, there are scarier rides like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, we were tired, but the kids wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. The only thing we didn’t like was that the park could be more exciting, and the scenery was not great. But the staff were very helpful, and the park was clean and safe.
**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**  
None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn’t know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it! He enjoyed the Mountain Train and liked Little Land, where there are small models of famous buildings. The older kids liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars. We spent six hours there and were happy there were places to rest. The park looked nice, and the staff were friendly. There was something for everyone, even adults.
**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**  
After seven hours, we still wanted to see more. The kids loved the Big Top Circus, which had a great trapeze act. We tried the Terror Line, and even though the girls were scared, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you will get wet, but you don’t. For younger kids, Toy Land is very fun. The kids wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were happy they were too small for it! The park is so well made that waiting in line is not boring. It was very clean, and the staff were great. One staff member even helped me with one of the girls when I couldn’t sit with both of them.
**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**  
We got to the park at one o'clock and were sad that it closed at 5 p.m. This park is great for younger children because the rides are not too scary. I am a bit scared of rides, but I had fun too. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slow and then becomes very exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over quickly! I wouldn’t go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun if you are brave. If the kids were older, they might have thought it was too easy, but they loved it.
**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**  
The park says there is "No Limit to the Fun," and we felt that was true. The tallest roller-coaster in Europe, the Rocket, is very big, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride. Jennie thought the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters in the air, was worse! There are many main rides, and the older kids went on them many times. Sarah was too small for some rides but liked the Long Slide. The staff were nice to younger kids, but some were not very friendly. You need a whole day to enjoy Fantasy World. We didn’t want to tell the kids we were going home early.

**Running a Business in the Countryside**
Five women share their stories about starting a business in the countryside.
A. **Christine Hogan** runs a computer design business. She makes over £200,000 a year and has four full-time workers. "My customers are my friends," she says. Christine moved from London to the countryside when her children were small. She wanted to work from home. She had experience with computers, so her husband suggested she start a computer design business. At first, it was hard and she needed a lot of money. But she was careful with her spending. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evening if she wants. Her business is small, and most customers come to pick up their work.
B. **Maggy Sasanow** designs greeting cards from her home. "I enjoy being independent," she says. She studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum. But when she moved to the countryside, there were no jobs like that. So, she started her own business and makes 50 different greeting cards to sell to museums. She works in a big room upstairs. The downside of working from home is that there are always chores to do, like mowing the lawn. She does not advertise; her business grows by word of mouth. People send her work from London because she is cheaper than other artists. Working alone can be lonely, but she thinks there are more good things than bad.
C. **Delia Turner** makes curtains. She started her business eight years ago when it was growing. In two years, her income went from £24,000 to £80,000. She had six full-time workers, but she had to let them go when the economy got worse. This was hard because it is not easy to find jobs in her area. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband’s help and works with women who also work from home. She has to lower her prices sometimes and look for new opportunities.
D. **Tessa Strickland** runs a children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago because London was too expensive and she loves the country. She likes being able to work when she wants. Most of her income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so she takes calls at strange hours. The downside is that she needs to be disciplined to close her office door. She publishes children's books from different cultures and works with authors and artists. At first, she felt lonely because all her work experience was in London.
E. **Meg Rivers** runs a cake business and a shop. She makes £250,000 a year and has six employees, some of whom work part-time. She started her business at home ten years ago. She is interested in health, so she began making fruit cakes with good quality ingredients. Friends and family asked for cakes, and soon she was sending them all over the country. Seven years ago, she rented a small building where everything is made. Now, she has a baker and an assistant, and a professional cake decorator. She does not bake anymore; she manages the business. Her biggest challenge has been the financial side because she did not have a lot of money to start.

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**
The Watkins family is very special. The sons are musicians and composers, and their dad makes musical instruments. 
John and Hetty Watkins are teachers from South Wales. They wanted to buy a cello for their son, Paul, who is ten years old. But the cello was very expensive. John thought, "Maybe I can make one." He found a school nearby that teaches how to make instruments. He took evening classes for three years.
After making some violins, John made his first cello. Paul, now 28, says it turned out great. John made another cello for Paul, and he used it until a few months ago. Now, John is a full-time craftsman and makes about twelve violins each year. He even sold one to a famous American musician named Jaime Laredo.
Paul and his younger brother, Huw, started playing music when they were young. Paul remembers climbing up to play the piano as soon as he could. He tried the violin for a short time but liked the cello more. He thought the cellist in his dad's music group was very cool. So, he took lessons and started playing the cello.
Huw, who is now 22, also plays music. He is a pianist and composer. He says his parents were supportive and did not push him too hard. Instead of feeling jealous of Paul’s success, he wanted to do well too.
Paul has done very well with the cello his dad made. He won a big music competition called the BBC Young Musician of the Year. At just 20 years old, he became the main cellist for the BBC Symphony Orchestra. He played with his dad's cello until last year. Now, he has a different cello that is very old and special.
Paul will soon play on television with his new cello in a famous piece called Elgar's Cello Concerto. He says he will play it his own way. However, he cannot watch himself on TV because he will be performing at the Cheltenham Festival that night. Huw will also be busy because his String Quartet will be played in London at the same time.
John and Hetty will have to be very organized to keep up with all their sons' music events in the coming weeks.

**Looking after the Countryside: The National Trust**
The National Trust is a group that wants to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden who works for the Trust.
Gareth says that a National Trust Warden needs common sense. He also needs to be good with people because he talks to farmers, visitors, conservationists, and building companies all the time. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. Many people wanted to be the National Trust Warden for the Lleyn Peninsula, but Gareth got the job because he knows the area well and has farming experience, even though he did not have formal training.
Gareth still helps on his parents' farm, which helps him understand the farmers' problems. He says, "They can't trick me!" His farming background also helps him do the physical work of the job, like building fences, planting trees, and making walls. Since he started working with the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. He remembers when he was young, he liked to pick flowers and collect butterflies. Now, he wonders where he can find those flowers and butterflies. He understands that farming has changed the countryside, but it is not the farmers' fault; they were just following the government's advice.
At first, farmers and conservationists did not get along. They both wanted things done their way. Now, they are talking and understanding each other better. Gareth says, "We are close to working together."
Gareth's job includes conservation, allowing people to visit the Trust's land, planting trees, and working with tenant farmers. He wants to finish jobs quickly and without problems. He enjoys seeing projects completed, but he spends a lot of time on reports and paperwork.
Gareth loves his job, even though he is always working. He enjoys talking to the public, but some people can be difficult. He says, "Some people come in, want everything, and then leave as if they own the place. It can be annoying!" But Gareth believes that common sense is important.
If you have common sense and like working outside, you might want to be a warden like Gareth. But be ready to wait a long time for a job on the Lleyn Peninsula!

**The Netball Captain**
In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day. She taught at a local school and then trained in a supermarket car park.
I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I am focused on my movements and my feet, so I don’t see much else. I might see cars slow down a little, but that’s all."
Kendra said, "My life is all about being my best for the World Championships." She is following a strict schedule to be very fit for the games. This is her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries taking part. She said, "We will have support from home, which is very special. It is important to improve the reputation of netball in our country. There will be more pressure because we are playing at home. People expect us to start with a good game."
Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra said, "We have always beaten them, but they will be fun to play. They are very skilled." The England team is ranked fourth in the world. Kendra knows the Championships will be hard. She said, "You have to push yourself every day. There is no rest between games. In a series, you can still win if you lose the first game. But in the Championships, you only have one chance."
In the fifteen years she has played at a high level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. Kendra said, "You train hard to win. But after the game, we are all friends."
Netball is also using more science for fitness testing. Kendra said, "It is important that we think and train like top players. As captain, I need to have a strong mind and lead by example. I want to support and encourage my team."
Kendra said, "From the start of my netball career, I have planned carefully. I decided that this competition would be my last as a player." She will likely coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**
What should you do if your child is very good at music? It can be hard to know how to help them. Some parents might not see their child's needs until the child becomes upset or difficult. Most regular schools can help children who are good at subjects like math or English, but children who are good at music need special support that regular schools may not provide. 
Children who are musically talented can benefit from going to a specialist music school. There are five of these schools in Britain. They help children aged seven to eighteen develop their musical skills with the help of professional musicians. 
At these schools, children spend a lot of time on music. They have individual lessons, play in orchestras, and practice singing. They also practice in special rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on important subjects like English, math, science, and languages. 
These schools are independent, which means they are not run by the government. The classes are small, so teachers can give more attention to each student. Most children live at the school, which means they eat and sleep there. This helps them be with other children who love music too.
However, there are some problems. The cost is high, around £12,000 to £17,000 a year for students who live at the school. The schools try to help families with scholarships and financial aid. Also, not all parents want to send their young children to live at school. The directors of these schools worry about admitting very young children because the environment is strict and intense. They want to help children grow up to be well-rounded individuals.
Sometimes, being in a special music school can be stressful. A child’s musical talent might change as they grow older, and the pressure to succeed can be hard. The schools watch each student closely and offer help when needed. 
Many former students say they learned a lot from the music teaching, but some feel that the focus on music means they do not get enough academic learning. Many musically talented children are also smart and want to learn more in school. 
Because of this, it might be better to wait until a child is older to decide on a specialist music school. Children who are also good at school subjects can do well in regular schools with good music programs. They can also take music lessons on weekends at music colleges, but this may not be possible for families who live far from big cities.

**An Eye for Detail**
Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. The big garden around her house gives her many ideas for her art. The garden has many of her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread all over the garden. There are many colors and shapes in the two long flower beds along the path that goes through the garden. This is because the previous owners loved gardening and left plants that Susan likes. She also kept the gardener, Danny. Susan says, "In fact, it was really his garden." They worked well together. At first, Danny would say some of Susan's ideas were not good, but when she said she wanted to paint them, he understood.
Susan likes to paint detailed pictures of single plants instead of the whole garden. Sometimes she paints a group of plants, but usually, she picks one flower and takes it to her studio. She says, "I don't set the whole thing up at once. I take one flower out and paint it. This might take a few days. Then I bring in another one and build up the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."
Her busiest time is spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. She says, "They all come out together, and you're so busy." But she also enjoys watching how flowers change as they wilt. For example, with tulips, "You bring them in and put them in water. After a day, they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, they seem boring, but they change all the time."
Susan has always loved plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers from the countryside. She didn't like garden flowers because they looked fake to her. She was fascinated by how wildflowers could grow in tough places, like cracks in rocks.
Today, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they grow well in her garden. She has a relaxed attitude about her garden, like a kind aunt who lets children play as long as they don’t break anything. 
Now, Susan has two art shows to prepare for, and she has a lot of flowers to paint. She has hired an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**
Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and from West Sussex, England. This is her second year working in Val d'Isère, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets.
Sarah studied French and History of Art at Oxford Brookes University. She says being a chalet girl is not a career, but it is a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a regular job. She meets many interesting people every week.
Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. The chalet can have up to 18 guests each week. She eats her breakfast before making breakfast for the guests. They have porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, she cleans up and either makes afternoon tea or cleans the rooms, which she thinks is the worst part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. On good days, she can ski until 4:30 p.m.
After skiing, Sarah goes back to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower first but does not sleep because it is not good to sleep before work. Dinner is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen. She does not like coming back to a messy kitchen in the morning. Sometimes she talks with the guests, but other times they want to be alone. Good guests can make her week better, but some weeks are not as good.
Sarah lives in the chalet with her friends. They go out at about 11 p.m. They usually start at a place called Bananas, then go to G Jay's, and maybe end the night at Dick's T-Bar. But on Saturday nights, she does not stay out too late because Sunday is her busiest day.
On Sunday, she starts work early. Breakfast for the guests must be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, she cleans quickly. She clears the breakfast, strips the beds, and gets everything ready for the new guests. If she did not shop for food on Saturday, she does it now. By 3 p.m., after cleaning, she prepares tea for the new guests who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are confused and have many questions.
Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski boots or skis. She takes them to the ski shop and gets a ride back to the chalet. Then it is time for dinner again. Sometimes she talks with friends, but if she is too tired, she goes to bed early.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**
Mandie Currie is a zoo-keeper. One day, she worked at the magazine Marie Claire. She said, "Choosing my clothes was hard because I usually wear a uniform at the zoo. I went to a photo studio and then to press previews before lunch. The zoo is calm and peaceful, but here I was busy when I could be quietly with an animal. Some people on the fashion team looked stressed, but my job is not stressful. In the afternoon, I laughed because I usually clean cages or handle rats. I like seeing how magazines work, but I enjoy my job at the zoo, so I will stay there."
Alice Cutler is a fashion assistant at Marie Claire. She spent a day at London Zoo. She wore leather boots and dark blue trousers, but the zoo gave her a green polo shirt to wear. She got very dirty while petting an elephant. She thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, she felt dirty but had a great day. She said, "When I stop working in fashion, I could work with elephants, maybe in Africa."
Karen Hodson is a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital. She worked with the TV gardening show Ground Force. She was very excited to meet the team and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter. She liked being outside because she sometimes does not see daylight at work. It was hard work, but she had fun. She thought she was strong, but the team was stronger. She realized that gardening is hard work, so she will not stop being a nurse.
Charlie Dimmock is a gardener on Ground Force. He worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. He made beds and gave out medicine. He thought he would feel faint, but he was okay.
