He liked the friendship among the nurses. He said, "My job feels less important than nursing. My day at the hospital was not easy, but I felt good about helping."
Lucy Harvey is a personal trainer. She worked with Ryanair as cabin crew. She changed into the uniform and felt different. People looked at her. Before the flight, her supervisor talked about safety. When passengers got on the flight to Paris, she gave out magazines. She felt nervous when everyone stared at her. On the way back, there were 80 schoolchildren who would not sit still. She wished she was back in the gym with one adult to help.
Sonia McDermott is an air hostess with Ryanair. She worked as a personal trainer in a gym for a day. She was worried because she does not exercise. She was surprised by how much attention trainers give to one person. In her job, she meets 130 passengers four times a day. At lunch, she saw that some trainers did not eat very healthily, but they drank a lot of water. She said, "I would not change my job for this, but it made me want to join a gym and be healthier."

**On the Rails**
Five famous people share their favorite memories of train journeys with Andrew Morgan.
**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to go back as often as I can. There is a local train from Cannes along the coast that goes to Italy. It takes you past beautiful views of the sea. It does not matter what the weather is like or what time of year it is; it is always lovely. Out of the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and houses in France. You feel like you are looking into the homes of rich and famous people. The people on the train are always lively because there are many tourists and locals, all enjoying the beautiful journey.
**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have enjoyed many train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which goes across the desert in northern Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park because I was too young and was sent to my aunt's house. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still had not traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first big train station I ever saw, and its big glass roof amazed me.
**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I am thankful for one train in particular: the Blue Train. It took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone said that pink is good for the brain, and I have worn it ever since. The journey was lovely as we traveled through France and then by boat up the Nile. It was the perfect way to relax after our wedding.
**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on articles about a trip around the world and had to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express train. The schedule was not reliable; we were just told to wait for a day. The driver would often wait for people to arrive. When the train came, many people rushed to get on, and some even traveled on the roof for free. At night, the train went through beautiful landscapes. It felt like a dream, like traveling on the moon.
**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people have favorite memories of trains from when they were children, but I do not. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It was not until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film that had a railway in Yorkshire. We filmed on an old train line that volunteers took care of. That is where my love for steam trains began. When we were not filming, we took every chance to ride the train. When I went back last year, everything was still the same, even the gas lights on the station platform!

'Want to Get Published?**
If you want to publish your story, expert Margaret Stubbs has some advice for you. Many readers of this magazine ask, "I have written a story/book. Who should I send it to?" 
First, you need to research where to send your work. You should learn about publishers and practice your writing skills. Writing well takes time and knowledge. No matter what you write, you need to know about the markets you want to reach. 
One of the best ways to learn is by reading. Go to your local library, bookshops, and newsagents. Read many different things to see what publishers are accepting. This information changes often because new magazines and books come out all the time. 
If you want to write short love stories, find magazines that publish them. Get recent copies and read them. Learn what kind of stories they like and who their readers are. The readers want different things, and the editor wants to meet their needs. 
Sometimes, new writers send their stories to me and say, "This has been rejected three times. Am I wasting my time?" I never want to discourage anyone, but it is often true that their work is not ready to be published. Many new writers are too quick to send their work out before it is good enough. 
If you have only written one story or article, it is very unlikely to be published. Most successful writers have worked in publishing or journalism for years before they succeed. 
When you send your work for the first time, keep writing more stories while you wait for a reply. Write ten or twenty more. Each one will be better, and you will start to see yourself as a writer. Your skills and confidence will grow. 
Do not throw away any of your stories; instead, try to improve them. In the beginning, it is best not to show your work to others. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections before they succeeded. 
Do everything you can to improve as a writer. Look for a creative writing course near you. If you can’t find one, join a local writers' group. This will help you get ideas and confidence from other writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.'

**No Title**
On the last day of a bad year, I was waiting at the Baltimore train station for the 10:10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people than I expected. The station did not feel clean and nice like it usually did. Older couples with matching bags filled the benches, and many college students had their bags on the floor.
A man with grey hair was walking around and talking to different people. He looked rich: he had tanned skin, a nice sweater, and a soft beige coat. He asked a woman sitting alone if she was going to Philadelphia. She said she was going north, but to New York. He thanked her and moved on.
Now, he came to an old lady and asked her if she was going to Philadelphia. She said she was going to Wilmington. He kept walking to a couple with matching bags. I was curious about him. I was going to Philadelphia too. I thought he could have asked me, but maybe he thought I looked unreliable. He quickly looked at me and then walked to the other end of the waiting area.
He looked stressed. He asked a woman reading a book, "Please tell me you're going to Philadelphia!" She looked up and said, "Yes, I am." He asked her for a favor. I stood a little away and pretended to look at my wrist, even though I didn’t have a watch. I could see the woman was getting cautious. The man said, "Nothing too difficult, I promise!"
They announced my train, and people started moving to Gate E, pulling their bags behind them. The man began to explain, "My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning and went home to find my wife upset. She hardly said 'hello' to me. My daughter forgot her passport and called from the station in Philadelphia. She didn’t know what to do."
The woman listened sympathetically. I thought it was better to stay quiet and see what he would say next. The man continued, "I told her to stay at the station, and I would get someone to bring her passport."
I thought it was strange. If it was such an emergency, why didn’t he go himself? The woman asked, "Why don’t you go yourself?" He replied, "I can’t leave my wife alone for that long. She’s in a wheelchair." I thought this was a weak excuse. 
I looked at them. The man was holding a packet, not a simple envelope, but a padded one, like a small book. I thought, "Watch out, lady!"

**Gary and Me**
John Moore is the owner of a restaurant. He talks about his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef. John believes everyone has a chance in life. Gary got his chance with cooking, and John got his chance to run a restaurant. When John heard about the restaurant, he quickly went to see it. It was in bad shape, but it was perfect for him.
Running the restaurant made John think of his childhood. His mother worked in a factory, and he felt sad when he was left alone. He wanted to have time for family. John's wife took care of the children and helped with the money, while John ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always had meals together. This helped their children, Gary and Joe, become confident. From a young age, they talked to the restaurant's customers, which was good for them.
Gary was a lively child. When he was seven, he jumped into a corner bath like it was a swimming pool and hurt himself. As he grew older, he worked for pocket money. He did small jobs and by ten, he was in the kitchen every weekend, earning a lot of money at school. He was very disciplined and woke up early. In a family business, everyone helps out, and John liked seeing Gary work.
Gary was not very good at school, but he was great in the kitchen. By 15, he was as good as the adult cooks and sometimes was in charge. He could make over a hundred meals. John knew Gary would work in catering because he had talent. When Gary needed work experience for school, John sent him to a friend’s restaurant.
Recently, Gary started playing the drums and has his own band. John worries about what will happen to Gary's cooking if the music becomes successful. He advised Gary to focus on one thing to be successful. John told him, "If you want to achieve something, do it by 30. After that, it may be too late."
At 17, Gary went to catering college. On his first day, he finished his work very quickly. He chopped vegetables and sliced meats in just one hour. He even helped other students. Everyone is surprised by how successful Gary's TV cooking show has become. John is very proud of him. He always tells Gary that if you want something, you must work hard for it because no one gives you anything.
John believes that when you talk to your children, they may only remember a little of what you say. But he thinks Gary has listened and learned from him.

**Finding a Flat in Dublin**
Finding a good flat in Dublin that you can afford is very hard. The best way to find one is to know someone. If you have a friend who knows someone leaving a flat, that can help. But if you are new in Dublin, like Jo, you don’t have any contacts. Jo had to stay in a hostel and look for a flat. 
Dublin felt very big and new to Jo. She was nervous when she took the train to work there. She didn’t think about why she was going. Everyone at school thought she would leave her small town. They wanted to go to new places and have exciting lives. Some of her friends went to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family helped them. But Jo was going to Dublin alone.
Jo’s mother thought it was good for her to stay in the hostel. It was run by nuns, so her mother thought she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm because many hostels are cold. Jo’s sisters, who worked in a hotel, thought she was crazy to stay in a hostel for a week. But Jo didn’t know they were talking about her. She was busy answering an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, “Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom.” It was close to her job at the post office and seemed perfect. 
There was no line for this flat because it was looking for a “Third Girl Wanted.” Jo wondered if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked normal. It was a red-brick house with a basement, but the flat was upstairs. A girl with a college scarf was coming down the stairs. She looked unhappy and said, “This place is terrible. The girls are not nice.” 
Jo asked, “What happened?” The girl replied, “She just acted like she was better than us. We don’t want her here.” Jo continued up the stairs. 
“Hi,” said the girl with “Nessa” on her T-shirt. “Did you see that stuck-up girl?” Jo introduced herself, saying she worked at the post office. Nessa said they were about to have tea and offered Jo a mug. One mug had “Nessa,” one had “Pauline,” and the last one had “Other.” Nessa said, “We can put your name on a mug if you come to stay.”

**Behind the Dolphin's Smile**
People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them in seaside places, movies, and TV shows. But according to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, dolphins are in trouble. Mark Simmonds talks about the problems dolphins face.
Dolphins are special to us. They are very smart animals, they can feel human emotions, and they make us think of freedom in the ocean. We see this love for dolphins in TV shows like Flipper and Seaquest with Darwin. However, these happy images hide the real problems dolphins face in dirty and overfished seas.
The number of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has dropped by up to 89,000. You might think that such popular animals are protected by laws and cared for in special areas. Unfortunately, this is not true, and the lack of protection could lead to a big disaster for wildlife.
There are forty different types of dolphins in the world. In northern Europe, the most common dolphins are striped dolphins, common dolphins, bottlenose dolphins, and smaller harbour porpoises. The striped and common dolphins usually live far out in the sea and are seen in small groups. We do not know much about them. 
Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be seen near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and were often found in places like the Channel coast and the Thames River in Britain. Now, they can only be found in a few areas, like the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few that are left show signs of stress.
It is hard to know exactly why dolphin numbers are going down. Overfishing is taking away a lot of fish from the ocean, which also affects dolphins and porpoises. Porpoises need to find food quickly. If fish are taken from one area, they may not have enough time to find food in another area. They can also get caught in fishermen's nets, which they cannot see. 
In modern fishing, large nets are often left in the water or pulled quickly through the sea. In recent years, many dead dolphins have washed up on beaches in France and Cornwall. Marks and cuts on their bodies show that they died because they were caught in these nets.
Dolphins can also store waste and harmful substances in their bodies. For example, pesticides can build up in dolphins. Female dolphins produce milk that can contain these poisons, which can harm their babies. There is already one case of a young dolphin dying from its mother’s milk.
Another big problem for dolphins is noise from humans. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to understand their world. In the sea, noise travels much better than in the air. This noise pollution from ships and oil wells may disturb dolphins in ways we do not fully understand.

**GETTING FIT**
Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you feel balanced, especially when life feels busy and stressful. Many articles talk about fitness because it is really good for you. 
There are many reasons to exercise and very few reasons not to. Exercise helps your muscles and changes your body shape. It makes your muscles stronger and helps you stand and sit better. It can also stop muscle problems that might cause injuries. Exercise can quickly improve areas like your thighs, stomach, and arms. It is good for your heart, lungs, and blood flow.
You might have heard these reasons many times, so you may not pay attention anymore. But here is something important: exercise can help with feelings of sadness and tiredness. It can also help you sleep better and reduce stress. Exercise can even help with some health problems.
If you are not convinced yet, just think about it: exercise is good for you. There are many types of exercise you can do, like aerobics, jogging, or using weights. But remember, if you train too hard or lift too much weight, you might get hurt. Start slowly and carefully. If you are unsure, ask your doctor what is best for you.
Good posture is very important. It affects how you look and feel. If you slouch, try to imagine that a balloon is pulling the top of your head up. This can help you stand taller and breathe better. Good posture also makes your body look slimmer.
Stretching is also important. It helps you move better and keeps your muscles from getting hurt. If you stretch four or five times a week, you will feel more flexible and fit. Stretching should be a part of your exercise routine, and you should do it slowly and carefully.
The best exercise routine includes warming up, stretching, a good workout, and cooling down afterward.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**
What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman stay away from home for many months? They are looking for the perfect shot. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, it is hard to find producer Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman. Right now, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, where it has rained a lot for six months. This has caused some problems. Newman said they had to buy a special piece of equipment. This helps Amanda pull him out when their vehicle gets stuck in the mud.
Amanda and Owen have made some of the best wildlife films on TV, like their famous film about leopards. While this film was being shown, they were already back in the field, looking for another shy animal, the jackal. This is normal for film-makers. They travel around the world to film interesting wildlife since television started.
I talked to Newman at a safari lodge, where he was meeting other people. He said, "We do have some arguments, but we get over them quickly." Neither of them thinks they are the leader. They get along well because they see the animals in the same way. 
When they travel, they set up their tents each night. But now, they have a fixed camp. They wake up at 5 a.m. and make tea the night before to keep it warm. They eat pre-packed meals that they heat up. Newman said, "We can be out for up to eight weeks, so cooking can be a bit stressful."
It can be tough, but being in remote areas lets them get close to the animals. Newman remembers filming a family of lions. One lioness would go off alone and then come back to greet her family. She even greeted their car as part of her round.
Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift." Two years later, they filmed Arctic foxes together. Since then, they spend four months in one place to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before they start, they must submit a script for approval.
Newman said, "Amanda and I had a good working relationship from the start because we shared the same ideas. We want to make a film that shows the true spirit of the place and the animals. We want to touch people's hearts. If you can make people feel something, that is better than just making them think."

**The Netball Captain**
In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day. She taught at a local school and then trained in a supermarket car park. I was surprised to hear about her training place. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I focus on my movements and my feet, so I don’t see much else. I might notice cars slowing down, but that’s all."
Kendra said, "My whole life is about being my best for the Championships." She follows a strict schedule to be fit. This is her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries joining. "We will have home support, which is very special," she said. "It is important to improve the reputation of netball in our country. There will be more pressure because we are playing at home. People expect us to start well."
Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra said, "We have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play. They are very skilled." The England team is ranked fourth in the world. Kendra knows the Championships will be hard. "You must push yourself every day. There is no rest between games. In a series, you can lose the first game and still win. But in the Championships, you only have one chance."
In the fifteen years she has played at a high level, netball has become harder and faster. "You train hard to win," Kendra said. "But after the game, we are all friends." Netball is also using more science for fitness testing. "We must think and train like world-class players," Kendra explained. As captain, she believes it is important to have a strong mind and to lead by example. "I support and encourage my team."
Kendra said, "My netball career has always been planned." She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She may coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have tears in her eyes. Her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.

**In Hot Water**
Rachel Mills is a scientist. She spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel teaches and does research about marine geochemistry. This means she studies the chemicals in the sea. She works at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University.
When Rachel is not teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle. This vehicle is for exploring underwater and is the size of a small car. She dives three kilometres down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, there is not much space. Rachel says, "I can touch the two pilots. We cannot stand up or move. We must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside." A dive can last for 16 hours. It takes three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up.
If there is a problem and she needs to get to the surface quickly, Rachel can press a panic button. This makes a small escape vessel come out. It goes quickly to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, but Rachel thinks it would not be a nice trip.
Rachel remembers her first dive. She got into the vehicle with an instructor on a ship. He explained what to do in an emergency, like if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would react in a small space.
Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place five days away from the Canary Islands. There, on the ocean floor, are many underwater volcanoes that blow out black smoke. The Russian team was leaving some scientific equipment to study a project that would make a hole 150 metres through a volcano.
When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre. Two-thirds of her salary comes from teaching, which she loves. She teaches so she can do her research on "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes. Water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It comes out at one metre per second and is very hot, at 350 degrees.
The only time Rachel felt scared was during her first dive with American scientists. They were towing equipment when there was a loud explosion. She thought, "I'm going to die." They waited in silence, but nothing happened. They were very relieved to be alive!
Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure. Every time Rachel looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels amazed. She thinks, "I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else has seen this." Rachel studied black smokers for three years for her Ph.D. When she saw them for real, it was an incredible feeling.

**Interview Tips**
First impressions are very important. Studies show that people make opinions about us in the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body movements, how fast or slow we talk, our voice volume and tone, and the words we say.
Mary Pearce wanted to be a teacher. She worked hard to get her degree. When she graduated, she felt very confident. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. That morning, she saw a small hole in her jacket. She thought about changing, but she didn’t want to be late. She believed it was important to be on time. Mary did not get the job. A friend who teaches at the school told her that the Head Teacher said, "If someone does not take the time to look their best at an interview, what kind of teacher will they be?"
Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "People who look like they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People think what is inside is important, but in an interview, you should try to look your best."
Many people forget how important it is to have a professional image. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a big accounting firm. When her boss retired, she applied for the job but did not get an interview. She thought it was a mistake and asked the Director of Personnel what happened. He told her she did not fit the image of an office manager and suggested she improve her wardrobe before applying again. Janet was shocked. She believed she did a good job and that her clothes should not matter.
How we move and use our hands also affects what the interviewer thinks. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 7% of our message comes from the words we use, 38% from our voice, and 55% from our facial expressions. If our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will pay more attention to our body language. So, make sure your words match your body language. Mixed messages can confuse the interviewer.
It is also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion. Her interview went very well, and she was offered the job right away. She was very happy but showed too much excitement. The boss saw how excited she was and offered her a lower salary than she wanted. She thinks she could have gotten more if she had controlled her excitement.
Finally, what we say and how we say it can help us succeed in an interview. David Artesio, a manager of an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. For example, the annual report can tell you about the company. Mention something that interests you during the interview. This shows you are interested in the company.
Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confusing sentences. She says, "Poor communicators talk in long sentences. Successful communicators use short sentences and clear points."

**A NEW LIFE**
**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years. He thought it was fun at first, but then it became boring. He did not plan to leave his job yet, but he lost it suddenly. He did not get a lot of money when he left, but it was enough to start his farm. He met a chef from a well-known hotel, and he started selling meat to them. Now, he also sells meat online. He is happy to be out of the office, but he still works a lot, about 80 to 90 hours a week.
**The Painter**  
Ron Able was a manager in advertising, but now he is an artist. He started painting as a hobby and found it more exciting than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. A career counselor helped him. Ron told the counselor that he did not want to go back to his old job, which surprised the counselor. Most people want to find work quickly for money. Ron and his wife moved to the north of England, where they did not know anyone. They left their friends, but they still keep in touch, and many friends visit them.
**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat business in her London flat. She enjoyed being a lawyer and made good money, but she worked long hours. She did not want to work more hours to become a senior partner, so she left. Many people thought she would get bored, but she did not. She has deadlines to keep her busy. She feels happier and less stressed now. However, she misses talking to her colleagues. She loves being responsible for her work. If she does a bad job, she knows it is her fault. When she worked for a company, she cared, but now she cares even more because her name is on the products.
**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started working in finance when he was 22. He liked the excitement but did not find it rewarding. He almost lost his job in 1989, so he decided to leave and travel for a year. During that year, he thought about what he wanted to do. He was interested in health, so he visited gyms and talked to the owners. He knew he needed training to change careers, so he took massage courses. Then, he got a part-time job at the Life Centre. He has no regrets about his choice. He feels more in control of his life now and is very happy.

**Dedicated to Their Sports**
Four young sports stars talk about their lives.
**A Darius (runner)**  
I have always loved sports. I played many sports, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football club, but I chose to focus on athletics instead. My best moment was when I competed for my country in the youth team and won a medal. Sadly, not many people noticed, and I hoped to get some sponsorship because training is expensive. I train at home all winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It is fun there with good training facilities and nightlife. But I have to be disciplined. If my friends invite me out the night before training, I have to say no. I wish I could go, but dedication is important in this sport. My main goal is to reach the next Olympics - that would be amazing.
**B Gabriel (surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so I meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are early in the morning. If I want to succeed, I have to skip late-night parties. I don’t mind too much, but I love sleeping in, and I have to give that up too. But it is worth it because I won the National Championships last year. After a win, I always celebrate, and if I win money, I go somewhere nice. Winning the championship helped me get a job to present a surfing show on TV. Now, I am a bit of a celebrity.
**C Dieter (yacht racer)**  
When I am on a boat with my friends, we have a lot of fun. We are traditional and celebrate wins in style. Some people say we act a bit childish, but we don’t look for media attention. Sometimes reporters care more about our celebrations than our race results. I am away for eight months a year, so it is nice to come back and hang out with my friends. You can’t always focus on sports; it is not healthy. I am known in sailing, but not many people recognize me on the street. I don’t want to be a celebrity. I get nice letters from fans who want signed pictures, and I reply to every one, even if it takes time.
**D Tomas (tennis player)**  
It feels great to walk on the court and hear the crowd cheer for me. At my last tournament, it got a bit crazy with many people around. I enjoy being recognized by fans when I am out shopping. But it has some problems too. My last girlfriend didn’t like it when I got attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that is why we broke up. It was hard, but you have to make sacrifices in sports; you need to be serious and professional. I focus on my game now and will catch up on other things in life after I retire, which happens early in this sport.

**Young Shoppers**
Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very hard for parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it’s not the newest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I can’t buy everything, and when I say yes, I feel bad for buying unhealthy food. But I also feel bad when I say no all the time. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but I worry they need to learn how to make choices. I can’t win."
Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes in a supermarket. More than £150 million is spent on advertising for children, mostly on TV. This amount is likely to grow, and supermarkets are a good place for this advertising. Children often do not understand why their parents say no to certain things. Parents worry about how much sugar is in food, but children are influenced by the fun ads they see on TV.
Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always right. It is good for parents and children to talk about food. If children only hear about products from ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents feel they are competing with ads and often disappoint their children."
The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, does not allow ads to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But Dibb says, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. So even if they can’t say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."
Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she talks about food with her children, and now her son thinks ads are not good. "We don’t have many problems in the supermarket now because my children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."
Parents also admit they are not always consistent with their children’s requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We don’t buy him sweets because we say they are bad for him, but we buy cream and chocolate for ourselves. It is nice to buy good things, and it is normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on how I feel. If I am happy, I am more likely to say yes. It is hard to be consistent."
Supermarkets could help reduce problems between parents and children by moving sweets away from the checkout areas or by having play areas for children. Even if parents spend less money without their children, shopping without their demands would likely bring in more customers.

**The Merrion Hotel: Luxury and Technology**
The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It took almost two years to change four old houses into this hotel. The hotel has the latest technology to help both the staff and the guests.
Peter MacCann is the General Manager. He wants his staff to know the guests' names. For more details about what guests like, he uses a computer system. This system helps the hotel give special service to returning guests. It cost £250,000 to set up, but MacCann believes it will be worth it over time. He is happy with how well it works. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first visit, those CDs will be ready for them when they come back.
Many hotel guests often complain about room temperature. The hotel has a system that lets guests change the temperature in their rooms. They can adjust it by three degrees around the normal temperature of 18°C. The front desk can also change the temperature between 14°C and 25°C.
The hotel is also good for business guests. MacCann thinks that about 65% of the guests will be business travelers. To help them, the hotel has put a business center in each room. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that can also copy and print, and a video-conferencing system.
Technology changes quickly, so the hotel has prepared for new improvements. They have added extra cables for future technology. The televisions are rented, so they can be replaced with newer models when needed. DVD recorders can also be updated.
Even with all this technology, MacCann wants guests to feel comfortable. The hotel has 145 large and cozy bedrooms. There is also a swimming pool, a gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.
The food at the hotel is very important. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, has moved his restaurant to the Merrion. He has designed a new kitchen and improved the restaurant. The hotel benefits from having a great place to eat without financial risks.
With good technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is likely to be very successful.

**Where I Get My Energy**
Emma Marsden asked six women how they get their energy in life.
A. **Jeanette Kupfermann, Journalist and Author:** "I get my energy from excitement. I like to do things that are challenging. When I learn something new, I feel very energetic. I also love rhythm. Right now, I am learning flamenco dancing. Dancing is great; it makes me feel alive. If I am bored, I feel tired. Doing something useful, even a little, gives me energy."
B. **Linda Kelsey, Magazine Editor:** "I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it. I love my job, so it does not feel hard. If you like what you do, you don’t feel sad, even if you are tired. I need a good amount of sleep. When I sleep six hours a night, I feel a bit tired. I know exercise gives me energy, but it can be hard to find the energy to do it! I go to a yoga class once a week and try to exercise at home. After I exercise, I feel much better. I often feel low in the afternoon, so I think it’s good to eat something then."
C. **Annie Nightingale, Disc Jockey:** "I don’t eat very healthily for energy. I think my energy comes from being positive and excited. I don’t like negative people. I believe we should enjoy life. It is important to achieve things and set goals. I love my job, and the last two years have been exciting. I work with many young and lively people, which makes me happy. I enjoy taking photos, even if I’m not the best at it. I also write words for fun songs when I travel."
D. **Floella Benjamin, Author and TV Presenter:** "My energy comes from doing things I enjoy. I believe in what I do, both at work and with my family. Being positive helps me. I love working with kids because they are full of energy. Energy is like a natural feeling that comes from talking to others. Just smile at someone and see how good it feels when they smile back. I try to eat healthy food and don’t smoke or drink, but I don’t have a special exercise plan. I get my energy from playing with kids."
E. **Deborah Moggach, Author and Playwright:** "What I love most is making a garden from nothing. I once turned a concrete area into a garden by breaking the concrete and adding soil. It was better than any workout. Knowing that someone wants to read my writing gives me energy too. I also like to explore private lands, and if I get caught, I say I didn’t know it was private. I enjoy it because it feels fun and childlike."
F. **Katherine Monblot, Therapist:** "I believe you should care about what you do in life. I like to take risks and get bored easily, which keeps me motivated. Doing things I don’t want to do makes me tired. I used to be part of many committees, but I didn’t like how they took my time. You only have a certain amount of energy, so use it for what is most important to you."

**ICE SKATING**
Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists found skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until iron skates were made in Scandinavia around 200 AD. For rich people in Scandinavia, skating was an important skill. 
In the early 1900s, skating was seen as stylish. But in the 1924 Winter Olympics, an 11-year-old girl named Sonja Henie showed a new, more athletic way to skate. This made skating very popular. Today, skating combines art and sport. It is both beautiful and hard work.
For beginners, balance and control are very important. You can go faster as you get better. The way you hold your body helps with balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and lean a little forward. Relaxing is very important when you skate. 
To start skating, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with your back foot and make a small movement with the other foot. It is not too hard! If you keep practicing, you can make bigger movements as you get better.
Learning how to fall is one of the first things a skater should know. Even the best skaters fall sometimes. To fall safely, try to stay relaxed. This helps you not get hurt when you hit the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand up.
Once you can skate confidently, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance skating, speed skating, and skating in pairs. It is best to start with figure skating and then learn freestyle. Most ice rinks have teachers who can help you learn the basics and then teach you turns, jumps, and spins.
If you watch good skaters, you will see how relaxed they are and how easily they move. To skate well, you should practice exercises regularly. It can be dangerous to skate if your body is stiff. Warm-up exercises should include stretching your legs, back, and shoulders, especially your ankles and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to avoid stiffness.
Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also helps your heart and lungs and makes your body stronger. When combined with swimming or jogging, skating is a great way to stay healthy and fit.

**Trills and Bills**
Seeing a talented child win a medal can make you very happy. Julia Gregson talked to three young stars and their mothers about their lives.
A. **Annika Reeder, 15**  
Annika won a gold medal for gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The training is very hard right now. I don’t have time to watch TV, go out with friends, or do much besides gymnastics and school. I take it one day at a time. When I am very tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can’t take too many days off because it makes you stiff."
B. **Annika's Mother**  
"Annika showed great talent from a young age. I have seen some parents push their children, but it doesn’t work. To perform at Annika's level takes a lot of time and energy. You have to want to do it yourself. People say we, as parents, have given up a lot, but they don’t see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it has done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was very shy, but now she has met people from all over the world and is more confident."
C. **Sarah Stokes, 12**  
Sarah started show-jumping at ten and has won the British National Championship. "It’s good that my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. The shows can last from one to five days. I never get tired of it; I love it! Even if my parents weren’t there, I would still do it because I am very determined. My goal this year is to qualify for the British young riders team. My big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."
D. **Sarah's Mother**  
"From the moment Sarah sat on a horse at age 1, I knew she loved it. When she was 5, she would wake up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for big shows, we travel all over England. To save money, we sleep in the horse box. Sarah is very organized and happy on a horse. Watching your child succeed at something they love is amazing."
E. **Jane McShane, 10**  
Jane is the Under-14 Chess Champion in Britain. "Tournaments are friendly. I know everyone and it’s fun. When I play, I don’t concentrate as much as I should. I just look around and don’t think too much. I don’t talk about my success at school because I don’t want to feel embarrassed."
F. **Jane's Mother**  
"Jane played her first chess game when she was 5. My father wanted to see if she liked it. I was bored when my father tried to teach me, but Jane loved it right away. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves, and by age 6, she was beating adults. I am happy when she wins, but if she wanted to stop playing tomorrow, I would support her. I don’t want to hold her back because she is so talented. If she has this gift, I want her to use it."

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, he is 2.28 meters tall and is the tallest man in Britain.
Every ten years, people in Europe get a little taller. More tall people are being born. This does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are going back to how we were as cavemen. We are getting better nutrition now, which is helping us grow taller. Professor Chris Stringer says, "We are becoming like Cro-Magnons again," who lived 40,000 years ago.
For most of human history, our ancestors ate many different foods. Women gathered fruits and berries, while men hunted animals. They ate from 85 different wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, farming started. This changed everything. Now, most of the world's land is used for farming. Three main plants - wheat, rice, and maize - give us more than half of our food today. This simple diet has hurt our health. 
In Ohio, scientists found that when people started farming corn, they became sick and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn was not good for health, according to some experts. But farming spread because one piece of land could feed many more people than hunting could. 
Today, many people are still not well-nourished. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets getting better again. Now, the average man in the US is 1.79 meters tall, in Holland 1.80 meters, and in Japan 1.77 meters. This is good news, but there are still problems. 
Even though people are getting taller, beds have not changed in size since 1860. Also, there is less space for legs in planes and trains. Clothes companies have to change their sizes often. 
The question is: how tall can we get? We cannot keep growing forever. Some scientists think we might reach a height of 1.93 meters this century. But there is a twist. While some people are getting taller because of better food, as a group, we might be getting shorter. 
10,000 years ago, during the last ice age, people were a bit rounder and taller to keep warm. Now that the climate is warmer, we seem to be getting thinner and shorter, even with good food. As the planet gets hotter, we might get even shorter. So, our growth could be affected by global warming.

**Studio Audiences**
What is it like to be in the audience when a TV show is being made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a common part of making television, but many people do not understand them. When we watch game shows, we see the audience getting excited and wonder, "Who are these people?"
Some people think studio audiences are not important. They say that even people who work in TV do not respect them. I thought studio audiences were just made up of silly people who want to be on TV for a moment. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from different backgrounds and jobs. TV shows try to attract different types of people for different programs.
Many people who watch TV at home do not understand why anyone would want to be in a studio audience. Why would someone apply for tickets, travel far, and sit for hours in a studio just to watch what they can see at home? One reason is that people hope to be on TV for a second. I did not believe this until I talked to Angela. She said, "I came for a chance to be on TV."
Another reason is that people are curious to see how a show is made. But the most common reason I heard was, "A friend gave me a ticket." Most of us have never been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it is like. You sit close to strangers while someone shows signs that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you clap or laugh when you see them. This is true for some shows, but not all. One studio manager said, "We believe a good show does not need these signs."
Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching TV at home? For Claire, being in a studio is "more exciting." Charlotte liked being part of live TV. She said, "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. When you watch him at home, you miss a lot." I missed seeing the live actors because I could only see the back of someone’s head. The opening scenes were far from where I sat, so I ended up watching the show on a monitor.
Going to a studio may not be the best way to watch TV, but that is not what matters. For most people in the audience, it was just fun and a free night of entertainment.

**Favourite Places**
**Bruce**  
I do not like wild landscapes. I like places with people. When I travel, I enjoy lovely villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I would ride my bike to the village of Lastingham in its beautiful valley. Cycling helped me relax from school. I loved exploring the hills, valleys, and old villages. I am from Scotland, so the landscape felt familiar but also different. I still visit there today. I wrote about my adventures in my diary. This was my first try at travel writing, which I later became known for.
**Sophia**  
There is a small train that goes from Hythe to Dungeness, run by volunteers. I always travel first class because it is not much more expensive than regular tickets. The views are not amazing. The train goes over Romney Marsh with its sheep and next to a canal. But there is one part of the journey I love - when the train goes through back gardens. For a few moments, we see people doing everyday things, like making tea or folding chairs. I see myself in their eyes, a woman in a small train, looking into their homes. I like the simple landscape of fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. It makes me look closer and find new things.
**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a quiet and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to reach and have many rocks, so there are not many people here. Some brave surfers come, but most visitors just enjoy the sea. This coast faces the Atlantic and is known for shipwrecks. There are walking paths along the coast that you can combine with trips into beautiful valleys with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in a simple place with a family in the village of Southole.
**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland. It is a wide-open moorland, perfect for hiking. There are not many people living there or visiting. It is a quiet and empty place, and I like the feeling of space. I found this area by chance when I was a student, and I visit every year, either alone, with my boyfriend, or now with my son. It has not changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits special. I feel sad that he is growing up in a city.
**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. I wanted peace and to connect with my English roots. I grew up in what is now Sri Lanka, but when I was twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and village streets. There was a story about a place we would never cycle past: if you went down the driveway, you would never come back. That place was Glenthorne. It is my dream place. It is a magical, quiet, romantic house. You can only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**
We are a family that loves animals. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work. She was very excited because she found a pine snake. "Can we keep him?" she asked. I said, "Yes, but only for one night." We had a special tank to keep animals for a short time. 
I got home late. I quickly put a pot on the stove to boil. Suddenly, I heard my sons screaming, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I ran to their room. The problem was with our cat, Domino, and a white mouse named Bianca. I got Bianca as a Mother's Day gift. 
Domino was running around the room with the mouse in his mouth. He wanted to escape with his catch. I jumped into the room but tripped and fell on the floor. I saw the snake escaping from the table and slithering on the floor. 
The snake was moving while the kids and the cat were jumping around, making a lot of noise. The dog was barking too. The pot in the kitchen boiled over, and I ran to turn it off. I came back with more energy. I grabbed Domino by the tail and saved the mouse from him. 
Later, I looked at the snake. I wanted to catch it, but it was hard. I sat on the floor and tried to calm the snake down. Slowly, the snake relaxed and rested its head on its body. I carefully lifted the snake and walked to the end of the garden. I wanted to let it go near a tree. 
When I finally let go of the snake, it surprised me. Instead of running away, it climbed up on my shoulders like a warm scarf. We stood there together, with my four children and the snake. My oldest son, DJ, said, "Mum, you are warm, and the shed is not." 
I asked the kids to help me encourage the snake to move. Slowly, it went up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last part of the snake left, my three-year-old son, Clay, sighed and said, "Wow, that was one big snake!"

**Drop Me a Line!**
In our fast world with phones and computers, writing letters is becoming rare. But for me, getting a letter is special. There is excitement when it arrives, joy in seeing who sent it, and happiness in reading it.
I have written letters for a long time. It started with little notes to my mother. She always made me write thank-you letters for gifts. It did not matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters. When I was 18 and moved to London to study medicine, I wrote to my mother every week, and she wrote back. Sometimes my father wrote too, and I loved his funny letters. Most letters from home talked about everyday life with my parents and their friends. We also called each other, but I remember the letters more.
I also received letters from my boyfriends. Many of them had to work or study far away, so we wrote to each other. Writing letters helped our relationships. I found it easier to express my feelings in writing than by talking. I love letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but it is even better to get a lot of news in a letter! I especially like letters in airmail envelopes with pretty stamps.
I get letters from friends in different countries. One friend is Mangala from Sri Lanka, and I have a penfriend in Australia and another in Vancouver. There is also a lady from France who writes to me. We started talking in a restaurant after a holiday. If I had not asked for her address, I would not have been able to write to her. Luckily, she replied, and now we write to each other regularly. I can practice my French with her because she does not speak English. We have visited her home twice, and she has stayed with us.
My best letter-writing story is from this summer. My family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was surprised that we kept in touch for so long. The local newspaper even wrote about us!
I am happy that my children are also writing letters. Like my mother, I make them write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did for my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas, set up by my penfriend. I really hope that letter writing does not become a lost art.

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art**
Many ancient pictures carved into rocks in France are being damaged. There are about 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego, in the French Alps. Scientists are worried that these drawings will not last for future generations. The mountain has drawings that are 4,000 years old. They show cows, fields, and different gods and goddesses. 
More and more tourists are visiting the site, but some are ruining the pictures with graffiti. Jean Clottes, who leads the International Committee on Rock Art, says, "People think these pictures will always be here. But if the damage continues, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He has seen tourists walking on the drawings and damaging them. Some visitors even take pieces of the rock as souvenirs. 
When tourists cannot take a good photo, they rub the drawings to make them clearer. The weather has already polished the drawings, and when the sun shines, some people rub them to see them better. Some visitors bring sticks to scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks.
Experts have different ideas about how to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, from the Museum of Natural History in Paris, thinks the best way to save the site is to make it a "no-go" area. This would mean only guided tours could visit. He believes that if we do not protect the site, it will be destroyed, and important research will stop. 
But Clottes disagrees. He thinks de Lumley’s idea is too strict and will upset local people. He says, "The site is a historic monument, and we must do everything we can to save it." 
David Lavergne, a regional architect, also wants to keep the site open. He says, "De Lumley’s idea is not the best. We want people to see the site, but it is hard to stop damage because it is so big. We may need to charge a fee to help pay for guards." 
Annie Echassoux, who has studied the site, is worried that as it becomes easier to reach, more damage will happen. She believes the best solution is to close off parts of the area and have guides. "We need money to protect this historic site," she says. "If we do not act, we will lose these drawings for the next generation."
