**Going Up the Wall**
Climbers used to go to the mountains to climb. Now, people can climb indoors or outdoors. The crowd is excited. High above them on a climbing wall is a French climber named Francois Lombard. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships in Birmingham. This place is also known for the TV show Gladiators, but both events have one thing in common - The Wall.
In the past, climbers practiced on cliffs. They climbed in places with good climbing spots. In winter, they had to deal with cold weather or climb on snow and ice in Scotland. As climbing became more popular, it was important for climbers to stay fit. Since they could not use cliffs for much of the year, they started to climb on brick edges or stone buildings. This helped them keep their fingers strong and stay busy.
Soon, many sports centers built climbing walls. These walls were made with special bricks that climbers could hold on to. One of the first climbing walls was made by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher, in the mid-1960s at Leeds University. He put natural rock in concrete to create a climbing wall.
In the 1970s, many climbing walls were built in sports halls, but they had problems. The walls were straight up and down, while real cliffs have different shapes like overhangs. Once the walls were built, they could not be changed, and climbers got bored of the same routes.
In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny created a new material that looked like the shapes on cliffs. This material could be attached to any wall and removed when climbers wanted something new. French companies also started to make climbing walls with steel frames. Steel was lighter than concrete, so they could build overhanging walls easily. This new system gave climbers many different holds to use.

**So You Want to Be an Actor**
If you tell someone you want to be an actor, they might say it is a risky choice. Acting is a risky job because there are many actors but not enough roles for them. When you decide to be an actor, some friends may think you are crazy, but others may support you. Everyone will give you different advice. 
Becoming an actor is a personal choice. You are responsible for your own dreams. There are no easy ways to become an actor. There are no tests to pass, and finishing your training does not guarantee you will get a job. Success depends on luck and talent. 
There is a need for new actors, and acting can be exciting and rewarding. Many people want to know what talent is. I think talent is a mix of natural skill and imagination. Imagination is hard to measure. It also depends on a person’s courage and belief in what they do.
Why do people want to act? It can be hard to explain. In theater, the important moment is when the actor connects with the audience. This connection is what makes actors want to perform. 
If you ask successful actors how they did it, they might not know. They understand some things about their skills, but they do not take success for granted. They know they must keep working hard because their fame can change quickly. 
Disappointment is a big challenge for actors. Last month, you might have been without work, doing other jobs. Then, you may get a chance to audition for a role. But even if you want the job, you might not get it. Because of this, actors often do not talk about their chances of getting a role. They find ways to deal with the stress of competition and rejection. 
No one likes to be rejected. This possibility is there from the moment you start auditioning. You are saying you are ready and hopefully talented enough for the job. In many ways, it is up to you. If you do not care enough, others may not care about you either.

**Food for Everyone**
We are happy to share our special selection of the best cookbooks available. 
A. When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, they often think of Delia Smith. Her recipes come from many places around the world. She loves exciting food and knows what the average cook can do in a normal kitchen. The book that made her famous is called *Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course*. This book is now a must-have for modern cooks. It gives simple and expert advice on cooking, with many great recipes that are not boring. This book is perfect for anyone who wants to have just one cookbook.
B. Raymond Blanc became a famous chef in just 15 years. He is the owner of the most famous French restaurant in Britain. Now, he has a book to go with his first TV show called *Blanc Mange*. Raymond wants to help everyone become better cooks. He explains how and why certain ingredients work together. He believes cooking is easy when you understand what happens in the pan. His book has over 80 amazing recipes that show this. It also explains why some dishes can go wrong and teaches some basic food science. Raymond loves to cook for others, and this book shows he is very good at it.
C. Le Cordon Bleu is a name that means the best in French cooking. For 100 years, expert chefs at this famous cooking school have trained many students. To celebrate its 100th anniversary, they have released a new book called *Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook*. This book has 100 of the school's best recipes. The recipes are classic but still fresh. Le Cordon Bleu has always supported traditional French cooking but has also changed some recipes to make them healthier. The book starts with basic cooking tips and then has sections for Appetisers, Main Dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe has step-by-step pictures and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Chefs from Cordon Bleu schools around the world have shared their famous recipes and secrets in this book.
D. Fast food? No way! Many people think good food takes a long time to cook. But Nigel Slater, the food editor of The Observer, disagrees. His new book, *The 30-Minute Cook*, shows that fast food can be good. Nigel believes you can make tasty food in the same time it takes to get a pizza. He has already written two successful books about this. In this new book, you will find many delicious recipes that are ready in just 30 minutes. Nigel has written over 200 recipes from around the world in a fun and easy style. Just because he likes fast food doesn’t mean he doesn’t love good food. If you think fast food can’t be great, try his recipes—they are delicious!

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, he is 2.28 meters tall, making him the tallest man in Britain.
Every ten years, people in Europe get about one centimeter taller. More tall people are being born. This does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are going back to how we were as cavemen. We are getting better nutrition now, which is helping us grow taller. Professor Chris Stringer says, "We are becoming like Cro-Magnons again," who lived 40,000 years ago.
For most of human history, our ancestors ate many different foods. Women gathered fruits and berries, while men hunted animals. They ate from 85 different wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, farming started. This changed everything. Now, most of the world's land is used for farming. Three main plants - wheat, rice, and maize - give more than half of the food we eat today. This limited diet has hurt our health. 
In Ohio, scientists found that when people started farming corn, they became sick and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn was not good for health, but farming spread because it could feed more people than hunting. Many people are still not well-nourished, but some countries like the US, Japan, and those in Europe are starting to eat better again. 
Now, the average man in the US is 1.79 meters tall, in Holland 1.80 meters, and in Japan 1.77 meters. This is a good change, but there are still problems. Beds have not gotten longer since 1860, and there is less space in planes and trains. Clothes companies have to change their sizes often. 
The question is: how tall can we get? We cannot keep growing forever. Some scientists think we might reach a height of 1.93 meters this century. But there is a twist. While some people are getting taller because of better food, as a group, we might actually be getting shorter. 
10,000 years ago, during the last ice age, people were a bit rounder and taller to keep warm. Now that the climate is warmer, we seem to be getting thinner and shorter, even with good food. As the planet gets hotter, we might shrink even more. So, our growth could be affected by global warming.

**A NEW LIFE**
**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years. Matt felt that working there was no longer fun. He did not plan to leave his job yet, but he lost it suddenly. He did not get a lot of money when he left, but it was enough to start his farm. He met the head chef of a well-known hotel. By selling meat to the hotel, more people learned about his farm. Now, he also sells meat online. Matt is happy to be out of the office, but he still works long hours, just like before.
**The Painter**  
Ron Able was a manager in advertising, but now he is an artist. He started painting as a hobby and found it more exciting than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. A career counselor helped him. Ron told the counselor that he did not want to go back to his old job. This surprised the counselor because most people want to find work quickly. Ron and his wife moved to the north of England, where they did not know anyone. They left their friends behind, but many of them still visit.
**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat business in her London flat. She enjoyed being a lawyer and made good money, but she worked very long hours. Katherine did not want to become a senior partner and work even more, so she left her job. Many people thought she would get bored, but she has not. She has deadlines to keep her busy. She feels happier and less stressed now. However, she misses talking to her colleagues. Katherine loves being responsible for her work. If she does a bad job, she knows it is her fault.
**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started working in finance when he was 22. He liked the excitement but did not find the work satisfying. In 1989, he almost lost his job, but he decided to leave and travel for a year. During that year, he thought about what he wanted to do. He was interested in health, so he visited gyms and talked to the owners. Paul knew he needed training to change careers, so he took massage courses. Then, he got a part-time job at the Life Centre. He has no regrets about his choice. Now, he feels in control of his life and is very happy.

**A Winning Game**
Two brothers are using their childhood game to make money. Dave and Norm Lagasse are in their forties and live in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA. They are playing a game called pichenotte, which they say is special. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, brought this game from Quebec, Canada, to the USA. The family played pichenotte every weekend and holiday. Dave remembers, "We had the best time ever."
When the family moved to New Mexico, they still played pichenotte with the board their grandfather made from old wooden crates. Visitors were curious because no one in southern USA knew this game. Three years ago, Dave saw that their old board was damaged, so he made a new one. His family and friends wanted to buy it. 
One night, the brothers took a new board to a sports bar in Santa Fe. At first, people thought it was a silly game, but soon they wanted to play! When people asked about the game’s history, Dave learned that it might have started in India with a game called 'carroms.' This game changed into 'squails' in Britain, and British people brought it to Canada. The French-Canadian version is called pichenotte.
Pichenotte can be played by two to four people. Each player has 12 pieces, called 'pucks.' They flick the pucks across a round board with their fingers. If a puck goes into a small hole, it is worth 20 points. There are also rings worth 15, 10, and 5 points, and eight small posts that are obstacles. The game usually lasts about two minutes.
Seeing how much people liked the game at the bar, the brothers made more boards and sold them at markets and craft fairs. Many people came to buy them, and soon there were pichenotte championships with a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup.' The brothers sold boards quickly and decided to make pichenotte their full-time job. They set up a workshop in their garage and have made over 450 boards. Each board is made of birchwood and mahogany, weighs 12 kg, and is 1 cm thick. Norm says, "They are very strong and last a long time."
The boards cost $595 each and can be bought from the brothers' website. There are no professional pichenotte players or TV shows yet, but the brothers hope to make a lot of money from their game. For now, they enjoy playing pichenotte in their free time.

WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE
When you enter the Model Village, it is hard to believe that a few years ago this was just a flat piece of land covered in weeds. For a long time, people thought it was useless land. One man, with the help of his wife, worked very hard to change this land into the beautiful village you see today. 
Many tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat land into a nice landscape. Machines like bulldozers helped, but a lot of hard work was done by hand. After shaping the land, about 1,000 tons of topsoil were added to create lawns, flower beds, and rock gardens. Hundreds of trees and bushes were also planted. These plants were chosen carefully because they needed to survive near the sea and strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were brought from Canada and New Zealand.
Colin Sims had the idea for the Model Village. He made over 100 models by himself over nine years, starting in 1972. The models are made from different materials like stone, concrete, wood, and plastic to last in all kinds of weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to learn about the materials, but soon he became an expert himself. 
You will see that all the models are made to the same scale and have many small details. This took a lot of patience and special building techniques. The Model Village is very popular and is known for its high quality. The methods used here have been used in other model villages in England and even in some college courses about modeling.
All the buildings in the village show traditional British styles and are not based on one specific place. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House, which is a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower. You will also see a Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest part of the village.
Please stay on the paths during your visit and do not touch the models. If you touch them, it can take us a long time to fix them. You can take photos from the paths only. Dogs are welcome if they are on a short lead.
To make your visit more fun, you will find buttons in front of some models. Press these buttons to see the models move. At the end of your visit, we would love to hear your comments. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us make the village more interesting. We also want to know if any models need to be fixed. 
We hope you enjoy your visit and come back again. Please tell your friends about the Model Village!

Every week, British tabloid newspapers print pictures that invade people's privacy. These pictures often break the rules that newspaper editors should follow. Sometimes, pop stars take pictures with paparazzi, but this is not common. Usually, it hurts people in the public eye when their private moments are shown on the front page. Very few people ask for help from the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which was created to help with these problems. Most of the time, these pictures are not important for the public. For example, does a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony help solve a crime? The actress has complained about such pictures before. Since she was in a hotel, where people expect privacy, she had a good reason to complain, but she did not take action. It is a problem that the PCC did not start an investigation. 
The PCC should also look into a recent story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star has not made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action against these bad stories? This seems like a good idea. It could lead to many decisions against newspapers. Other newspapers would report this, and it would be on TV and radio. The public would not support these newspapers, and editors would stop publishing such stories. Photographers would also be affected and might not be able to hide and take pictures of celebrities anymore.
If the PCC decided to act like a "police officer," there would be some problems. How would they decide to start an investigation? Should they ask the person who was hurt to make a complaint? If that person does not want to complain, should the PCC still investigate? Celebrities might expect the PCC to look into every story about them and be upset if they do not. The PCC would have a very big job. How could they watch all the newspapers in Britain, including local ones and magazines? 
There is also the problem of embarrassment. Even if someone’s privacy is invaded, would they want to go through an investigation? Many people just want to forget about it and move on with their lives. Some might have other reasons to stay quiet. They might have a worse story that they do not want to become public if they complain. In this way, the PCC could also become a problem for them.
One British comedian had a bad experience with the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon. He did not complain then, and he did not complain later when a photographer took pictures of him and his family on holiday. He was afraid that the newspaper would use the pictures again and make a new story about his anger. They thought it was just a joke because he is a comedian. This fear is understandable. People think they will be targeted again if they challenge the tabloids. It is hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

Many college graduates get advice when they start their first job. This article talks about what to think about when you want to find your second job. We are not talking about people who want a temporary job while looking for a permanent one or those who leave a job they do not like after a few weeks. Instead, we focus on those who are ready to take a real step in their career. You have learned some skills and have an idea of what you want to do.
What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. You need to think about whether you want to specialize in one area, move up to a job with more responsibility, or change to a different field. Whatever you choose, be careful when picking your second job. You should plan to stay in this job for two to three years. Future employers will look closely at this job when you apply for your next one. It should show that you are serious about your career. Most importantly, this job should help you grow and give you more responsibilities.
If you want to travel, now is a good time to do it. You can work temporarily when you come back and then find your second job. Employers will be happy to see that you have traveled and are not likely to leave again soon.
Juliette Davidson worked for three lawyers after leaving St. Aldate's College. It was a good first job because they were supportive. She learned how to work in an office and improved her typing skills. However, there was no chance to move up in that job. One day, she decided to leave, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year.
Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. She says, "In two and a half years, I have learned a lot and my job has grown." From the start, her boss wanted to help her develop. Her job title is the same, but her tasks have changed. She now does most of the letters and budgets and answers questions from important people and those wanting to start their own business. Brenda includes her in all her work and gives her special projects and events to organize.

'Confident People: What’s Their Secret?'**
Confident people seem like they were born that way, but many say it is a skill they learned. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.
**A. Jenny**  
When I left school, I was very shy. I thought I would always be shy. When I was about twenty-five, I helped at my daughter’s school. I was nervous, but I did well. Someone suggested I take a university course. On my first day, I was very scared, but my confidence grew over time. Working at the school changed my life.
**B. Michaela**  
Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to run the family business. I was scared and became too aggressive. I thought that was how confident people acted, but I learned that confidence is about believing in yourself. If work is too much, I don’t feel guilty if I leave some tasks for the next day. When I face something hard, I remind myself that I have nothing to lose. Fear can make you feel less confident, so I talk to myself to calm down.
**C. Lisa**  
People think I am very confident, but I often feel scared inside. I learned to look confident because it is important in my job on TV. Interviewing people showed me that many of us feel nervous in important situations. My mother gave me good advice when I was a teenager. She said, “Who is looking at you? Everyone is too busy worrying about themselves.” I remember this often. I also believe you gain confidence by facing your fears. I was very nervous during my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt I could handle anything.
**D. Barbara**  
I feel confident because I enjoy my work, but I built this confidence over time. If you keep working and learn from mistakes, you will feel more confident. I work hard and people like me, but not everyone does. That’s okay. You need to like yourself and not worry about what others think. My company offers training courses, which help me feel better about myself. It is good to set small goals so you can see your progress.
**E. Kim**  
After college, I worked as a secretary. I would sit in meetings and not always agree, but I was too scared to speak. Eventually, I found the courage to share my thoughts. When I started working in politics, I had never spoken in public before and I was very nervous. I told myself, “Don’t be silly. People do this every day.” I also wrote down some notes to help me. I think everyone feels a little nervous when speaking in public. The secret to confidence is to keep telling yourself, “Nothing is impossible.”

**Visit to Malaysia**
Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival and spends a nervous night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled when I gave him his broken kite. "You have to keep it," he said. "It's traditional. If the line breaks, finders keepers... and I have many more." He showed me a pile of beautiful kites at his feet. All the kites were 120 cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and bamboo. We sat in the shade of the trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, and watched Malaysia's biggest kite festival.
In the middle of the beach, there were 10 platforms where helpers held up the kites. A line of nervous competitors held the lines of their kites and waited for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites flew into the sky like rockets. More than 500 men and boys had signed up for the competition, which lasts for five days every year. Each person had four different kite designs. The kites were judged on how they looked, how stable they were in the air, and how well they flew.
"Flying kites isn't hard," said Adnan, "but making them takes real skill. Come to my house, and I will show you how to make one." I got five invitations that day, and I decided to go to his house. There, I drank cold tea and ate fish crackers in a big, nice room. As it got dark, he asked me to come back the next day to help him fix his kite, but I could not. Instead, I drove to the southern part of the state, heading towards Kuala Lumpur, into the mountains with thick rainforests.
I took a wrong turn, and the road ended at a river. A small boat was waiting to take people across. Nearby, I saw a sign that said: "Jelawang Jungle 3 km." Before I started walking, I should have known that most of the path was steep and slippery. When I reached the track, I met a man named Baba, who took care of a kitchen and some bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about the insects under my thin mattress. 
At night, it was very dark, and I heard many sounds. A waterfall was loud nearby, and many creatures were moving around. In the morning, I saw a great view of five green mountain ranges. In the afternoon, it rained. First, there was wind, then lightning hit the trees. I got soaked. As I slid down the hill, I wondered how the big butterflies avoided the rain. I also worried about my car getting washed away and if I would drown if I opened my mouth. Luckily, my car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the hill.
In Kota Bahru, the capital of Kelantan, everyone asked me questions: "Where are you from?" "How old are you?" But they were friendly. Kelantan is known for its kites, but I will remember it more for the kindness of the people.

What kind of shopper are you? We all go shopping, but we shop in different ways. Do you know what type you are? Abby Edwards asked some people about their shopping habits.
A. Melanie, 22, dancer  
"I love shopping! I can't spend enough money! When I have money, I go shopping and feel happy. I can't walk past sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we go shopping together a lot. We are both addicted to shopping!"
B. Brenda, 40, office manager  
"I don’t like shopping much. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks. I take my son and daughter shopping for clothes, but we all like different things. I don’t spend money on myself often, so when I do, I feel guilty and don’t tell my husband how much I spent."
C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager  
"I only shop for what I need. I don’t like shopping and only go when I have to. When I go, I know what I want and I don’t want anything else. Shopping makes me tired."
D. Anita, 35, TV producer  
"I like to look around sometimes, but I know what I want and where to find it. I don’t waste time. I do have some clothes I bought that I don’t wear, so maybe I make mistakes when I shop."
E. Lizzie, 41, secretary  
"I really don’t like shopping. I can never find what I want or get help. The shops are too noisy and messy. Luckily, I don’t shop for clothes much because I get most of my clothes for free. For food, I go to the supermarket once a week and do it quickly."
F. Lisa, 22, actress  
"I think I’m a happy shopper. Sometimes I go shopping with my friends, and we often buy things. I don’t usually go with something specific in mind, but if I see something I like, I buy it."
G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant  
"I’m a careful shopper. I like shopping, but I don’t buy a lot. I usually know what I want and don’t spend too much. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but then I feel worse because I spent too much money."
H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker  
"I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it’s too busy. I’m a careful shopper. I have an idea of what I want and I look in different shops to find the best price. It takes me a long time!"
I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager  
"I don’t like shopping. I work in the city, so shopping is not fun for me anymore. When I have to shop, I don’t try things on because it’s too much work. The clothes I buy don’t always fit, but I don’t care too much. I’d rather make mistakes than spend a lot of time shopping."

NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE
The Open University is a place where you can get a degree, just like other universities. The good thing is that you can study while you keep working. You can also learn about many different subjects. If you have never studied before, you will enjoy learning new things. You will meet many different people and make new friends. Your degree can help you find new jobs.
At the Open University, you do not go to classes in person. Instead, you study at home using television, radio, and computer programs. If you want, you can go to one class a month at an Open University center. There are exams to take, just like at other universities.
If you want to know more, please fill out the form below. This could be the start of an exciting new time in your life.

**Gallery News**
**Easter Quiz for Children**  
During the Easter holidays, children can join a fun quiz about surprises. You can get free quiz sheets at the desk by the Orange Street entrance. The quiz will take you to 14 surprising paintings, and you will answer different questions about them. The quiz sheets will be available from 25 March to 9 April during normal gallery hours.
**New Picture**  
The Gallery has a new still life painting by the Dutch artist Jan van Os from the 18th century. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) shows flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is one of the first paintings like this in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778. It is normal for artists to date their work in two years because they wait for flowers to bloom in different seasons. This painting was given to the Gallery by Miss Violet Churchman in memory of her sister, Ida Nancy. You can see it in Room 25.
**Special Exhibition**  
The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" started in the Sunley Room on 15 March. The Gallery has bought works by three Spanish painters from this time: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu. They are joined by Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italian artists who worked in Spain: Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition will be open until 31 May.
**Lecture News**  
There are lectures every Wednesday to go with the special exhibition. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will talk about Melendez. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will discuss Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will talk about Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists tell stories through their pictures.
**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**  
The Gallery is happy to say that the restaurant has improved and expanded. With new kitchens, the restaurant now offers many hot and cold dishes at good prices.
**Information for Visitors**  
Free guided tours of the Gallery happen every day at 11:00 am and 3:00 pm (except Sundays). These tours show some of the Gallery's best pictures and the important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

**Little Chefs**
A group of children aged ten to fifteen spends their Saturdays learning how to cook. Their classes are very popular, and there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course, where children can have fun and learn to make good food.
Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we eat the food we made together."
Flora is twelve years old. She has some trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really liked it. My mum told me to find a hobby instead of doing nothing on weekends. At first, I was happy at home and didn't want to go. But now, I am really glad I came."
Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's a lot of fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, even if the kitchen is not always clean when they cook! Adults keep learning about food. If parents teach their children to cook when they are young, they will know how to make food for themselves when they grow up."

**Outdoor Centre Fees**
The fees are for a car with four people. If you have more than four people, it costs 50p for each extra person. You need to pay the fees at the main office. The centre is not a private club. It is open to everyone who wants to enjoy outdoor sports and activities. If you are coming with a group, please tell the centre before your visit.
**Windsurfing - One-day Course**
We have beginner windsurfing courses on Saturdays and Sundays when the weather is nice. Learning to windsurf is very fun! You will remember the first time you sail across the water. We have boards with small sails for beginners. The cost is £32.50, and this includes all the equipment.
**One-day Adventure Course**
This is a great chance for you! You can try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. This course is for adults who want to learn outdoor activities in a fun way. You do not need to be very fit or have experience. You just need to be interested. The cost is £22.50.
**Play Park**
The Play Park is for children aged two to ten years. It is one of the best parks in the country. It has sand and water play, slides, a big ball pool, a play castle, and much more. Next year, we will open a new Play Palace and Play Ship.
**Group Day and Residential Courses**
We also have day and weekend courses for groups. Schools, colleges, and youth groups often visit us. We have three large rooms with twelve beds in each. You can book these rooms for groups of up to 36 people (at least 12 people).
**Summer Adventure Holidays (for ages 8-14)**
Activities include sailing, climbing, windsurfing, and fun games. 
Safety is very important at the Outdoor Centre. All staff are trained in First Aid and are qualified to teach the activities. We make sure that all children only do activities that are right for their age and abilities. For this program, children must be able to swim 25 meters and be in good health.

**STAMP COLLECTING - A FUN HOBBY**
Many people of all ages enjoy stamp collecting. It is a fun hobby that can last a long time. Starting your collection is easy because you can find stamps everywhere. You can get stamps from holiday postcards, birthday cards, and letters from friends.
When you start collecting stamps seriously, you might want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club. This club helps collectors get new British stamps. As a member, you can order special sets of stamps for your collection. You can receive these stamps in three ways:
1. We can send you a complete set of stamps in an envelope.
2. We can send you the same stamps in a colorful pack with interesting facts.
3. If you like, we can send you individual stamps for your own special book.
The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members. You can join too! A two-year membership costs just £5. If you join with a group, you can get a discount. This is a great deal! When you join, the Club will send you a Starter Pack for free. This pack has 100 stamps and a nice box to keep them in. You will also get a 4-page guide with tips on how to collect stamps and addresses of shops that sell them.
Every two months, you will receive a magazine from the club. The magazine has competitions, quizzes, and a chance to exchange stamps with members from around the world.
Why not start this fun adventure? You will enjoy looking at the different stamps in your collection and searching for new ones. Join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and have fun collecting stamps! To join, fill out the application form and send your membership fee. You will get your Starter Pack within 28 days.

MONEY
What is money? Money can be a pound, a dollar, or a franc. It is like a gram or a kilometre, but you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or two cinema tickets. But the note is just a piece of paper that does not cost much to make.
A long time ago, people did not have money like we do now. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green, the farmer, traded corn he grew for honey from Mr. Hive. This was a trade between two people who wanted what the other had.
Over time, many societies created their own types of money, called currencies, so people could trade more easily. Now, most countries use a national currency.

**Write a Winning Story!**
You can win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story printed in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other people will win £100. We need good stories from writers. The judges are Mary Littlejohn, a novelist, Michael Brown, a TV reporter, and Susan Hitchins, the editor of Keep Writing. They want interesting and original stories.
Last year, detective stories were very popular, but the winner wrote a love story. You can write about anything you like. Here are some tips to help you:
1. **Write About What You Know**: Write about things you understand. Last year, many stories were about love, family, and problems with friends. Make ordinary situations interesting so people want to read more.
2. **Get Your Facts Right**: Make sure your information is correct. If you describe a place or explain something, it must be right. Don’t write about things you are not sure about.
3. **Hold the Reader's Attention**: Start your story in an interesting way and end it with a surprise. A bad ending can ruin a good story. Develop your story carefully and think of something unusual for the end.
4. **Think About the Characters**: Make your characters feel real. Use good words to describe them.
Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, typed, double-spaced, and on one side of the paper only. We cannot accept stories by fax or email. You must include the application form with your story. We cannot return your story or discuss our decisions.
You should not have had any fiction printed in any magazine or book in this country. The story must not be printed or recorded anywhere in the world. You need to pay a fee of £5 to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story to us.
The closing date is 30 July, and we will tell the winner within one month. If you win, you must agree to have your story printed in our magazine.

THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST
Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many years, she was the only woman scientist in history books. Her father was the director of Alexandria University, and he made sure she got a good education. This was special because most women at that time could not study much.
Hypatia studied in Athens and Rome. After that, she went back to Alexandria and started teaching mathematics. She became famous for her knowledge of new ideas. We do not have her books, but we know she wrote important works about math. Hypatia also liked technology and created some scientific tools to help her work.
At that time, many leaders were afraid of science, and people who worked with it were in danger. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.

**Grass**
Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are more than 9,000 types of grass, and they grow in every part of the earth. Grass can live in very cold places like the Arctic and Antarctic. 
Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to big animals like cows and lions. All these animals need grass to survive. 
Grass grows back very quickly after it is cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, new grass grows from below the ground, not from the top. This is why many animals can live together in one place. When they eat all the grass, new grass starts to grow again, so there is always food for them.

Kal Kaur Rai is a young woman who loves fashion. She just won the title of Young Achiever of the Year at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she liked to draw clothes and create designs. She never told her parents, who own a supermarket, that she wanted to make fashion her job. She thought they wanted her to have a more traditional job, so she studied management at university.
After university, Kal moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. She went to many events but could not buy the expensive clothes she wanted. So, she started making skirts and tops for herself. When her friends saw her clothes, they asked her to make some for them too. 
Kal found a small shop in London that agreed to sell her designs. The clothes were very popular, and none of them came back. This made her feel confident, so she decided to leave her advertising job. She took a loan of £20,000 to start her own women's clothing brand. 
Kal's parents were happy for her and said they would support her. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business makes more than £500,000. Her designs are in fashion magazines, and she creates clothes for pop stars. Winning this award has made her well-known. 
Kal feels very lucky. She says, "What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this."

**Sunningdale Hotel**
The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has given great service to many people from all over the world. In the last 80 years, more than 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have stayed here.
The hotel is on a main road that goes to the town center. It takes about 20 minutes to get to the center by bus. Many buses stop outside the hotel, but guests should not take the blue buses with the sign "Express" because they do not stop near the hotel. There is also an underground station less than 100 meters away.
The hotel has 200 comfortable single rooms. Each room has hot and cold water. Showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of the hall. The hotel has a shop, sitting rooms, four TV rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are also eight pianos for guests to use. Guests can park their cars in the hotel parking area. Daily newspapers are free, and guests can buy stamps at the office.
Guests who stay for a long time must pay for their room every week in advance. They need to tell the hotel one week before they leave. Both short and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests get rooms first.
Meal times are: breakfast from 7 am to 9:30 am, lunch from 1 pm to 2 pm, and dinner from 5:30 pm to 7 pm. If guests are studying or working late, they can ask for dinner until 11 pm by writing their name on a list or calling before 7 pm. There are 10 choices for breakfast and dinner.
No animals or fires are allowed in the hotel. Guests should be quiet, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. If guests arrive by train, it is best to take a taxi to the hotel because it is far from the main train station.

**Tom Cruise**
Tom Cruise is a very successful actor. But his life was not always easy. When he was a young boy, Tom was shy and had trouble making friends. He liked to be in school plays, though. 
After finishing high school, Tom went to New York to find a job. He worked as a porter and also took drama classes. In 1980, a film director named Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. 
Ten years later, Tom became very successful. He was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood and made millions of dollars for each film. Today, Tom still acts in movies and has many fans all over the world.

'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? Bo the cat wanted to explore a furniture van. She had a big adventure! The driver found her after driving for more than 500 kilometres. It was a long day, and both the driver and Bo were hungry. The driver gave Bo some milk and tried to find her owner. He called his last customers, but they did not lose a cat. It was getting late, so he took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he took her to an animal hospital. Bo's owner was also looking for her. After searching everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that had come to his neighbour. He remembered the name of the company. He called them, and soon Bo was back home safely.'

**The Ghan Train**
Mark Ottaway took a train from Darwin, in the north of Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train goes across Australia, from the warm north to the cooler south. It is often called the "famous Ghan," but it is known for being late.
In the 1920s, there was a plan to connect Darwin and Adelaide by train. They built a line from Adelaide to Alice Springs, but floods often made it hard for trains to run. A new line was finished a few months before Mark's trip. The train can go up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a fast train. It has few stops, and most passengers are on holiday.
The Ghan was first built to carry goods, not people. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to the south of Australia by train would save time and money. The Ghan is said to be the world's first north-south railway.
When Mark waited to get on the Ghan, he saw that everyone was excited for the trip. Many of the passengers were older Australians. The first stop was Katherine, where the train stayed for four hours. Some passengers took a boat trip there. Mark did not get off until Alice Springs, where he went on a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, so they just walked around it and watched the sunset.
From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many passengers stop there. The view from the train after Alice Springs is not very interesting. There is a lot of flat land with cattle. But on the third day, they reached the hills near the Southern Ocean. Mark's journey was over. Even if the train did not meet all the promises, it took him to some amazing places in Australia.

**Climbing to the Top of Britain**
Every year, many people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. It is the highest mountain in Britain, and it can be very cold there. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first climb on Ben Nevis.
It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We climbed up the north side of the mountain to a place called Tower Ridge. It is 600 meters high, which is probably the longest climb in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the "Carries," which are big bowls in the mountain halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need these spikes because the snow is very hard, like ice.
Even though some people in my group were very experienced, we took a lot of safety equipment. This included lights to get help, hard hats, and extra clothes. The weather was good, with no strong winds, but we still felt nervous when we started climbing. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always hard.
The path went up, and my legs felt heavy. I was the weakest person in the group, so I had to take more breaks. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but as soon as I got to them, they started climbing again. I promised myself to train better before my next climb.
After climbing 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge. It is only 1.5 meters wide, and the mountain drops down hundreds of meters on each side. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, which is 48 kilometers away. But we were not lucky because a mist came down.
Getting back down to camp can be just as hard as going up. You need to read a map well because a wrong turn can lead to dangerous slopes in winter. I was happy we took turns reading the map. That first time, I only felt I really enjoyed the climb when I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top!

**Anna's New School**
This week has been very exciting because we moved into our new school building! It is a great place. The builders used wood to make it, just like our old school. But this school is special because it is good for the environment. 
The school took a long time to build. We watched the builders clear the land where the school would be. It was exciting, but it also meant that some nice land was gone. The building machines were very loud, and sometimes the builders had to stop because of the rain. We thought the building would never be finished.
Now, we have five big classrooms. They are much bigger than the old school next door, which was very old. We also share one room with people from the town for meetings. There is a nursery, a nice dining room, and big changing rooms. We can’t wait to use them when our new sports field is ready.
When you enter the school, you will see that there are no heaters! The heat comes from all of us inside - the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building keeps the heat and sound inside. If we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we are in a concert hall!
You will also notice that there is a tree on the roof! The builders put it there because it is a custom in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We went with our teacher to see it yesterday, and it spins very fast. It is so big that we can see it from far away! We took pictures to put on our website.
Even though we are using the school now, some parts are still being finished. For example, we are putting on a play for our parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall to do it. The new hall will be ready next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn much faster here!

A month ago, I did not know that on a Saturday afternoon in November, I would be 30 meters above the ground and having fun. Now, I looked down at the river far below me and understood why people like rock-climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The place where we stayed was not great, but we had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air.
On Saturday morning, we met the other ten people in our group. Cameron came with his friends, Kevin and Simon. Sisters Carole and Lynn came with their friend Amanda. We all came from different places and did not know the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outside, but we were not sure how.
Half of us went caving in the morning while the others went rock-climbing. Then we switched activities at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of pushing, we finally got out. We were covered in mud but happy and excited about what we had done.

**Letter to the Newport Evening News**
On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. Inside it were my cheque book, address book, and my purse, which had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized I lost it, it was too late. I didn’t know what to do. I am 72 years old, far from home, and I felt very worried. I stood by the road and cried.
A young man saw me and asked what was wrong. I told him what happened. He gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I told the bus driver, he said I could keep the fare. I got home safely, and soon after, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus. He said they found my handbag and would bring it back to me.
I got my handbag back, and everything was inside and safe. I want to say thank you to everyone who helped me that day. I really appreciate their kindness and honesty.
Mrs. B. James, Newport

**Sharks**
Sharks are some of the most scary animals in the ocean. They are very good at finding food underwater because they can see well and feel movement with special lines on their bodies. This makes sharks dangerous for smaller sea animals that they eat.
Sharks are like other fish in some ways, but their bodies are different. For example, most sharks must swim all the time to breathe and stay alive, so they do not sleep much. Also, if sharks are turned upside down, they can stop moving completely. This is helpful for scientists who study sharks. It helps them learn more about these interesting animals.

'Joining the Kirov Ballet
My name is Nathalie. Last year, I was one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. At my first ballet class, I was nervous because I didn’t know anyone. Everyone came to me and asked questions in Russian. I tried to speak in Russian, and then they started talking to me in English, so we could understand each other.
Now, six months later, everyone is very nice to me. My Russian has improved a lot, and I understand my teachers better. For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mom stayed with me. When she left, I felt a little sad. One night, I called her because I felt lonely.
The ballet classes in Russia are much harder than in England. I eat a lot to keep my energy up. This helps me perform well in class. In the evenings, I watch my favorite movies on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before they finish.
Now that I am used to living here, I feel at home. I enjoy walking around the city and visiting different shops, even in December when it was very cold. I bought a fur hat because it was minus 10 degrees Celsius, but the Russians said it was warm for that time of year! At least my room is warm and cozy.
Right now, we are getting ready for a new show, and there is a competition for young dancers that I will enter. I feel very lucky to be here.'

**THE ICEHOTEL**
For many years, people visited the Arctic in summer to see the land of the midnight sun. In winter, only a few people lived there, and they enjoyed the snow and ice. In the late 1980s, people decided that the dark and cold winter could be a good thing. 
In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit had an exhibition in a special igloo (a building made of snow) in the small town of Jukkasjarvi, on the frozen Torne River. This building was called Arctic Hall, and many visitors came to see it. One night, some guests thought it would be fun to sleep in Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and the idea of an ice hotel started.
Today, the ICEHOTEL is famous all over the world. When winter starts, a team of builders, architects, and artists from many countries come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. As they finish one part, it opens for visitors and guests, while they continue to build other parts. The first part is ready in December, and each week a new part opens until January 7th, when the hotel is finished. 
The ICEHOTEL is built outside, using snow and ice, so the finishing date can change depending on the weather. In spring, when it gets warmer, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, the temperature is never colder than -5 to -8 degrees Celsius, even if it is very cold outside. Guests get warm clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves included in their stay. It is also a good idea to bring sweaters, scarves, and thick socks. Guests should wear shoes that are a bit bigger than normal to fit the thick socks.
If you want to visit the hotel, you can buy warm clothes and other things on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these items when you book your visit, and they will be in your room when you arrive. The hotel is in Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can take a bus from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

**Shopping for Furniture**
A report by Dave Worthington
Homestyle is a new furniture shop. It opened at midnight last Thursday but had to close very quickly. Up to 6,000 people came to the shop. There were many special offers, like a leather sofa for £45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). 
The shop usually opens from 9 am to 9 pm every day, but it said it would stay open for 24 hours at first. However, it had to close just half an hour after opening. A police officer said that they knew a lot of people would come, but the crowd was not patient. The shop became very full, and the managers decided to close the doors. 
People outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold before they could go in. They did not want to wait in line. There was also a long line of cars trying to park. Many people left their cars in the road and walked to the shop, which blocked the road.
One customer, Jenny Smith, got into the shop. She said, "I waited in line for three hours, but I didn’t have time to buy what I wanted. The staff were calm and explained what was happening. They had to close for safety. I will come back when they reopen, but I don’t want to wait in line again."
